Review title: The Gold Standard Of Bond Films
Review_body:
Coming off the success of Dr No and From Russia With Love it seems hard to imagine how to continue that level of quality for a third time-somehow Goldfinger managed to do so. Many consider Goldfinger to be the best of the Bonds and while there is a compelling argument to be made,Goldfinger was a variation on the more serious,grounded previous films(From Russia With Love In Particular). But Goldfinger set a new standard and has served as an exemplar for James Bond films ever since.Sean Connery was still in his prime when he did this film complete with his suavness and bearing that made the character of James Bond what it is. When you have a hero as excellent as Bond you need a good villain(s) and Gert Fröbe and Harold Sakata were two of the best,in there own separate ways. After initial choice,Orson Welles,(who would have been fantastic in the part) demanded to much money the producers settled for the more budgetary and rather unknown Gert Fröbe as Auric Goldfinger. Fröbe pulled off the role beautifully blending all aspects of the character authentically;being sinister and contemptible yet not devoid of his own unique charm. And while Goldfinger is the main villain of the picture he is mostly the mind behind it all and his enforcer is is Oddjob. Oddjob is a mute so the performance relies exclusively on physical talent and former Olympian Harold Sakata couldn't have been more cut out for the role. Nearly every Bond villain mastermind since has had a silent,inhumanely strong henchman but none have ever lived up to the standard set by Sakata as Oddjob.The only real major flaw in this film is Goldfinger's plan and the ending. While not as farcical as others,Goldfinger's plot is fairly farfetched and planes dropping gas on Fort Knox is just a little too hokey. But it gives you the climax of:Bond trapped in a vault in Fort Knox,chained to a small nuclear weapon with Oddjob there to stop him and a battle raging outside. And just because there are some parts that are implausible,doesn't change the fact that on the whole the picture is pretty sensible-solving all problems with a logical answer.
While the script's plot may have some flaws the dialouge is nearly devoid of any. It has some of the wittiest,funniest and clever lines in a Bond film(and most other movies). The majority of which being delivered by Connery.
Another feature of this film that adds to its quality is John Barry's score. Even in some scenes in which you might not notice it immediately,its ever present and creates a whole new dimension to each scene.On a budget of 3 million Goldfinger grossed a total of about 126(a little over a billion in today's dollars). It was also the first Bond film to win an Oscar,it has been included on the AFI Thrills and BFI lists and remains a classic to this day.

Review title: Height of the James Bond Movies
Review_body: This is Sean Connery's pinnacle of the portrayal of James Bond.Auric Goldfinger is a classic James Bond villain who can only be surpassed by Mr. Blofeld. Oddjob was a truly scary villain as well. The villain's plan and the plot were well devised and not idiotic.The movie moves slowly by today's standard but not too slow. The movie itself has aged well except for those car chase scenes. The golden dead girl on the bed scene is one of the most memorable scenes in movie history.Also, did enjoy the strict adherence to the original book. That also deserves kudos.5/5. Sean Connery's top performance as James Bond. Hands down.

Although Goldfinger isn't my favorite in the series, I can see why others esteem it so much, even Spielberg in Catch Me If You Can. In an almost total departure from the approach of From Russia With Love, Goldfinger introduces 'the formula' of the pre-credit sequence, souped- up cars, gadgets, ridiculous stunts, peculiar henchmen, and over-the-top megalomanical villains (The girls were always there). The theme song is the most memorable in the series. In this episode the formula works because the elements are so fresh but in later installments it appears fatigued. Goldfinger, a masterpiece of pure entertainment: 9/10.

Review title: "...this is gold, Mr. Bond. All my life I've been in love with its color..."
Review_body: GOLDFINGER is an action thriller, the third in the James Bond series, in which the secret agent 007 tries to stop a crazy and rich tycoon in his intention to set up a radioactive bomb inside Fort Knox. It is based on the novel of the same name by Ian Fleming.The producers have refreshed and enriched a concept with excellent plots and cruel villain. Mr. Bond is surrounded, through a new concept, with a high-powered car and tricky gadgets. Of course, beautiful women circle around our charming agent. However, unlike the first two films, exotic, luxury and lustful games are reduced to a reasonable level. All this has changed the character of the main hero. Mr. Bond is more convincing and more serious in this film.The pace and direction is in the hands of villains. Mr. Bond is somewhat at a disadvantage. His charm and seductive skills do not affect a pilot who has an interesting name. However, we know that he will save, on a heroic way, with a little luck, this situation at the end, however, his position is not promising. The tension has a new dimension in the James Bond series. Therefore, this film offers more action and adventure compared to an exotic melodrama and love farce.Sean Connery as James Bond is a charming and cool hero. He tries to "pull the brakes" when it comes to women, which further enhances his charming performance and occasional jokes. However, sharing love with attractive blondes in exotic places is stronger than him.Gert Fröbe as Auric Goldfinger is a brutal psychopath who seems to have all the trump cards in their hands. He is a villain, who is ready for anything at any time. Mr. Fröbe has offered a good and convincing performance.Their support are Honor Blackman (Pussy Galore) as a frigid and capable Goldfinger's personal pilot and leader of an all-female team of pilots known as Pussy Galore's Flying Circus. Pussy will succeed to resist the charm of secret agent 007. Well, at least for a while. Harold Sakata as Oddjob is a sinister as a Goldfinger's lethal Korean manservant. His specific movement and a method of killing are very interesting. Shirley Eaton as Jill Masterson it a pleasant sight for sore eyes. Too bad she has quickly "painted" out.

This is what people think of when they think James Bond. It has all the ingredients. Sean Connery, Aston Martin, evil villain, pretty girls, and the weapon that will kill everybody. Yes. Goldfinger is arguably the most famous James Bond movie. James Bond (Connery) is investigating millionaire Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) and his plans to steal the US Treasury's supply of gold from Fort Knox. The scene when Bond asks: "You expect me to talk?" and then Goldfinger replies: "No Mr. Bond. I expect you to die!" has gone down as one of the most famous movie lines of all time. The Aston Martin DB5 has also gone down in history as one of the most famous movie cars ever. I'll end the review here by saying, Dr. No pioneered the Bond films, but Goldfinger perfected them.

The main weakness of this enjoyable Bond Film is the villains. Goldfinger in the form of Gert Frobe is very weak. Whilst Harold Sakada made for a really good Oddjob, this entire film needs a modern upgrade with someone who can pass as a vulgar murderous villain. Frobe does not have the charisma - given how many he kills to get to his "grand slam" he hasn't got what it takes to be a vile villain. Equally, for the female villain (honor blackman) to simply foil Goldfingers master plan simply cos she had a romp in the barn with Bond is most unlikely. Very watchable with some decent action but the ending comes too quick and is disappointing. I for one hope in due time this one is remade with a cast which is equal to the task of drawing you into their murky world. Bond fans will love this but there are much better ones as the series has progressed and it certainly isn't as good as "From Russia" which was one of the predecessors

I still think Goldfinger and From Russia are the best Bond movies. Connery at the top of his game here. This is a spoofier movie than the first two Bonds, but it works superbly. Great villain in Gert Frobe's Auric Goldfinger, and the best Henchman in all the Bond films in the guise of Oddjob.This is the film that really took off at the box office and launched Bond as the only serious rival to the Beatles in the 60's mania stakes. It was one of the most successful movies of all time on release, and Thunderball would excel even that performance the following year. Our story of course concerns Bond out to discover what Operation Grandslam is all about. It's great fun.Honor Blackman is one of the most memorable Bond girls. "I must be dreaming" is a classic Bond line.It's a shame in a way that Goldfinger proved the template for 70s Bond, films vastly inferior to this one. I can take Bond with a rubber duck camouflage hat; submarine cars not so much...

Review title: One of the finest Bond films
Review_body: Goldfinger certainly deserves its reputation as one of the greatest British films. Sean Connery really comes into his own in his 3rd instalment as Bond and the budget is evidently bigger than previously. It's also by far the most original of Connery's films with Dr No being rather bland (good but we've seen it all before) and From Russia with Love was critiqued as being a copy of North by Northwest, or at least taking too much inspiration from it.The villains in the form of Goldfinger, Pussy Galore (subtle?) and Oddjob are very interesting and not just carbon cutouts, Goldfinger is a supervillain but he has style and a sense of humour. And he poses an actual threat.This is where Bond really comes into his own for the first time, we have the gadgets, the girls, the locations and the action. It's all fantastic stuff.10/10: If you're a Bond fan you absolutely must watch this!

Review title: My third and THE third film of the JAMES BOND legacy
Review_body: I was very disappointed with this James Bond and so far (I have watched the first five James Bonds) it is my least favourite. I found there was a certain (uncomfortable) atmosphere about it different from any of the Bond films I have watched. Other things I did not like about it were the fact that all the good women died and James Bond was left with a b**** who was originally James' enemy! Also the villain Goldfinger does not really seem to demonstrate how evil he is, unlike many of the people in the villain organization Spectre. Furthermore the film was too slow and even the fight scenes seemed either slow or uninspiring.The main thing I did like about this James Bond was the performance of Sean Connery as James Bond himself. I feel we really came to know his character and his personal feelings to things in this film. His performance in the last two films, "Dr.No" and "From Russia With Love," were good as well, but I felt in "Goldfinger" he shone more. Oh - and the song "Goldfinger" is fantastic! :-) I recommend this Bond to people who enjoy the slower, more scheming fights and to people who love Sean Connery as BOND. Enjoy "Goldfinger"! :-)

Goldfinger may be the signature Bond film to many, but in reality it was one of the most ridiculous, implausible, and insipid of the lot. A woman dies from being painted gold, which is impossible. Goldfinger's all-blonde, all-lesbian pilots violate the airspace of a United States military base, crop dusting death from their Cessnas and they're not shot down by a squadron of F-100's. They gas all the soldiers in Fort Knox, who, in turn; are not really gassed because they are faking it. James Bond is held captive for what appears to be half the film. Cheesy battle between members of the armed forces and a group of Chinese criminals recruited by Mr. Goldfinger. Bond practically raped the head lesbian, she turns straight, and betrays all the other lesbians. Bond forces a girl to pull over in her Mustang by slashing her tires with his blade-equipped wheels on his tricked-out Aston Martin. He nearly kills her in the process, much like Messalah did in the chariot race in Ben Hur. The whole plot is silly and the movie is ultimately too dumb. Opening sequence was cool, the Aston Martin tooling around in the Alps was cool, and the theme song was incredible. Other than that, it sucked. And the fat Japanese dude with the metal frisbee derby hat? Very dumb. A heavy metal derby hat is not aerodynamically designed to float like a frisbee.

Review title: Best of the Connery era by far
Review_body: One of the best in the Bond enterprise, 'Goldfinger' delights with its action sequences, storyline, and actors. Honor Blackman is truly one of the all-time great "Bond girls." And of course, nobody does it better than Sean Connery as James Bond himself.

Review title: The Film That Changed Bond Forever
Review_body: 1964 was when the Bond films went from a rising film series to a worldwide phenomenon. What made that possible was Goldfinger. In a way, it continued on from the two films that proceeded it and yet a departure from them as well with its introduction of over the top characters, action packed pre-credit sequence, high profile gadgetry and larger then life (possibly even outlandish) plot. While this is the film that changed Bond forever is it the greatest?Leading that effort is Sean Connery's Bond. From the moment he emerges out of the water in the pre-credit sequence right up to the very last scene, Connery owns every single scene he's in. Connery even gets some good acting moments as well such as Bond's near outburst at M or Bond's quite desperation during the film's famous laser beam scene.. Connery also has great chemistry with his various female co-stars as well, all important thanks to the plot. This Bond isn't quite the rough and tumble character seen in either previous film thanks to a greater emphasis on humor but Connery serves the character and the film well.Gert Fröbe's Goldfinger changed the role of the Bond villain. While previous villains were physical as well as intellectual matches for Bond for the most part, Goldfinger was the first one that was purely the latter. Fröbe, dubbed by actor Michael Collins, gives an effective performance as the seemingly mild mannered businessman who is far more then what he seems. While not the best villain of the series, Fröbe's Golfinger remains for the most part effective nevertheless.Perhaps more effective and making the larger impact is Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore. That fact is no small feat considering that the character doesn't appear until around half way through. It helps that Blackman was somewhat older then the girls of the previous films which gives the character a sense of believability, especially when it comes to her chemistry with Connery's Bond. That chemistry helps to make a plot point late in the film believable if only just. Overall, Blackman makes the most of every second of the screen-time she has.The supporting cast of the film does good as well. Of special note is the short but famous appearance made by actress Shirley Eaton as Jill Masterson in the Miami portion of the film. Also making a large impact both in the film and on future henchmen is Harold Sakata as Oddjob who remains a menacing presence throughout, even if only using a shadow to do so. Rounding out the supporting cast are Tania Mallet as Tilly, Cec Linder as Felix Leiter, Lois Maxwell as Miss Moneypenny and of course Bernard Lee as M. And of course, Goldfinger is notable for making Desmond Llewelyn's Q a character whose presence would be looked forward to in every Bond film that followed thanks to Llewelyn's playing of the friendly antagonism between Q and 007. As a result, it's pretty well cast all around.The production values of the film are strong as well. Ken Adams return as production designer gives the entire film a larger then life sense from Miami hotel rooms to Q's lab, Goldfinger's rumpus room and of course the incredible (if incredibly unrealistic) interior of Fort Knox. Peter Hunt's editing keeps the film moving at a pace starting with the fast paced pre-credits sequence. Ted Moore's camera work once again serves the film well, especially during the scenes of the Aston Martin DB5 driving along in Switzerland or in revealing the scope of Adams Fort Knox set for the finale. The effects work is the only real downside to the production values thanks to some dodgy model shots with some all too visible wires. That said, the physical effects are superb such as the various pieces of DB5 gadgetry. The result is satisfying all around.Goldfinger though would be less effective without John Barry's fantastic score. The entire score is a showcase from the use of the James Bond theme in the pre-credits sequence to the stings used for Oddjob's appearances to the suspenseful underscoring of the laser beam sequence and the bombastic, yet suspenseful, underscoring of the climatic raid on Fort Knox. Not forgetting the opening titles song performed by Shirley Bassey which, combined with the opening credits that plays highlights of the film over a gold painted woman, sets up the film that is to follow. In fact, Barry set the standard by which future Bond scores would be judged.Which brings us to the two things that sets Goldfinger apart from its predecessors: director Guy Hamilton and its script. Both the direction and the script present a different take of the Bond world with emphasis on the more visual and larger then life aspects. This includes the introduction or greater emphasis placed on many of the aspects that have been discussed all ready. This is both a good thing and a bad thing. Viewing just this Goldfinger, those elements work splendidly in creating a suspenseful yet at times humorous adventure film. Yet the effect on the series as whole would only become apparent in the years to come as the filmmakers tried to replicate the successful formula of this film to the point of becoming heavily clichéd, if not self-parodying at times. Yet the work of both the director and the screenwriters serve this particular film very well.While Goldfinger isn't the greatest Bond film, it certainly has plenty to offer. From Connery's Bond to Gert Fröbe and Honor Blackman's larger then life character's to the supporting cast, the acting is good. The production values are fantastic as well from the sets to John Barry's score if one is willing to look past some occasionally dodgy effects work. Yet Goldfinger's introduction of certain aspects to the Bond films changed the series for both better and worse. So what can really be said about Goldfinger then is this: it changed Bond forever.

Review title: BOND#3: an Odd Obsession With Gold
Review_body: MASTER PLAN: use a dirty bomb to irradiate Fort Knox, thereby increasing one's personal wealth of gold. How good is the film "Goldfinger?" Enough that nearly every Bond film after this copied the formula - but none could, of course, completely match it. The now-requisite action teaser was itself imitated by James Cameron for his parody "True Lies" 30 years later. It's a great showcase for Bond's 'infiltrate & destroy' abilities, complete with a fun fight scene and deadly pun thrown in. This also had the first song sung over the credits, by Shirley Bassey - probably the best of the series, as well. The first post-credits sequence is in a spectacular version of Miami, where Bond seems to be vacationing. However, though apparently off duty, he has his first run in with the villain of the title and his 2nd meet with CIA liaison Leiter (a different actor from "Dr.No's" Leiter, as would usually be the case in the series). This entire portion has a relaxed quality, almost whimsical, but ends on a pretty grim note; that famous shot of the girl on the bed after Bond regains consciousness still sends chills down my spine, even after seeing it numerous times. The filmmakers remind a relaxed audience: hey, this is Bond's world; it's weird, it's scary; it's surely fantastic. Don't let your guard down.Where as Connery was the new breed in "Dr.No" and the consummate professional solidifying his status in "From Russia From Love," here he is already the familiar superstar, possibly the greatest star of the sixties at this point. His Bond is by now ingrained in the public's perceptions and can do no wrong. But, he's still a coiled spring, a waiting tiger, certainly not sleepwalking through an old role. When he's close to death, as does expectedly happen a few times during the course of this adventure, we still tense up, thanks to his performance. He does have some new toys to play with in this one, moving the Bond thriller away from the strict espionage tactics of the previous film. After the (extended) meeting with M, here is the prototypical instruction scene with Q, where he introduces Bond to his new, fully-equipped auto. This set the standard for the rest of the Bonders, but still outshines them all. And, check out the tour of the testing facility (we had a tour of SPECTRE's digs, a similar layout, in the previous film). The title villain follows Dr.No as the latest wealthy megalomaniac, but here he's much more colorful and deals with Bond throughout most of the film, unlike Dr.No's late appearance in the earlier film. And there's Oddjob, the brutish henchman; he has also never been equaled in terms of style and menace (Jaws came close in "The Spy Who Loved Me" over a dozen years later).Why has "Goldfinger" and its far-out elements never been surpassed? Well, how can it be? How do you top someone like Oddjob, that living brick of a thug and his hat? How do you outdo the ingenious yet simple plan against America's gold reserve, a combo of elegance and sheer audacity that must have sprung from the mind of the world's biggest egoist? How do you better a name such as Pussy Galore? It's all here: the larger-than-life villain; the unbeatable henchman; the classic femme fatale - she's depicted as Bond's equal, rather than as another Bond girl. The actress, Blackman, was not a simple young thing, like most of the Bond girls. There are also several classic scenes, now embedded in the minds of fans everywhere: the laser beam threatening Bond where it really hurts and Goldfinger's classic line come to mind, besides the one already mentioned with the girl on the bed. Everything came together splendidly in this one, including Bond's climactic battle with Oddjob (how do you beat an unbeatable foe?) and the main villain's final scene. Obviously, much of this par excellence is due to the source material - Ian Fleming's novel. On the downside, this started the trend to basically remake this with each new Bond film, but it can't take anything away from this one. Bond would return in "Thunderball." Bond:10 Villain:10 Femme Fatale:10 Henchman:10 Leiter:7 Fights:10 Stunts/Chases:9 Gadgets:9 Auto:10 Locations:9 Pace:9 overall:9+
