Title should have been: "007 Beds Everything In Sight". It seems no woman is able to resist his power of attraction. It's quite funny that they're still making movies with the same rampant horny main-characters in 2020.Plot holes galore: 007 literally throws down his gun, and allows himself to be captured by the baddies, when he actually could just have shot them all... and while we're on the subject of 'guns', why on earth would a secret agent use a 6 capacity revolver? He OBVIOUSLY has access to better guns. There's a myriad selection of pistols that can hold in excess of 15 rounds in a pistol magazine ie. the Browning Hi-Power (1935) can carry 15rounds as standard/unmodified.In another scene, 007 gets shot with a tranquilizer dart and IMMEDIATELY falls asleep. This is a known fallacy and no tranquilizer can paralyze (or knock out) a target in less than 30seconds, since it takes time for the tranquilizing agent to enter the bloodstream and reach the brain (yup, it has to reach your brain, not your heart/lungs like some people may assume).And let's not even talk about the 'gas' they use as a plot device in the movie... that is the biggest plot hole by far, as it's LITERALLY impossible for any gas to do what they showed in the movie.They for some reason like to speed up the footage in certain scenes. I noticed at least 3 scenes where they sped up the footage by at least 2x for seemingly no reason at all. It's really strange.Overall, it's an OK 007 action flick, but sub-par even for 1964 especially considering how unrealistic and impossible the plot-devices are that they use.

I don't know why, but the first time I watched this some years ago, I didn't think it was all that good.  Perhaps it was because I was somewhat young and had only seen some of the newest James Bond films.  But I recently obtained the DVD of the film and watched it again and found it to be much better than I remembered.The story is surprisingly smart and well written, and the pacing is very good, there aren't any long boring stretches of story.  The action is well placed, and very fun to watch.  Sure this film has it's flaws, like any other, but it's a good, fun movie.The cast is great, Sean Connery plays James Bond of course and very well I might add.  Gert Frobe plays the infamous "Goldfinger" very well, being quite ingenious and devious.  The women of the film are very nice to look at, as usual.  The rest of the cast was great as well.  I must admit that I really enjoyed the chemistry (despite being a short scene) between James Bond and Q.  Desmond Llewelyn expands his character, Q, from the previous Bond film: "From Russia With Love", very nicely.  Bernard Lee and Lois Maxwell both return to their respective roles, and pulling off great performances.  Harold Sakata plays the notorious henchman "Oddjob", very nicely as well.Another great reason to watch this film is to point out all the connections to the Austin Powers series, there are a lot so pay close attention for them...if you like or have seen the Austin Powers series that is.In comparison to the earlier Bond films, as much as I didn't want to say this before having watched it the second and third time, this film is probably better than both "Dr. No" and "From Russia With Love".  While they were both excellent films, this film seems to have a more interesting plot and just all around better done.  So, if you like any of the other James Bond films, you should definitely give this one a chance.  Just keep one thing in mind, this film was made back in 1964, so treat it like one.  I hope that you will enjoy the film.  Thanks for reading,-Chris

Review title: One of the best Connery Bond Films
Review_body: Such a great film in it's time. It was the first Bond film to appeal to teenage boys because of it's almost comic book look, the cars and of course the gadgets.Auric Goldfinger is a great Bond villain and the laser scene one of the most memorable in film history. 'Do you want me to talk?' 'No Mr Bond, I want you to die' - Pure genius that is.The Bond girls are all good and Honor Blackman looks amazing as Pussy Galore. Even though she was 38 she looks as good as any of her co stars.The only downside to the film was that the end was something of an anti-climax, apart from the fight with Odd Job.However definitely one of COnnery's best Bond films.

Review title: Probably the single most memorable villain in the series!
Review_body: Goldfinger is the apex of the Connery Bond films. The elements kept building as the series progressed, with FRWL one-upping Dr. No with greater scope and intrigue, and Goldfinger topping that with an even bigger villain. The series was now an institution and the public had high expectations of glorious stunts, memorable scenes, quick with, and the most beautiful leading ladies in film.Goldfinger launches things with a somewhat lackluster teaser, compared to the previous film and subsequent ones. Bond infiltrates a drug operation, via a scuba insertion (with tux ready underneath) and proceeds to quickly destroy it. He then takes a breather at a club, for a bit of relaxation and electrocution. Bond follows this up with a nice breather, though he finds himself embroiled in the crooked card game perpetuated by one Auric Goldfinger. Bond trips him up, but pays a price as we find his accomplice and lover painted gold and murdered. Bond is next pulled into a rather mundane mission revolving around gold smuggling, but gives it his all as he learns the target is Goldfinger. A game of golf brings our adversaries together again and the continue to cross paths as they journey to the big score: an attack on Fort Knox! The film introduces us to one of the most memorable villains in Goldfinger, played by German actor Gert Froebe (while dubbed) and the henchmen di tutti henchmen Oddjob (played by wrestler Harold Sakata). Goldfinger is the measuring stick for all megalomaniac's to follow. He is neither an agent of SPECTRE or the USSR, he is a villain of his own creation. Oddjob is pure thug, lacking in Red Gran't measured attacks, but making up for it in brutality. Oddjob would become a symbol for henchmen and would be copied and parodied endlessly.The gadgets we have come to expect really come to the fore here. Where Dr. No just gave us the Walther PPK and FRWL added the fantastic, but believable attaché case, Goldfinger gives us the Aston Martin DB5, with the most amazing optional extras to be found. We have machine guns (for clearing traffic jams, no doubt), oil slick dispensers, rotating license plates, a tracking system, and an ejector seat (no, we are not joking...). Strangely, Q forgot the cuplholder.Connery is really in the groove here and he is matched by the rest of the cast. Froebe is charming and menacing, while Sakata radiates danger. Honor Blackman leaves Steed to fend for himself, and enters our world as Pussy Galore, who proves to be not as immune to Bond's charms as she believes.The set pieces are memorable, from the golden "sacrificial lamb" to the laser torture sequence, to the battle for Ft. Knox and Bond's fight with Oddjob. The scenery isn't quite as exotic as last time, but it is varied, with Mexico, English golf courses, the Swiss Alps, and the southern US. And, just when you think everything is finished, we get a surprise attack at the end. All in all, one of the most memorable entries in the series.

This is the best Bond film, and a very good movie in any genre. Gert Frobe is the perfect arch-villain; not campy or played over-the-top as so many other Bond villains have been portrayed. Connery is at his best and seems comfortable and happy to be in the role. Honor Blackman is a very sexy Bond woman who can also act and carries her own in the film. Odd Job verges on the comic-book villain, but is an amusing and believable heavy and his fight with Bond is electrifying. The plot is suitably bizarre and almost believable. The Bond and Goldfinger golf course scene is great. The finale is the best in the series. The car chases and Bond gadgets are still believable and the special effects extravaganzas of the later Bond movies don't overpower the movie. The music is John Barry 1960's with the trademark twangy-guitar theme and the movie theme song isn't lame like most of the rest were. Along with this Bond film, the others to see are Dr. No and From Russia With Love. Avoid the Roger Moore series and also the one Lazenby film. I've recently been watching all the Bond films again and except for the two mentioned, they just don't compare to this one.

Review title: No different than its predecessors, Goldfinger is another fine action movie with no shortage of ridiculousness and women as objects
Review_body: Goldfinger is a solid example of the early Bond movies - a decent villain, but a plot with little substance that relies heavily on hand-to-hand action sequences and Bond seducing women constantly. Goldfinger has a fully coherent plot (more so than From Russia With Love), and my favorite villain yet. It drags a bit less, and on the whole I can agree that it's the best of the first three. It still is in the same category as the previous two, though - fine movies that just don't have much substance to engage with. The way women are constantly treated as objects for Bond to seduce and protect is extremely tiresome, and the fact that there's a nonconsensual kissing scene made it even more upsetting here. The entire plot and Bond's success rests on convincing Pussy (what a silly name choice) to see his side of it, despite a single paper thin scene of him pleading. The climactic action scene with the admittedly cool henchman with the steel hat was shockingly bad - one of the better parts of From Russia With Love was the solid climactic action scene, but here it couldn't be less convincing, with Bond throwing himself across the ground and hitting the wall with no force. I did like the callback to the opening scene of the movie with the electric shock, though. It's not a bad movie, it's just so mediocre and forgettable that it is truly odd to me how iconic Bond as a figure is, especially if this is the peak of Bond films.

Review title: One of the best in the series!
Review_body: James Bond`s enemy this time is Goldfinger, played by Gert Fröbe. Goldfinger has a desire for gold, and the British Intelligence send James Bond after him because they think he is up to something big, which he is. The action, the soundtrack and the atmosphere in this movie is very good. A must see!  Go for this one instead of the movies starring Timothy Dalton and George Lazenby. 9,5/10

What is it about James Bond that is so appealing to teenage boys and men? Is it the gadgets? Or maybe the Women? Or maybe the amazing adventures full of excitement and delight? Whatever the reason, the formula was best used in `Goldfinger.'`Goldfinger', which is the third Bond adventure, completes the Bond formula that was in development during `Dr. No' and `From Russia with Love'. In this film directed by Guy Hamilton (taking over for Terence Young) Bond (Sean Connery) is send in a mission to stop Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) from completing his `Operation Grand Slam' which involves the break in into Fort Knox which would make him the richest man in the world.Along the way he meets his newest Bond Girl, Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman) and Goldfinger`s sidekick Odd job. The film overall is the greatest in the series so far and Connery plays Bond at near perfection proving that he is the greatest Bond of them all.This is the film that set the standard for which all Bonds would follow and like its predecessors the film had its chair of gadgets. The most famous gadget in the film which is probably the most famous in the series is the Aston Martin DB5, which featured a reclining license plate, a tracking device, a water hose, and among others that blew audiences off their seat. Many actually believe this to be the greatest Bond car of them all, but I think it's all in the use. For instance the Aston Martin is useful to perform pranks on friends by water hosing them, if the next seat passenger is annoying then you can just press the little red button and throw them out of the car, now if you cheated on your girlfriend then the BMW from `Tomorrow Never Dies' would be your choice, since the car is unbreakable and can electrify you then no p***ed off girlfriend can mess around with your car, now if you want to go to Cuba and take care of some personal business then the car from `The Spy Who Loved Me' is the best car to use as you run free through water. Finally, while your girlfriend is trying to break your car and you're not taking care of personal business, then you can just cruise around the streets in your Aston Martin DB5.

Review title: "Do you expect me to talk?" "No Mr Bond, I expect you to die!!!"
Review_body: When Goldfinger rocketed onto the screens back in 1964, no one was anticipating the success it was going to contain. Sean Connery returns as James Bond 007 to stop the evil Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) and his henchman (Harold Sakata) destroy all the gold in Fort Knox. The film contains the action (the pre-credit sequence, finale), the girls (Pussy Galore, played by Honor Blackman) and the gadgets (Aston Martin). "Do you expect me to talk?" Who hasn't heard of the famous line said by Goldfinger to Bond? The film had huge detailed set pieces with the most amazing set being Fort Knox. The action which takes place within is exciting and gripping. It might be the James Bond/Oddjob fight or the race around in the Aston Martin, there is surely going to be a scene here for everyone. Shirley Bassey's powerful Goldfinger theme music is belted out. Even to today, the theme tune is still seen as one of the best theme tunes.Originally seen as the best, but now one of the best (along with Casino Royale). It contains one of the best cars, one of the best theme tunes and is one of the best films. James Bond will return in Thunderball.

Of the nineteen James Bond movies that have been made so far, "Goldfinger" is easily the best 007 film. It has everything. Great villains, great women, great action, great humor, and the best Bond of them all, Sean Connery. In "Goldfinger", James Bond faces off against the title character, a man obsessed with gold who is planning a major heist by breaking into Fort Knox. Gert Frobe, who plays Goldfinger, just might be the best Bond villain to date. Harold Sakata, who plays Goldfinger's mute henceman Oddjob, is every bit as good as Frobe. These two villains are definitely in the classic tradition of the 007 series. Honor Blackman is also excellent as the lead Bond woman, the no-nonsense Pussy Galore. And of course Connery is outstanding as usual in the role that made him famous. The action scenes are spectacular with excitement for start to finish. With a thrilling music score by John Barry and a smashing title song sung by Shirley Bassey, "Goldfinger" is the James Bond film that is absolutely perfect. None of the other films in the series are as perfect as this one. This is the best of 007!**** (out of four)

Review title: Sean Connery shines as Bond. The first great movie. 85/100
Review_body: In his 3rd outing as super spy James Bond, Sean Connery gives his finest performance in this role. He's suave in this movie in a way that he wasn't before...especially compared to the debut of this franchise ("Dr.No"). Never before has he been this likable...you just want to be with him...or better yet, be him! (hmmm...that's if you are a bloke).There are times in this movie when his attempts at bon mots or interaction with women aren't his high points, but they are buried under the rest of his charismatic performance.When I first saw this movie a month or so back, I was looking at scoring it around 8/10. Having watched it again the other day, I have to say how pleasurable it still was...the lovely chemistry between Connery and Honor Blackman, and just the winning persona of Connery as Bond in this movie. The first two Bond movie don't really have that 'repeat' viewing quality. For me, this is ultimate Connery as Bond movie. The plot is simple and Goldfinger's personal assistant is one of the most memorable henchman in the franchise...more memorable than some of the principle villains in the past or future movies.The setting:The U.S.A. (Miami, Kentucky); Geneva.The plot: Seemingly legit businessman Auric Goldfinger is suspected by Bond's organisation (MI5) of being a gold smuggler, so James is assigned to find out how Goldfinger is managing to smuggle gold undetected. Just by the by, you do get a nice snapshot of the business of gold early on in the movie...the world's changed since then...the British currency no longer is supported by the value of Britain's gold reserves. As for Goldfinger's actual scheme...it's wonderfully ambivalent...initially I just found it totally absurd, yet it does have its own diabolical logic which makes it insanely sensible! Looking at the end credits, it seems that the scenes supposedly shot in the US were done at Pinewood studios, in England...the studio made famous by the Bond movies. With this bit of information, it sort of makes sense now why the Americans didn't really sound convincing to me...but maybe they are real American actors, and not British impersonators.This is the first Bond movie to 'tick all the boxes' as far as the franchise formula is concerned: Pre-title sequence: Yes. You get the iconic gun barrel graphic, theme music and gunshot. Then the pre-theme sequence which now appears for the 2nd time, after the first movie did not feature it.Movie title theme: Yes. The first Bond movie where the theme song is at the start. And this is the first classic too...by Shirley Bassey, of course. Surely the greatest exponent of this formula. The lyrics pretty much give you the back story to Auric Goldfinger! Sexism: Yes. Bond comes off as patronising a couple of times in his dealings with women...by what he says ("Man talk") or a slap on the bum. This is a minor quibble, as he does come across as cooler other times, even when he isn't being the perfect gentlemen to some of the female characters.Silly female character names: Yes. You get the impression that "Dink" is a rather lame attempt at this formula, but gosh, you ain't seen nothing yet! One of the male characters has a rather odd name...literally. Both of these names gets 'satirised' in one of the Austin Powers movies.Wine snobbery: Yes. Thank God that even M has gotten sick of this trait by now! (he describes one of Bond's digressions as a "lecture"...bravo M!).Q: Yes. Second time in a movie, after the debut movie didn't have it. A fixture now.End credits teaser: Yes.Things to look out for: Famous last words by Bond: He makes a gratuitous comment about The Beatles, which had by then taken the world by storm...note how it combines old world taste in music with Bond's signature snobbery!...not often you hear the phrase "The Beatles" and "earmuffs" in the same sentence!"My dear girl, there are some things that just aren't done, such as drinking Dom Perignon '53 above the temperature of 38 degrees Fahrenheit. That's just as bad as listening to the Beatles without earmuffs!" 008 - This might be the first mention of other "00" spies...and that they may be better for some assignments than Bond is...as M lets him know, not too subtly.Bond's prowess - Not sure, but maybe the principle female character in this movie is supposed to be a lesbian...it seems to be hinted at, obliquely. Bedding her would surely cement the Bond legend, right? S.P.E.C.T.R.E. - you can't look at them. It's not featured in this movie...which might actually be why I like it so much.The end credits mention a technical adviser called "Russhon"...which is a name that appears in the movie...on a sign near Fort Knox. Speaking of which...how is accurate is the representation of Fort Knox?

James Bond: he's the man, and for his first couple of films it seemed like filmmakers had the Midas touch. In his third cinema adventure, the superspy's heroics and stakes are far bigger and more fantastic, and it adds up to one of the most escapist spy movies ever made.From start to finish, the film's pace is brisk, and it doesn't hold back. In one movie, Bond uses every ounce of resourcefulness, wit, and brawn against his adversaries. There is plenty of action, all really fast-paced and well-staged, if not really over-the-top and zany. Bond drives a car loaded with a ridiculous number of gadgets: machine guns, a smoke screen, radar, rotating license plates, an ejector seat, and a little thingy that comes out of the wheel to jack up other cars. These are cool scenes that pushed the Aston Martin DB5 into legendary status. When he isn't driving around, Bond fights bad guys with just about everything he can - guns, fists, and things in the environment. Among these fights, he takes on a Korean dude who seems invincible, and throws a lethal metal hat that can slice through solid stone. To help him, Bond makes allies with quite a few lovely ladies, one of whom is asphyxiated when she's covered head-to-toe in gold paint. At one point, Bond is tied to a slab with a laser beam creeping towards him; how does he get out of that? The whole movie is loaded with exciting and iconic scenes, and it breezes by smoothly and concisely. Each scene is really good, and there's never a dull moment.This story is as outlandish as they come, but the film carries no pretense. It is pure escapism, and the plot's absurdities play into the tone and style perfectly. The plot progresses smoothly, and a lot of conventions are introduced that carry over to future films (especially in regards to the sheer number of gadgets, action setpieces used). Bond is as cool as ever, while the villains carry a pretty decent presence and persona. However, all characters remain simple and one-dimensional.This film has very solid and interesting photography, and snappy editing. Sean Connery is still effective as Bond; Gert Fröbe straddles a line between playfulness and angst as Goldfinger, and it makes him fairly enjoyable to watch. I could always take or leave Honor Blackman - her character may have quite the distinctive name, but I found her character borderline unlikable. Other actors are alright. Writing is not bad. This production uses some very slick and colorful sets and costumes; some of the props seem really over-the-top (the insides of the nuclear bomb looks like a giant toy for some reason), and some of the special effects show their age. Shirley Bassey's theme song is a really strange and discordant song, but for some reason it's also really catchy, and it set the trend for future Bond theme songs. John Barry's score is very energetic, jazzy, and hip.What the film lacks in plot, it makes up for in action, energy, style, and sheer iconic status. It is one of the most essential titles in the series, and that makes it a must-see.4.5/5 (Entertainment: Perfect | Story: Pretty Good | Film: Very Good)

The characters and plot are just absurd. The movie doesn't dive too deeply into... well, anything. That makes it easier for the audience to miss quick sentences and actions that derail the plot or make the characters seem idiotic. The movie is essentially mindless action, and even the action lacks all believability.With that said, it's very clear to see how the Bond gadgets inspired decades of imagination. While Goldfinger's particular gadgets aren't entirely realistic, they do make one wonder what could happen if they were more realistic and used in a better grounded film.

Review title: Iconic, But Not The Best Bond. Surprisingly Cliche & Not Very Sexy.
Review_body:
I really enjoy the Bond films, so re-watching in order and rating these movies is one of the activities I most looked forward to when I decided to create this IMDB account. As a fan, I must say that this is an over-rated Bond film. The title is catchy - 'Goldfinger'. Titles matter. The next film, 'Thunderball' (1965) - terrible title. However, it turns out, 'Thunderball' (1965) is a much better film than 'Goldfinger' (1964).The biggest problem with 'Goldfinger' (1964) is Goldfinger, the character. Bond films are always filled with cliches, to the point that Bond films create cliches (see the animated show 'Archer' (2009)); however, Goldfinger is a list of cliches in one character. So, your villain in your third film is rich, huh? Ok. And, he's super smart... well, ok. What's that - he has a super-weapon, too? A big laser? Wow. Also, he has nuclear weapons. Really? Did he even need the super-laser? Not really... And, he has his own private army, too. *sigh* Cool.Personally, I think the worst thing about Goldfinger was that he travels around cheating old folks on cruise ships at gin rummy. What as *ssh*l*.Also, Pussy Galore, the top-billed 'Bond Girl' of the film? Yeah, not sexy.All things considered, this is a fine Bond installment with an overall weak plot, peppered with Sean Connery/James Bond performing unrealistic fight scenes with men and way-too-realistic abuse scenes with women.RealReview Posting Scoring Criteria:
Acting: 1/1;Casting: 0.5/1 (Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore was a mistake);Directing: 1/1;Story: 0.5/1 (The Goldfinger character sucks);Writing/Screenplay: 1/1;Total Base Score = 4Modifiers (+ or -):Authentic Location Shooting: +1 (As usual, this Bond film is packed with great location scenes. I like the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami.);Believability/Consistency: -1 (The fights were terrible, the antagonist character was ridiculous, and Pussy Galore might be a dude.);Cultural Significance: +0.5 (The idea of this film came to represent James Bond, and spawned parodies. However, I don't think most movie watchers in 2021 have actually seen this film);Total RealReview Rating: 4.5 (rounded up to 5 for IMDB)

Review title: Following in the steps of it's predecessor!
Review_body: From Russia with Love was a great Bond movie and so is Goldfinger. Story is very interesting and nicely presented leaving no room for boredom. Women, as always, are gorgeous, especially Shirley Eaton as Jill Masterson (scene of her dyed in gold paint is one the most iconic scenes from this movie franchise) and Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore. Especially great is the intro song sung by Shirley Bassey, and to this day it's the one of the best Bond songs (tradition which this movie started). All in all, fans of Bond will be satisfied with what Goldfinger has to offer, so I give the movie 9/10! I recommend it to everyone!

I've seen every James Bond film. From Dr No to Die Another Day. Sean Connery was the best one to play the debonair secret agent with a cruel, sardonic streak. Dr No and From Russia With Love were both excellent adventures in their own right, and provided 007 with situations that would become trademarks, such as dastardly villains and beautiful women. And then came Goldfinger. The one where everything clicked into place.Goldfinger is often regarded as the best Bond adventure in the series. And it's not hard to see why. This is the film where Bond's style was becoming established. And unlike some of the later adventures, this is a tightly plotted action film with excellent direction that leads from one classic set piece to the next. A joy from start to finish.007 is pitted against Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe). A dealer in gold bullion, he is about to pull off the crime of the century by knocking off Fort Knox. But his aim is not to steal anything. But instead to plant an atomic bomb to irradiate the gold supply, so his own gold stock will skyrocket in value.Goldfinger's plan is quite brilliant when you think about it. What separates his masterplan from the other megalomaniacs Bond tangles with in the future is the fact that it sounds plausible. There's no reason really why it shouldn't work. The only thing Goldfinger didn't anticipate was Bond.The best way to describe why Goldfinger is so enjoyable is because it's so much fun. From the very first frame the film works wonders with Bond in a wetsuit stripping down to reveal a stylish tuxedo. Then comes 007's tryst with a sexy woman, only to be attacked by a hit-man. There's a stunning camera angle where the killer is reflected off the girl's eyeball. One marvels at how that was accomplished in 1964!Then comes the fight. Which leads to Bond throwing him into the bathtub. Followed by an electric fan. "Shocking!" In any other Bond film that quip would have sounded cheesy. But in Goldfinger, it works perfectly. Followed by the song Goldfinger, sung with great ebullience by Shirley Bassey.It's not long before the actual plot kicks in, and the classic moments come thick and fast. Jill Masterson painted in gold. Bond's golf game with Goldfinger. Oddjob. The introduction of the Aston Martin. Bond's playful banter with Q. The ill-fated Tilly Masterson (sister of Jill). A thrilling car chase. And finally...The most famous scene of all. Bond's near emasculation by laser beam. That's such a gripping scene because Goldfinger has Bond. There's no way he can get out of this one. No gadgets. No gimmicks. "Do you expect me to talk?" "No Mr Bond. I expect you to die!" He only escapes through sheer luck by overhearing Operation Grand-Slam. Even though he has no idea what that is. He was just grasping at straws. It's rare that 007 finds himself in such a tight spot.Then comes the Bond girl, Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman). Very risqué that is! Unlike some of the simpering, moronic bimbos that would populate the series in future (cough Tanya Roberts cough), Pussy is smart, feisty, and more than capable of holding her own against Bond.It's at this point the action slows down a little. This is only a minor chink. But it does lead up to one very contrived scene where Goldfinger holds a meeting with a gang of hoods and explains in detail what Operation Grand-Slam entails. It is a very pointless scene because it's only purpose is for Bond to find out what the plot is. Goldfinger kills them anyway so you wonder what was the point.But aside from that, Goldfinger is a flawless film. Because of the way it perfectly balances action and humour, whereas Roger Moore's tenure degenerated into campy ludicrousness, Goldfinger has become the classic it rightfully deserves to be. Then we get the wonderfully constructed Fort Knox. That must have cost Pinewood Studios a fortune. It is so huge, and seems real right down to the smallest detail. Then comes Bond's fight with Oddjob and his killer bowler hat. And a fantastic fight it is too. Bond's method of dispatching Oddjob is clever, and very unexpected. You assume it's the hat that will kill him. And it does. But not the way you think.And finally, Goldfinger's demise. And an odd death it is too. But he had it coming. Capped by the customary final explosion. And Pussy surrendering to Bond's charms. The perfect end to a perfect film. The delights are plentiful from every angle. Even the cute gag when the bomb's timer stops on 007.Goldfinger has never been surpassed by any of the others. It is sheer perfection. Some have come close from time to time. But this still remains the series finest hour.

Review title: A Bond film with all the elements
Review_body: Goldfinger, the Bond film that made some of the most famous things of Bond that we know today, with big gadgets and great one liners, Connery excerpts brilliance and truly cemented his place in Bond history. A fun with that also packs a punch, Bond goes through a story with big villains with monster like henchman and with everything sparkling In gold, what else you could you want from a Bond movie, I felt this film was a safely very good and here below is why I felt that.The Story is fast and fun and with big things going on and a very dramatic but action packed story, the plot is fun and brings you really into the story. I loved the pace and where Bond goes and who he meets with some spectacular sets and parts where it may be slightly slower but then suddenly it speeds up and. Finally with the plot it has a good amount of thrilling parts, with the beginning and end being that, with the middle of the plot sandwich being Bond figuring out what is going on, great stuff.Connery does well in the lead role again and firmly brings out what we want to see from Bond, and with his gadgets and such to help, Connery isn't left without any help in his third outing to entertain us. I liked the villain Auric Goldfinger but it has to be said most of his shots when he is being his ever evil self involve Oddjob his devout henchman who's hat throwing skills make his of the most memorable people from this film if not of any film in the Bond series. Honor Blackman as the Bond girl I didn't feel was massively good but she carries Bond along well and make a different Bond girl than most of them we see.The script was good and contributes highly to Connery's great one liners he dishes out al through the movie. I loved the gadgets involved and is one of the Bond's that is actually good with the use of gadgets, for example like his Aston Martin with the revolving license plate and it's great gun's + more, you can't ask for much more in that department. Finally technical wise, it feels very well done as a production and although some films around the time has shabby and dim lit sets, Bond's sets are great big ones and even one of the more humble Bond's.The film isn't without criticism, it has it's parts where it drags just a little, but to be fair to the film the good parts basically make up for the parts where it maybe slightly misses the mark. I also felt the story is kind of ridiculous and that although most critics and audience alike like the film, many I feel would have to admit that the story Is kind of far fetched for even a Bond Movie, can't damn it for it's wacky ideas though.Bond fans should fall in love with this and probably already are with stereotypical Bond all the way through this, and with ease. Those who enjoy the three genres Bond is, Action, Adventure and Crime will not displeased by this as it also represents them in a good way with the villain being a good criminal, Bond fights a lot and with that he goes to a lot of different places also.It is safely very good, I will disagree with those who think it is a GREAT film but nevertheless I can see why they feel that way about this. Connery really brings Bond to life here and with thrill and a suave personality that just makes you want to see them all, by far this is Connerys best and wouldn't be surprised if you thought this was THE best Bond film of the entire film series.

Review title: "He loves gold. He loves only gold. Only gold."
Review_body: You don't review James Bond movies, you evaluate them, rate them according to how well they meet expectations. There are certain things one has come to expect, even demand of a Bond film and each individual effort either delivers or it doesn't. So, here are ten elements that make a Bond film a Bond film and how GOLDFINGER rates on a scale of 1 to 10: Title: GOLDFINGER: Certainly a strange name for either a movie or a human being, yet it does bring together two concepts perfectly: Greed and phallic symbolism. 8 points.Pre-Credit Teaser: Bond blows something up, kisses a girl, kills a bad guy and delivers a one-liner. None of which are important to the ensuing story. 3 points.Opening Credits: Having used a woman's naked flesh as a screen for a slideshow of the opening credits in FROM RUSSlA WITH LOVE, Maurice Binder takes the next logical step and uses moving images this time. It's only afterward that it might dawn on you that the lady in question this time is a gilded corpse. Creepy. 7 points.Theme Song: As the prototypical Bond theme song, the incomparable Shirley Bassey empowers it with a sultry sensuality, even as the lyrics are about greed, betrayal and murder. The first Bond song to become a classic. 10 points."Bond, James Bond": I think this is the film where Sean Connery officially takes control of the character of James Bond and of the film series itself. You don't sense that he is playing a character, but the character is a part of him. Possibly the quintessential Bond performance. 10 points.Bond Babes: The notion that Bond Girls are rather disposable probably took root here. The ill-fated Masterson sisters, Jill and Tilly, come and go rather quickly, but Shirley Eaton's glittery death under a coat of gold paint is unforgettable -- and became a symbol for the series as a whole. However, despite her attention-getting name, Pussy Galore isn't really that interesting of a character. Though ex-Avenger Honor Blackman set a standard for lesbian chic, she seems to switch sides, so to speak, awfully quick. 7 points.Bond Villain: Auric Goldfinger is the perfect Bond villain: Gert Frobe plays him with childish arrogance, a tad of hamminess and a sense of humor. Bond would meet other self-made millionaire, out-to-control-the-world megalomaniacs in the decades to come, but none would stand out with such a distinctive flare. "No, Mr. Bond, I expect to you die!" Great line. 10 points.Bond Baddies: Okay, this is arguably where the Bond series begins to get a bit campy. A Korean butler with a sumo wrestler's body and a lethal, steel-brimmed derby is colorful, to say the least. But Harold Sakata's Oddjob became a cultural icon and earns a well deserved tip of the hat. 10 points.Plot: Possibly the cleverest of all the Bond narratives, the film finds Mr. Goldfinger hoping to nuke Fort Knox in order to contaminate the U.S. gold reserve and up the value of his own gold supply. A bit ridiculous, maybe, but so much better than traipsing around looking for some arbitrary McGuffin. 8 points.Production values: An escalating budget is reflected in the slick and polished look of the film. For better or worse, the low-budget grittiness of the previous Bond film is gone for good. 7 points.Bonus Points: That Astin Martin! You've got to love that Astin Martin. 5 points.Summary: Regarded by many as the best Bond movie, it is the gold standard upon which all future films in the series will be judged.Bond-o-meter Rating: 85 points out of 100.

Bond hits the big-time. After 2 so-so films, the 3rd hits the mark, there must have been some doubt after the first and again after the 2nd whether they would continue with the series. But this film settled it, if this was poor we would not be talking about a Bond series, as it would have ended, but this made it.Sean Connery is great in this, with Gert Frobe, making a great bad man. Honor Blackman is great, looking good as well as acting good, Harold Sakata a Japanese/Hawaiian provides the Korean Odd-Job Henchman, one of the best although a non-speaking role. Cec Linder played Felix Leiter in the character's comeback, but not very well. Bernard Lee, Lois Maxwell and Desmond Llewelyn play the usual team.The action scenes are good, but it's the story and the intrigue that do it, it sets the scene for the rest. The locations were all good too, almost all authentic, Miami and Kentucky in the USA, various areas of Switzerland did for Geneva, and the Golf course was in Buckinghamshire, England, however many of the scenes supposed to be there were faked in the studio, but the scenery that was on offer was great and well photographed. The music was great, composed by John Barry and the title song sung by Shirley Bassey, one of the best, probably only beaten by herself again - Diamonds Are Forever A New Bond theme started in this film was Cars, the first appearance of an Aston Martin, a DB5, however this was not the best car in the film, there was a red & white Ford Mustang convertible but the real car star was the 1937 Rolls Royce Phantom III Sedanca de Ville, if I had the money, that's the one I would have chosen. Spectre sat this one out though.On the Bond Girls, the Main one was Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore, however he had at the start Nadja Regin (no. 8) a Serbian who appeared as a Belly Dancer, she was in the last film as well, but in a different role, the inclination was he had already had her and was going back for seconds, then Margaret Nolan (no.9) a British actress (a large busted woman who appeared in a few Carry-On's) who played the character Dink, then Shirley Eaton (English, no.10), easily the best looking Bond girl up to this point, who played Jill Masterson and had the famous scene painted in Gold, then her character sister Tilly Masterson (no. 11), played by Tania Mallet from Blackpool, although he did not get around to shagging her before she got killed. Then Pussy Galore, making her the 3rd Main "Bond Girl" but 12th in total so far.A great addition to the series, and one of the best of all time, despite a few faked scenes, without those I would have given a 10.
Still the best of the Bonds in my opinion an all time classic. Love this movie.

This is the point where the Bond series really fired into action-terrific stunts, explosive action, good set pieces, memorable villains, car chases, gadgets, and feisty, strong willed women. Probably deserving of being called the best Bond movie, though it is not my favourite, as it has everything a Bond movie should have. It also stands beside other action films for its excitement levels, is full of one-liners and memorable images, and has a very good plot and strong performances from everyone.Bond is investigating a gold smuggler, in a brief turn away from the full blown SPECTRE plots of previous films, and uncovers a plan to destroy the world's economy. Bond meets Auric Goldfinger, the man believed to be responsible, and soon is struggling to stop the plan and save the world.Famous moments- The Jill Masterson 'turns to gold' scene. The 'Shocking' bath moment. The famous Aston Martin's ejector seat scene. The laser scene. These are a few. Pussy Galore, as her name may suggest is Bond's 'girl' this time, and is easily the strongest female character to date in the series. We have Oddjob, a terrifying silent assassin who uses his steel rimmed bowler hat to dispatch of his enemies, one of the best bad guys in any Bond movie, and Goldfinger himself, the archetypal Bond Villain, smart but...dumb. The theme tune is one of the strongest, and the film made sure that Bond had a place in movie history. 8 out of 10.

I am no big fan of James Bond films.I have seen them all on television many times.But this is the best Bond film.Sean Connery is very good as Bond and Oddjob is funny.The last 30 minutes is pretty silly.4/5

In this 3rd entry to the James Bond series, Bond starts off by investigating a man named Auric Goldfinger, to see if he's cheating at a card game. When Bond straightens Goldfinger out, Goldfinger quickly strikes back, killing Bond's latest fling. Bond wants to find out more about Goldfinger, so he goes on a mission to find out what he's up to. Bond finds out that Goldfinger is attempting to have a nuclear bomb go off inside Fort Knox so that nobody can touch the gold for years, and the price of his personal gold supply will go up. Now with the help of his CIA friend Felix Leiter, Bond will attempt to stop Goldfinger once and for all. This entry into the series is and always will be the best.The reason why everyone and their brother loves this movie so much is that it features all the classic James Bond elements. You have the famous scene where Goldfinger attempts to cut Bond in half with a laser. You have the famous 1964 Aston Martin DB5 complete with machine guns, an ejector seat, and oil slick. This is the first James Bond movie to feature a title song over the opening credits, brilliantly done by Shirley Bassey. This movie features not one, not two, but three Bond girls. Jill Masterson is definitely in the top five hottest Bond girls. I actually feel that her role and Honor Blackman's role should have been reversed, because Honor Blackman isn't the most attractive Bond girl there is. Every scene in this movie is great. It has more action than the first two films and yet it still has a great story. Auric Goldfinger makes a great adversary for James Bond and Oddjob is the greatest henchmen James Bond has ever had to face.Everyone in this movie gave knockout performances. In my opinion, this is Connery's best performance as Bond. Gert Frobe is excellent as Goldfinger, and Honor Blackman is good as the main Bond girl of the film, though she isn't the most attractive Bond girl ever.Goldfinger is the best film in the series and Bond fans should always go back and watch it after seeing crap like Moonraker or Die Another Day.8.5/10

Goldfinger is one of the very best Bond movies. The plot and the characters are exactly what you'd wish for. Especially Pussy Galore (that name must be one of the worst the film industry has ever come up with, along with Snake Plissken of "Escape from New York") and Oddjob, the hat-flinging body guard.If one should watch the JB's out of order, see this one first.
A good installment of the James Bond franchise one of my favorites. Definitely worth a watch.

Bond (Connery at his peak) battles against gold-obsessed Auric Goldfinger's wild operation Grand Slam, while charming the dames, fighting decapitating-bowler-hat-wielding midgets and preserving a superhuman sense of class and style.It is with "Goldfinger" that the definitive elements of the Bond formula really fell into place, from the superb pre-credits sequence referenced in True Lies (Bond removing a wetsuit to reveal a perfectly ironed tuxedo) to the legendary title-song, through the action and over-the-top villains, "Goldfinger" attains a balance of class, ruthlessness and silliness that no other Bond film would reach. Connery blasts all other Bond incarnations out of the water, keeping his steely cool even when threatened with laser castration (one of many classic scenes). The villains are a fitting match, from Goldfinger's insecure megalomaniac to the mute killing machine that is Odd Job. And how can you deny the genius of a film with the following dialogue:Bond: "Who are you?" Pussy: "My name is Pussy Galore!" Bond: "I must be dreaming..."A few Bond films have come very close to matching Goldfinger's perfection: "You Only Live Twice" and "The Spy Who Loved Me" in the action and wildness departments, "From Russia with Love" and "Living Daylights" on a more serious side, or even the more recent "The World is Not Enough" in its use of the Bond character. But Goldfinger will always be the ultimate James Bond flick!A treasure: often imitated, never bested at what it does.

Sean Connery's third go around as James Bond has become the quisessential James Bond Flick and for good reason..from the catch opening chorus by Shirley Bassey and the intro pretty lady decked out in gold to oddjob's hat and the name of the bond girl Pussy Galore..What else could one ask for? The most popular and arguable the best Bond as James tries to stop Goldfinger and his pilot from robbing Fort Knox.. On a scale of one to ten... Goldfinger strikes a 9

Review title: I can see why this is regarded as the best Bond.
Review_body: Although not as sophisticated as "From Russia With Love" it does have a unique storyline at the time. Sean Connery reprises his role for the third time as super spy James Bond, and in this movie he had achieved cinematic gold.The plot, as like the novels, is trimmed down by screenwriters, but somehow it works better in this one as the pace in increased in the film. New Bond director Guy Hamilton gives us a stylish "new" look and James Bond, and the screenplay also ave us one of Bond's most memorable lines, "Lemon-marinated vodka martini. Shaken, not stirred." Connery delivers, as always. I guess you couldn't say anything about him now. Gert Frobe plays the titular villain who plans to destroy Fort Knox delivers his performance with chilling brilliance. Honor Blackman plays Frobe's right hand woman Pussy Galore (God bless Fleming for that name!)James Bond isn't James Bond with gadgets. That is why Desmond Llwelyn returns with an impressive array of gadgets, including the mouthwatering Aston Martin DB5, which is a prized item in any extreme Bond fan.Overall, not in par with "From Russia With Love" (at least for me), but still deserves a spot in the James Bond classics.9.42/10Delton

Review title: This is my all-time favorite James Bond movie.
Review_body: "Goldfinger" (1964), whenever someone mentions James Bond, or anything else related to the franchise in that category, I immediately think of this film. This is, without a shadow of a doubt, my all-time favorite Bond movie in the series. It has a perfect story, perfect acting, perfect sets/locations, perfect special effects, and of course a perfect soundtrack to tie it together. The story is, a man named Auric Goldfinger, played by Gert Frobe, is planning to rob the gold from Fort Knox and it's up to Bond to put an end to his schemes. Now, to most people, the plot at first glance may sound kind of pedestrian. But, that's one of the biggest reasons why it works so flawlessly. A perfect storyline for any spy film should be simple, yet complex, which is exactly what "Goldfinger" delivers and then some. When the plot is simple, you get more invested in the story and the characters and the complex part is where it captivates the viewer to keep guessing all the way through. This movie has stellar action scenes, great drama and also includes a few laughs along the way from beginning to end. It also includes my personal favorite exchange in the series, where Bond is strapped to the table by Goldfinger and is about to be sliced with his laser. I don't want to spoil it in case you haven't seen the film, but, you'll know the lines when you hear them. The plot does have a few over the top moments, but that's what makes this movie so much fun. All of the Bond films have their over the top elements and most of them are hit and miss. But, when those over the top moments are utilized properly, they can be effective in the best way, which is what "Goldfinger" brings to the screen seamlessly along with the other four contenders on my top five Bond films list. As far as the acting goes, it's some of the best I've seen in the franchise. Every respectable actor and actress perform their characters flawlessly. Sean Connery is perfect as James Bond, Gert Fröbe is perfect as Auric Goldfinger, Harold Sakata is fantastic as Oddjob, Honor Blackman is brilliant as Pussy Galore, Desmond Llewellyn nails it as Q, Bernard Lee is stellar as M, and so on. All of them really bring their characters to life! But, the shining star has got to be Sean Connery himself. He is my all-time favorite James Bond actor out of the six. He was born to play this role! Every other supporting actor in this movie is just as stellar as well. The chemistry between the characters is impeccable! All of the sets/locations are stunning, and give this film a beautiful atmosphere. You can't go wrong with filming your movie in Europe, or anywhere in North America! All of the special effects are perfect and still hold up to this day. Finally, the soundtrack composed by John Barry is phenomenal. John Barry is one of my top 10 all-time favorite film score composers, and the soundtrack for "Goldfinger" is one of his best. It also has one of the best theme songs in the series, the title song: "Goldfinger", by Shirley Bassey. Now, I understand that a big and brash song like that may not be for everyone. But for me, it sets the tone perfectly and gets you into the mood for the movie right away. Her voice does sound a little brassy at times, I suppose a good nickname for her would be Shirley Brassy! That being said, it's the perfect theme song for this film and it hooks you to the story immediately. "Goldfinger" is nothing short of a masterpiece. It's my all-time favorite Bond movie! I can watch it over and over again and never get tired of it. Of course, I give this film 5 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 10 out of 10 IMDB stars. If you're getting into the Bond series for the first time and don't know where to begin, start with "Goldfinger". It is the epitome of James Bond movies and it set the standard for not just the Bond franchise, but for spy films in general. Let's wrap up this review by giving a moment of silence for the late, but great: Harold Sakata, Gert Frobe, Honor Blackman and the one and only Sean Connery. May you all rest in peace and thanks for all the years of entertainment. Any way, go and see "Goldfinger" today, it is pure gold!

Rewatching all the Bond films in preparation for the new one and rewatching this again was brilliant. I forgot what a good film it is. I agree with another reviewer, it's quintessential Bond! The one liners, the look and feel of it.

Review title: James Bond is the man with the midas touch
Review_body: Goldfinger is perhaps the most famous Bond of all. The Action is fast and the suspense is kept on a constant boil. Sean Connery already feeling the restraints of Bonadage delivers a cool crisp performance here. The Gadgets such as the gadget ridden Aston Martin helped push Bond's popularity up even more. even The bizarre murder of a girl at the film's start She's murdered by gold paint. this leads to Bond having a vendetta of sorts he wants to avenge the girl's death But when M gives him a assignment that concerns Goldfinger Bond is more then happy to take the mission. the plot is not your standard Bond plot. Goldfinger is gathering a group of Mobsters as well as his own considerable air force to commence operation Grand Slam. We find out along with Bond what Grand Slam really is. It appears Goldfinger is working for SPECTRE and they want Goldfinger to invade Fort Knox and set a nuke off in there to make the gold untouchable for at least 59 years . This would throw the world's gold market into chaos and increase the value of Goldfinger's own gold and with the USA'a Gold finances in chaos the USA would tumble into chaos. Brilliant plan except Goldfinger has not counted on 007 to spoil the plans. This movie has the most famous of everything 007 From the most famous villain and his henchman Goldfinger and Oddjob to Bond's most famous lady Pussy Galore wonderfully played by Honor Blackman. To the most famous torture scene in Bond history. Bond faces death by laser while laying on a gold table. "Do you expect me to talk Goldfinger?" "Noo Mr. Bond I Expect you to die" This movie makes the Claim that the Bond movies themselves are a work of art. And if you don't believe me just pop some popcorn sit back shut your brain off and be prepared to Enjoy yourself with a action movie that delivers all the thrills chills and excitement you can actually want from a movie.

I don't rate this as high as From Russia With Love despite the fact that it is the most popular and widely admired of the Connery Bond films. It is slicker and more fast-paced, but it never quite attains the grittiness of its predecessor.Bond: Connery virtually owned the role by now and could really do no wrong on screen. There is really no reason to carp about any of his choices here.The villains: The film is blessed with two of the great Bond villains. Gert Frobe's odious gold-obsessed Goldfinger pretty much makes the mold from which many subsequent megalomaniacal villains would sprout, but few seemed as authentic. The torture scene with a laser slowly heading for Connery's crotch while he tries to verbally outwit Frobe is certainly one of the most inventive moments in the series. Harold Sakata's hateful henchman Oddjob, with his legendary razor-sharp hat for beheading hapless victims, surely ranks at the top of most effective Bond villains. The women: Shirley Eaton got a lot of press as the "woman who gets painted gold" but she really is not in the film enough to have too much impact. Honor Blackman, as anti-heroine Pussy Galore, is the first resourceful Bond woman who does not require rescuing by the hero, but I am not as fond of her as other Bond women. She is attractive, but missing an element of vulnerability or appeal, and I am never completely convinced of what motivates her at the end of the film. The transition in her character does not make a whole lot of sense.The plot centering on a robbery of Fort Knox is perfect Bond and actually seems halfway possible. The film moves like a rocket and does not get bogged down in too many details, as some subsequent entries do. A perfect example of a prime Bond film - hard-edged and brimming with dark humor and action. Shirley Bassey's title song is arguably the best from the series.

Review title: NO MR BOND, I EXPECT YOU TO DIE!
Review_body: This was my favourite of Sean Connery's 007 adventures, it was faster paced and Bond seemed in real jeopardy which wasnt always the case in the previous 2 films. Dr No was an introduction to mainstream cinema...testing the waters as you will. From Russia with Love was a cold war thriller that worked brilliantly but didnt necessarily set the tone for the future. Gaoldfinger on the otherhand was exactly the blueprint that Ian Fleming's series would follow for the decades to come. Goldfinger and Odd Job were delightful villains and Pussy Galore went down as one of the most recognisable Bond girls ever. Bond and Goldfinger have back and forths that leads to Bonds capture whilst Goldfinger attempts to unearth his masterplan in Fort Knox. Brilliant film and in my top 5 Bond films to date

Review title: Bond maintains his charm in a film that begins to look tedious
Review_body: James Bond has no problem using treacherous women as a shield or exercising his judo as a tool of seduction; Bond is still Bond. The problem is with the design of the film: a lot of improbable things put together: an overly talkative villain who could never be so successful in real life, a string of naive mobsters, an assistant who falters at the first plot, incredibly accessible women, and a James Bond who is unlikely to be saved from any trouble. Already in this film, after two good films, we see that Bond becomes a parody of himself. The film entertains but generates reservations about a future that we know will turn increasingly black.

Much of James Bond's third big-screen outing is amusing, and much of the amusement is intentional.  Even now, after countless viewings of this film, it's hard not to smile at the name of Pussy Galore.  And Goldfinger's response to 007's question, "Do you expect me to talk?" is classic:  "No, Mr. Bond.  I expect you to die."  On the other hand, one is more likely to snicker than smile at the scene in which Goldfinger brings together most of the country's crime bosses, all of whom panic and behave like frightened school girls at the sight of a pool table that moves electronically across the floor.  Then there's the silly, all too sudden way the U.S. Army passes out after a fleet of planes drop poisonous gas from the sky.  The soldiers drop to the ground as quickly as the characters in "Plan 9 from Outer Space" did when the UFO whizzed by, flashing a beam of light as powerful as a wooden match.  Fortunately, such moments are few, and "Goldfinger," one of the best of the Bond thrillers, remains as entertaining as ever.  As Pussy Galore, Honor Blackman proves that a woman need not be under 30 (or even 35) to be sexy, and Connery's performance as Bond is his best in the series. 007 was truly defined in this entry.
Bond is WHOA GOldddddddfinggggggger goldfinggerrrr he's Goldfinger so Bond FUN

The first of four Bond films directed by Guy Hamilton, and by far the most iconic entry among critics and fans. Pretty much all the Bond movie clichés started right here!! Great theme song by Shirley Bassey, contains some of the most memorable scenes of the franchise (Do you expect me to talk?), fantastic gadgets, and Bond has some truly funny one-liners. The whole affair really feels like a 60's pulp-thrill comic book brought to vivid life, and I mean that in the best sense possible. However, with all these elements that surely make Goldfinger an entertaining flick, why is it I don't LOVE this entry as much as everybody else does? I think it comes down to two critical things: 1. Despite her outrageously hilarious name, I find Pussy Galore to be the most over-hyped Bond girl of all time. Outside of her name, I just find her to be a bland, unremarkable character and don't get me started on the infamous barn scene. 2. The second act, in which Bond is a prisoner of the title villain, is a bit too slow-paced and nearly grinds the whole affair to a dead halt. The fact that the whole second-half of the movie takes place in America doesn't help matters (I find pretty much all the Bond movies that take place in America to be boring) Don't misunderstand, I do enjoy this movie and I do appreciate it's importance to the franchise, but it doesn't even break my personal top ten Bond entries.

Review title: The Most "Bondish" Film of them All
Review_body: This was the third Bond film after "Dr. No" and "Fron Russia with Love" and for many it is the best one in the whole series. I don't know about that, in fact I enjoyed a lot the first two also, but no doubt "Goldfinger" is probably the all-Bond-picture.Sean Connery plays the 00 agent as good as no one after him did so far; his elegant sarcasm and arrogance fit perfectly well with the paid killer Bond really is though he works for the British Secret Service. His car has all the imaginative tricks and Bond makes good use of it; an interesting plot; fine outdoor locations and lavish settings; an excellent and eccentric villain (Gert Froebe) and his menacing and deadly side kick; beautiful Bond girls (Shirley Eaton, Honor Blackman and Tanya Mallet), and great moments (Bond's last meeting with Oddjob works great and Eaton's golden death -though probably impossible in such a short time- is most ingenious).Which one is the best Bond film will depend on each ones particular taste, but in my opinion no one is as much a Bond film as this one.

What I like about this Bond-film is that it's so contemporary without being to cheesy. Sean Connery is one of my favorite Bonds and Goldfinger is one of my favorite movies.What I like about the Connery Bonds is the fact that the gadgetry was still more down to earth and did not play an overly emphasized role. Here we have more room for interesting characters and settings.If there's something I didn't like about this Bond it would have to be the sped up scenes that always stand out like a sour thumb. Also while to movie is quite crisp it still has some distance to go before it reaches the same level of drama as Dr. No or Golden Eye.A great film, none the less.

Review title: The decline of Bond the spy and the birth of Bond the cartoon
Review_body: Goldfinger is more crowd-pleasing, perhaps, than the cloak-and-dagger style of "From Russia With Love," but it holds up less well over time. Bond aficionados can trace the appearance of some iconic elements of the franchise to this installment, such as the Aston Martin and the emphasis on gadgetry. Few Bond songs are as good as Shirley Bassey's eponymous theme. The pre-title sequence here, a few minutes of anything-goes action unrelated to the main plot, created a tradition that would be repeated in most future Bond titles. Yet the extreme campiness of the plot and the villains strain credulity and take Bond out of the realm of traditional espionage heroes. Fans of Bond the spy as opposed to Bond the superhero may well lament "Goldfinger"'s emphasis the bizarre and the outrageous.

It's no Casino Royale "the family jewels" torture scene, but it will make you squirmy for all you men out there.I prefer the first half over the second. The first half's grittiness-all though, not fully shaken or stirred-is still present and drawing. The second half is merrymaking, but it becomes instinctively over-the-top, but in a good-natured, more cinematic sort of craze. Not 100% my cup of tea though.What. A. Twist.The deceased chick-count has doubled. This movie isn't disinclined to kill off folks. Jeez.Hats alarm me now.Goldfinger is the undiluted definition of the exemplar "Bond Movie" (From Russia With Love is, well, quite the opposite).I thoroughly savored this Bond flick, but I can't seem to wrap my head around why most fans prefer this over From Russia With Love-which I find significantly more profound, iconic, and timely. Who knows? Maybe I'll end up preferring Goldfinger one day. Only time can tell. (Verdict: B+)
