With the release of Goldfinger in 1964, the James Bond franchise had hit its stride, and it would prove to be the entry that cemented all the elements that would forever create a "James Bond movie" into a formula that has been deviated from very little for the last four decades. Goldfinger is oft-cited as the best of the James Bond series, and while my personal taste edges just slightly more to From Russia With Love, Goldfinger comes in a very narrow second.In Goldfinger, James Bond (Sean Connery) is assigned to investigate Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe), a businessman with a distinct love for all things gold. It is suspected by the British government that Goldfinger is amassing a large supply of gold for nefarious purposes. Bond introduces himself to Goldfinger during a round of golf and then follows him to his operation in Switzerland. Eventually captured by Goldfinger's imposing henchman, Oddjob (Harold Sakata), Bond meets Goldfinger's personal pilot, Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman) who appears susceptible to his charms and he eventually discovers that Goldfinger has a significant heist planned.Goldfinger utilizes almost every element that would become a staple of the James Bond series. It features a snappy, action-packed pre-title teaser sequence that is only peripherally attached to the film's main plot; the main title sequence is a marvelously designed showpiece, featuring a song belted out by Shirley Bassey; it features the most memorable of henchmen, the mute Oddjob, whose principal weapon is his steel rimmed top hat that he can sail through the air like a Frisbee; a memorable female lead in Honor Blackman, and finally, a strong villain with Gert Frobe. After two films that were used to help the producers find their way, in Goldfinger they polished the series to its future shine.Goldfinger was also the film that brought gadgetry to the forefront in Bond films. Goldfinger featured what would become James Bond's signature piece of equipment: his tricked-out Aston Martin DB5, complete with bullet-proof shield, oil slick, smoke screen, machine guns, and don't forget the ejector seat. There are few who have discovered the Bond series as kids and have not been wowed by the super cars that Bond would drive in, and this is the first, and arguably the best. The film gets lots of neat set-pieces out of the car, including a high speed chase through a factory yard and surrounding woods, and gadgetry would almost become a character in Bond films, largely thanks to this movie.Connery has perfected his Bond performance here, with lots of double entendres and one liners to keep him slightly above the fray, while still not detaching from it. Bond is a character that is always able to find a sarcastic comment to make about the goings on around him, but never seem removed from the story. Goldfinger gave the Bond series what is still one of its standout female characters with Pussy Galore. As portrayed by Honor Blackman, she is striking but full of energy and verve, not some featherweight who is just along for the ride (as many Bond girls would prove to be). Gert Frobe is also one of Bond's best villains and Frobe delivers a terrific performance, despite not speaking English (his dialogue was dubbed).With Goldfinger, every element for a successful Bond film was put into place and the winning combination would rocket the series into a successful stratosphere that it would never come back from. It is not unreasonable to say that most of the long term success of Bond can be laid at the feet of Goldfinger.

Review title: Not As Good As From Russia With Love But This IS Bond.
Review_body: First in the series coming out in 1962 was "Dr. No" which was Bond but different It had a weird starting and without the barrel scene it had something missing that I think all Bonds should have. "From Russia With Love" I believe is Bond at his best. It shows all the sides of Bond from the wit and charm of the womanizer to the coldness he has to have in his job. In this third film "Goldfinge" we see more of Bond's character unfolding, and together with the bad guy and some of the funnier puns Bond has made in his movie this is certainly one of the Connery ones to remember.Anyway the reason I think this film is not as good as FRWL is that every now and then the plot can get a little bit dozy and while even the boring bits were bits you could watch I think for sheer enjoyment "From Russia With Love" is classic Bond.Anyway, this is what Bond is all about, and who could forget the classic name Pussy Galore, it is a name that showed how James Bond could be funny at the same time, and it is hard to believe how in 1964 they could get away with that, but if they had n't they would have lost a huge bit of cinematic history.Overall, Goldfinger is a good inclusion to the Connery Bonds and is my second favourite of his films. I rate this one 73%.

Goldfinger is one of Bond's greatest successes - and it is easy to see why.Sean Connery is widely acclaimed as the greatest cinema Bond - he was pretty darn good in this film. The monumental image of the woman painted in gold is one that will never be forgotten in cinema, and is this film's finest moment. Full of intelligence and wit throughout, including the scene when Bond foils Auric Goldfinger's cheating at golf, this is a real classic of a film. And it isn't done too badly either - you can't really poke fun at any of the special effects or action scenes.This film is full of great villains - Auric Goldfinger is a truly menacing billionaire of a villain, and the tough, cruel and menacing Oddjob is another memorable nemesis of Bond who is fallen in a great scene by the super-spy. Goldfinger delivered his greatest line when he was about to cut Bond in half with the laser - "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die." That scene still is dripping with tension and fear over 40 years on.This film had far more appeal than Moonraker - partly because it was older and did far more with a lesser-astronomical budget, but mostly because it is more unforgettable and monumental than the 1979 outing. Full of brilliant villains, cunning plans and classic spying gadgets and action, Goldfinger is nothing short of a classic Bond film. 10/10

The third installment of Bond was again quite close to the book, and more of a pure spy story than the action flicks the series later became. Made in the 'good old days', when they could film a Bond movie each year and have a hit every time! It is also the container for the most provocatively named of all 'Bond girls', Pussy Galore. Fleming dreamed up a few of these not so sly double entendres, but this one was REALLY out there. LOL This movie was the first Bond film to change locales around the world several times, moving from Miami to England to Europe and then to Kentucky.The manner of death of some of the villains is a bit altered from the book, but for a film adaptation of a novel Goldfinger stays very true to the original story.Sadly, the battle between Goldfinger's forces and the troops stationed at Fort Knox presage a sad development in Bond climaxes as the series progressed.Very enjoyable, Bond is still more of a spy than a commando, sit back and appreciate it.

Review title: SO FAR THE BEST JAMES BOND MOVIE EVER MADE
Review_body: Sean Connery was at his absolute best in "Goldfinger",which for me is the best James Bond made so far.It's an evergreen classic and superlative in every department of filmmaking.

Review title: Now I remember why I used to like Bond movies so much
Review_body: When I was a kid I used to like James Bond movies very much, but after few years I lost my interest in Bond, probably because the latest Bond movies were kinda dull. Not so long ago I've watched Quantum of Solace and I liked it but only for action, everything else was boring. Just yesterday I've watched Lived and Let Die and I liked it so much that I decided to watch all other Bond movies and so today I've watched Goldfinger and now I remember why I was so crazy about this film series. OK, maybe special effects aren't that good as in nowadays movies, but still action is very entertaining. Also there are many colorful characters, original ways to die, good girls, bad girls, some of the craziest plans of taking over the world and many other things that made this film series so entertaining. You just watch it and see it for yourself.

This movie comes so close to being the perfect James Bond movie yet in the end it fails to deliver. Yes, it has the great theme song, all the gadgets and girls (if you're a bad actress you get killed fast!) plus a memorable villain and evil sidekick but the gassing of the US Military in the end is almost comical as the flying beauties in their airplanes release sleeping gas. Some actors fall down before the plane even approaches them, and then it turns out everyone was acting?? All the overturned trucks scattered around and all the military personnel are just faking it? I can't buy it. Yes, this scene is in the book but it's just asking me to suspend disbelief for too long. Don't get me wrong, this is probably one of my favorite Bond flicks, there's a lot to like here. However, close but no cigar.

After FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE, this one combines all the best aspects of the Bond films (only the Sean Connery ones), since the rest really didn't matter much.  I wish Shirley Eaton (gold paint girl) had more dialogue since she was an accomplished English actress for many years.  Gert Frobe, a respected German actor is completely believable as is Harold Sakata as Odd-Job. 
There are many beautiful Bond babes in this one, including the highly respected Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore.  Great climax at Fort Knox, cool Aston Martin car scenes, great theme music and overall music, and Mr. Connery still has his sense of humor.  This probably made more money that the other ones which is fine by me.  There's really no "Good" Bond girl in this plot.  Pretty much (post-Shirley Eaton) all the women are out to get him in theory.  Very well done!

I saw "Goldfinger" recently, on a new digital print, as part of the 2007 Summer Of British Films festival.So, "Goldfinger" in 2007...? Hmm... That is a difficult one because, well, "Goldfinger" has dated. (Hell, it was made in 1964. Everything made in 1964 has dated.) But, saying that, if you can get beyond the terrible quips (Bond electrocutes a baddie, puts his jacket on and, practically winking at the camera, says "Shocking"), and lazy plotting (why doesn't Goldfinger just take the mobster who decides not to join in with his plans outside and shoot him, rather than go through the whole rigmarole of getting him to drive away so that Oddjob can kill him and crush his car?) and displays of the power of rampant machoness (Bond turns the mercenary Pussy Galore - by the way, the greatest Bond girl name of all time! - to his side, just by nobbing her in the barn), it is still a great and very enjoyable movie."Goldfinger" is still incredibly funny, has brilliantly choreographed action scenes, looks brilliant in the new digital transfer and, of course, Connery is still effortlessly cool. No wonder that people still consider him to be the definitive movie Bond. He has utter sexuality and magnetism.It's not the best Bond film (Hi there "On Her Majesty's Secret Service"!), but it is a good movie.

Goldfinger is absolutely the best James Bond-movie ever and I think it will stay that way. Sean Connery is the one and only James Bond and he shows that in Goldfinger. The jokes are funnier than ever and Gert Frobe is the coolest bad guy of all the villains in JB-movies. And what about Oddjob, Goldfinger helping hand, or is it hat? The Bond girl has of course a crazy name, Pussy Galore (!).You don't get better entertainment than this, a definite must see!!

Quintessential James Bond movie that both made and, in some ways, denigrated the series.  It's a good movie -- simple-minded, with some absurd ideas and crude effects, but it's wrong to judge the past by post-modern standards. James Bond had been a blip on movie-goer's radar screens for a few years, but "Goldfinger" was the turning point.  Everything comes together and it works better than one of Q's gadgets.  It plays up one of the big themes in Fleming's books -- Bond's ineptitude and survival more by luck than brains -- but also started the downward spiral away from the books and into fx-laden comic book silliness.  The plot is still within bounds of the plausible, and it serves as a well-oiled machine for Connery's Bond, who is not yet Roger Moore's superman.The most intriguing aspect is Goldfinger himself.  Masterfully limned by Gert Frobe, Goldfinger is set up as Bond's enemy from the beginning, and the thread of their rivalry continues through all the episodes.  Goldfinger comes closest to getting rid of Bond several times, with as little talk as possible;  and he has a better reason than future villains had for keeping him alive when Bond is at his mercy.  He is a powerful presence and very real threat from the first post-credit episode.Whether one agrees that the other elements are the best of Bond, it's nearly unanimous Harold Sakata is the best henchman.  From his steel hat down he's the coolest, and became a more potent symbol of the Bond franchise than Connery.But the franchise was damned by "Goldfinger"'s success, and condemned, like Sysyphus, to keep rolling the same stone up the hill, but each time the hill had to be higher.Fortunately wiser heads prevailed when Connery was succeeded by both Roger Moore and then Timothy Dalton.  In each case, the movies went back to basics -- not necessarily following strict storylines from Fleming's work, but making Bond less dependent on tricks and mirrors and gadgets, and making the villains less megalomaniacal.  With Moore, after a good start with two fine films, his movies took off into even more absurd flights of fancy than ever imagined even in the psychedelic '60s.  (Considering Bond history, it's probably a good thing Dalton's very no-nonsense, licenced-to-kill basics Bond bowed out after his first two phenomenal episodes, before he got sucked into the infernal balderdash like "Goldeneye", or worse).Is "Goldfinger" the best Bond?  That's too subjective a term. "Quintessential" is the best description.  It's not a good place to start watching Bond, either, because it compels one into the one-upsmanship of the bigger-equals-better Bonds, rather than encouraging viewings of the more sensible films in the series, such as "From Russia With Love", "Dr. No", "Live and Let Die", "For Your Eyes Only", "Living Daylights" and "Licence to Kill". But as far as the Bond films go, all its parts work equally as well, and if one could only take one Bond flick to a desert island (magically equipped with DVD) this would be it.

Review title: Mixing business and girls! Mixing thrills and girls! Mixing danger and girls!
Review_body: I made a list of things I noticed in this film: - The climbing gadget, Bond uses to climb the wall, at the beginning of the movie. Is so classic and yet so modern.Sean Connery's face expressions are always so natural, he made a really good James Bond.The part when Agent 007 defends himself with the girl, in the begging of the movie. He can bee sometimes brutal with women and sometimes really charming.He is truly resourceful, when he fights specially.In the hotel, when he breaks in Goldfinger's room, Sean Connery had great athletic legs! - Some of the special effect are real enough, even though the movie was made before man even set foot on the Moon.The grandma with the shotgun was so funny, I laughed like crazy! - The scene in the plane, when Pussy Galore went in the pilot's cabin and told James Bond to switch his charm off, because she is immune. The James turned around to the stewardess. That was pretty ironic.The judo fight between James Bond and Pussy Galore in the barn was not so well done.When the bomb stopped at 007 seconds and James starred and congratulating his C.I.A. friend."This is no time to be rescued", the final replica and when James covered him and Pussy in the parachute.
This movie is just as cheesey as you might imagine, but it's not unenjoyable! Filled with action and witty one-liners from Bond, it made for an enjoyable night.

Review title: "No, Mr. Bond. I expect you to die."
Review_body: In 1964, the formula for nearly 20 future movies was set in stone with the third James Bond film, Goldfinger, often regarded the best of the Bond films. I'm in no position to judge the merit of such a statement, but I will say it's a favorite of mine. To start off with, I'm a Sean Connery-Bond person; no warm spot in my heart for Roger Moore or Timothy Dalton, though Pierce Brosnan has added life to the franchise, as far as I'm concerned. In Goldfinger, Connery exudes everything that makes James Bond that character that we think of: suave, cool under pressure, quick on his feet, a ladies man. We see the ladies of Bond, from the first scene to the last, as Bond conquers not only evil herion dealers to a loony gold-hungry super villain who's plan is a simple one: take over Ft. Knox and crash the gold market. So the plan is silly, and the execution of the plan is just as absurd, but with most Bond movies, the plot is not what's important, it's the scenes you're expected to see. In Goldfinger, we get to see the Bond-blow something up scene, the Bond-flirt with Miss Moneypenny (Lois Maxwell) scene, the Bond-meet with Q (Desmond Llewelyn) and get vital equipment scene, we see Bond-roll in the hay with the villain's woman scene (literally in Goldfinger), and we see the return of the villain for one last hurrah scene. The formula is all there for us to see in Goldfinger, and we'll see it again in the future. The joy of Goldfinger is the villain, Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe), with his head henchman Oddjob (Harold Sakata), as they formulate a ridiculous scheme to take over Ft. Knox and blow up all of the gold inside of it. Oh yeah, there's help from the Communish Chinese too. The movie also features the dirtiest of the double entendre-named Bond girl, Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman), prompting the movie's biggest laugh when Bond realizes who he's waking up to. Goldfinger's special effects are pedestrian by today's standards, and director Guy Hamilton's use of speeding up the film distracts in some scenes, the movie still holds up as one of the ultimate Bond movies.

I've never seen any of the Connery or Moore Bond films so I was excited to start here. The movie wasn't bad but it was just slow in some parts. Some of the scenes just went on longer than they should.Also a few of the scenes were a little cheesy. Maybe that's how they were back then? The shootouts were so poorly directed. Guys just running into a line of fire just to slowly fall over.I do love Connery's portrayal of 007 though! Most people say he's the best and after this movie I may have to agree.Not a bad flick. Just a little long and cheesy in parts.

Review title: Goldfinger is the 'Gold' Standard for All Bond Films!
Review_body: In Agent 007's third outing on screen, the outrageously entertaining Goldfinger, a vacationing James Bond is informed that his trip to Miami Beach has an ulterior purpose: monitoring the movements of Auric Goldfinger (Gert Fröbe), an international gold merchant who the British government suspects is plotting something vaguely fiendish. Bond quickly gets on Goldfinger's wrong side by ruining his card game and libidinously charming away his female companion, Jill. Those two brash moves don't sit particularly well with Goldfinger and his rottenness becomes immediately apparent as he memorably deals with both offenders. Now with a personal stake in stopping Goldfinger, Bond sets off to stop the glutton-for-gold before he can unleash his sinister plan. Soon, Bond finds that Goldfinger's plot goes much deeper than simply playing havoc with Britain's economy: the rotund madman has a conniving scheme code- named 'Operation Grand Slam' that involves bringing all the economies of the West to ruin by irradiating the gold at Fort Knox and thereby turning the gold basis of the United States' economy into shiny irradiated paperweights – sending the value of his stockpile of bullion through the roof. Bond tries to neutralize the situation, but it's not going to be easy with the hired muscle around Goldfinger - the likes of the oriental assassin Oddjob and Pussy Galore (the first Bond girl with an innuendo-laden name) in his way. The thrill of a James Bond movie, is watching James Bond be his upper crust, chauvinistic, cocky, shaken not stirred self. And in Goldfinger, Bond is at his smug best thanks to Sean Connery's relaxed swagger. Unlike the latter day dashing villains, Fröbe plays Goldfinger as anything but, being slightly uncomfortable and seemingly always uneasy - the exact opposite of Bond. At first glance, Goldfinger seems like a small-potatoes schmuck for the likes of Bond, cheating poolside at gin in Miami with his escort's help. But her death at Goldfinger's orders provides an unforgettably vivid Bond image — her limp body 'suffocated' by a coat of gold paint — and establishes Goldfinger as a psychopath to be reckoned with. That ruthless homicidal rage goes a long way toward selling a physically unimposing gasbag as a formidable cretin, making for a memorable Bond villain. Director Guy Hamilton directs the film with flair and packs the film full of fantastic touches such as the souped-up Aston Martin replete with machine guns, a tire shredder, navigational radar, a smoke-screen device and a passenger-ejector seat. Then there's Shirley Bassey's classic Bond theme, the sinfully seductive '60s jazz that reeks of sex and violence in one protracted explosion of ear-splitting ecstasy. It is perfection and nothing less.Twenty three outings later, Goldfinger still remains definitive James Bond movie - a phenomenon that kicked the franchise into overdrive and really made Bond an icon. Did someone say Diamonds? Forever? Nah, that's Gold!

Review title: Without Doubt, the Quintessential, Definitive Bond Movie
Review_body: This is the definitive James Bond flick. It established the Bond formula and set the standard for all Bond films to come.Sean Connery is once again flawless as James Bond. He is charming, charismatic, and has all the ladies after him. Pussy Galore, played by Honor Blackman, is one of the most famous Bond girls and one of the toughest (although her name is admittedly questionable). The Masterson sisters are in the film only briefly, with Jill, of course, being painted with gold in a classic image.Auric Goldfinger is one of the best Bond villains ever, and is played with panache by Gert Frobe. The scenes between him and Bond are filled with genuine tension. His henchmen, Oddjob, is also one of the best villains of the series. Along with Jaws, he is the most invincible of the Bond henchmen.The plot, while not as gritty or serious as "From Russia With Love," is very engaging with Goldfinger's classic plan to raid Fort Knox. The production set is delightful, taking place in places such as Miami and Kentucky.From the opening scene to the chase scene with the Aston Martin (Bond's best vehicle ever!) to the battle at Fort Knox to the climax in the plane, the action scenes will have you on the edge of your seat.The script is witty and the film moves at a brisk pace. There are too many classic scenes to name, and the title song by Shirley Bassey is one of the best.This is unquestionably the most iconic Bond movie, and for my money, it was also the all-around best Bond movie until "Skyfall" came out. A true classic.RATING: A+

Review title: Goldfinger- the greatest bond outing ever
Review_body: I consider Goldfinger to be the best Bond movie ever made, along with Live and Let die, Licence to Kill and Goldeneye. Everything is top notch, the scripting, the dialogues, the villains etc. The theme tune probably the best of them all, it was sung by Shirley Bassey who coincidentally also sang Diamonds are forever and Moonraker. Then we have two fabulous villains, Auric Goldfinger and his henchman Oddjob. Then we have in my opinion one of the coolest bond car ever, the Aston Martin This movie also contains one of my favourite Bond dialogues, in the scene where Bond is being tortured by a laser Bond: Do you expect me to talk Goldfinger: No Mr Bond I expect you to die.There are also a lot of memorable scenes, for instance in the scene where Bond finds the woman he has just spent the night with covered in gold from head to toe.Up until Goldfinger the Bond series was reasonably successful but Goldfinger took the success to a whole new level. There may be a dozen more Bond movies but there will never ever be a Goldfinger.

007's best movie outing with the best Bond, Sean Connery. This is the one where everything came together just right, the action, the humour, the gadgets, the girls, it all works brilliantly. Respect to all the other actors who have played 007 but no-one comes close to Sean Connerry's portrayal of James Bond. It also boasts a great villain in Goldfinger, a fantastic henchman in Oddjob and a gorgeous Bond girl, Pussy Galore played by Honor Blackman. Nobody does it better than Sean ***9/10***

In the year 1964, when Beatlmania was in full form (just recall the witty humor line in Goldfinger about Beatles) and China detonated its first atomic bomb, MGM released Goldfinger. Probably the best in 007 series. So what makes it so good, that no one other even came close to it?Well, actually it got all what 007 movie  should have. Suspense story (111 minutes, without dull moments), a start opening scene with witty humor ("shocking", "positive shocking") that continuous throughout the movie, great villain (Goldfinger) and almost impossible to beat henchman Oddjob (Harold Sakata), Q laboratory (not to mention Aston Martin), superb theme song and finally charming Sean Connery as its best. And as the "cream de la cream" it got something else, that no other 007 movie has?
The most beautiful girls and (hold your breath, guys) they are all blond goddesses. From the voluptuous masseuse Dink (21-year old Margaret Nolan), sensual beauty Jill Masterson (27-year old Shirley Eaton) and her sister Tilly Masterson (23-year old Tania Mallet) to, for many fans the best Bond woman ever, Pussy Galore (37-year old Honor Blackman). Despite her age, she got huge sex appeal and she wasn't immune to Bond charm (well, at least not till unforgettable "barn scene"), what made her even more sexy.
Sure, you could argue about some holes in the scripts, such as Goldfinger presentation and the attack with nerve gas. Or you could mention the heavy use of rear projections (used to cut the expenses from shooting abroad). But, on the other hand, everything is soon forgotten when you watch one of the most charming movies in history of cinema. A classic.10 out of 10

Review title: The birth of the modern blockbuster
Review_body: Bond has now wet his teeth with a couple of missions with Sean Connery on fine form as the world's favourite secret agent, he is finding his range within the role and in this, still the greatest bond film in the series, no offence Daniel, he finds his feet superbly, even though he is knocked off them more then once during the film's duration.Auric Goldfinger is a good excursion from the usual SPECTRE villains we have seen in the previous two films, Goldfinger is a bit of a cad, cheats at cards, hires pretty women to be seen with him and is merely a scoundrel. Isn't he? Well no, he's a cold blooded killer who would be his henchman's hand, or his own, dispose of his enemies, coolly and cynically if they get in his way at all. He is not one of those villains who thinks about keeping hold of an adversary as a bargaining chip, Au contraire, he will just kill them. This is what makes Mister Goldfinger such a dangerous villain, with his henchmen Oddjob, he is more than a match for any man.Bond is sent to find out what Goldfinger is up to, a routine mission to explore Gold Smuggling, but the mission turns out to be anything bu that as Bond gets into further scrapes and situations that constantly thrill and entertain as he travels from Miami to England to Switzerland back to the US. This film is the birth of the modern blockbuster for many reasons, it's exciting opening as he concludes his last mission, the great title sequence by Maurice Binder, which so many other films try to catch the eye with, the script is tight, always moving forward either with a cool piece of dialogue or a great action moment, or another confrontation between Bond and Goldfinger or one of his many assistants.Connery is magnificent in this film and from the moment he starts his mission in South America to the final end, with a performance of panache, style and swagger that few would ever get close to matching, the direction by Guy Hamilton is as taught as any in the modern era and the soundtrack is perfect,enhancing every moment at a time when John Barry was heading towards his peak work, with this being a major step.Add Q's monologue for good measure as he bores Bond to death whilst introducing the world's most beautiful car and you really have it all. Yes some sequences have dated a little (Modern audiences would not stand for the ticking clock stuff) but this is great family fare that will certainly continued to be loved by many for years and years to come Nuff said (Check out my other reviews) Em

I had a lot of problems with this movie. Let me list them: 1) The number two person in the conspiracy to nuke Fort Knox changes sides and betrays her comrades...because Bond slept with her? Gimme a break. Judging from her personality, she'd be about the last person in the world I'd expect to do such a thing. It's obvious that the writers couldn't think of any way of getting out of the corner they'd written themselves into, so they tossed in a deus ex machina cop-out ending.2) Bond just doesn't do much of anything in this movie. He spends the last half of the movie sitting in a cell while other characters run around and do things that don't advance the plot one bit. It's boring. I appreciate the fact that he uses his brains to get out of trouble, but he never really "gets out" of trouble, he just turns a bad situation into a slightly less bad one. This is about the only Bond movie where he's so ineffectual, and it makes for a very unentertaining film.3) Bond allows himself to be captured by the bad guys so that he can go and check on the condition of a woman who got hit with a flying hat? He barely knew her! He gave her a ride to a gas station; that's it. It makes no sense that he'd jeopardize his mission in order to check on the condition of a stranger. What was he going to do, give her CPR? He certainly didn't want to be captured as part of any sort of plan, as he spent the next ten minutes of the movie trying to get away again.4) Why didn't Goldfinger just kill Bond? He hit the nail right on the head when he said that Bond only knew the name of the operation (blockbuster), but he didn't know any of the details. Then Bond tells him that if he is killed, they'll send another agent. Well, obviously. Goldfinger certainly must have assumed as much. But how would anyone even know if Bond was killed? It was just another poorly thought out scene.5) Pussy Galore is a really unlikable character. Not only is she just plain homely, but she brags and brags and brags about herself.6) The ending on the plane felt very tacked on and silly. Are we to believe that a woman and a fat guy overpowered all the soldiers in a military aircraft hanger and stole a plane right out from under their noses?Oh, there are a few good things about the movie. The Swiss Alps are beautiful, even in Summer. The car is really cool. And of course the theme song is fantastic.Overall, this is easily the worst Connery Bond film. Much worse than any Roger Moore or Timothy Dalton or George Lazenby Bond movie. I can't for the life of me understand why people hold it in such high esteem, the writing is just so ridiculously sloppy. I enjoy most of Connery's other Bond films, but this thing sticks out like a big, stinky sore thumb.

Bond Review. Title: Another title named after the main villain and it does have a sophisticated ring to it.Pre-Titles: An action-packed opening sees Bond blow up a drug laboratory, trying to seduce a dancer and dispatching a henchman via electrocution in a bath. This is the perfect pre-title sequence filled with energy and bringing you straight into the action, ending with Bond brilliantly delivering the classic line, ''Shocking.positively shocking.''Theme Song: Shirley Bassey's 'Goldfinger' has become iconic and one of the most popular songs in the series. It has excellent instrumental work, a certain mysterious quality and Bassey sings it with a burning passion.Plot: Bond begins to investigate gold magnate Auric Goldfinger who is accused of stockpiling gold bullion. He soon discovers Goldfinger's plan named Operation Grandslam, which involves contaminating Fort Knox's gold supply and disrupting the world economy. The story is the ideal mix of the far-fetched and espionage. The main plot sounds quite daft, but it is played out with a realistic tone and kept straightforward so that it never gets too extravagant. The pacing is superb once again, the story moves along at a great speed and it smartly only slows down during the most important scenes.James Bond: Sean Connery is at his most content in the role and it is clear that he is enjoying himself throughout. He tones down the rough edges of Bond and really plays up the smooth charm of the character, which sounds like a retreat but it works perfectly for this film. Connery's charisma is at an all-time high and he makes an engaging screen presence.Bond Girls: Honor Blackman, mostly known for her work on The Avengers, is top notch as the famously title Pussy Galore. She flawlessly plays Galore as no-nonsense and initially cynical, but she has believable chemistry with Connery and they share some really good scenes. Shirley Eaton is very good in her small role as the charming Jill Masterson, the image of her painted in gold is one of the films many memorable moments.Villains: Gert Frobe is truly wonderful as Goldfinger. He has a commanding, almost larger than life presence and gets the message across with his facial expressions alone. Frobe makes Goldfinger someone we want to find out more about and he consistently delivers great line after great line. Harold Sakata set the bar for hulking henchmen as the silent Oddjob. He uses his movements and expressions to his best ability giving his mute character, he is a real physical presence and an intimidating figure.Support: Cec Linder is one of the weaker points as Leiter given Jack Lord's great performance prior, he just looks too old to be convincing and comes off more like Bond's goofy uncle than a CIA spy. Tania Mallet is fairly decent as Tilly Masterson and is convincing as someone who wants revenge.Action: The action scenes move seamlessly from small and gritty to big set-pieces. The Pre-titles and Bond's infiltration of Goldfinger's headquarters are really exciting sequences that are heavy on intensity. Bond's confrontation with Oddjob is excellent as well as suitably brutal and the demise of Goldfinger, though dated and daft, is good fun.Score: John Barry delivers one of his best scores here. The music is memorable throughout and adds a striking quality to many already important scenes. He balances everything out beautifully once again, the creeping intense sounds for the low-key scenes and big bombastic numbers for the action.Production Values: Production wise this is a change from Young's grounded approach into something much more slick and stylish that would remain in future instalments. Hamilton clearly has a good eye for shots and he knows how to approach scenes to make them memorable. We get so many iconic moments and pieces here, Masterson covered in gold paint, Goldfinger's laser ready to cut Bond in half, Oddjob's razor hat and the Aston Martin DB5. Not to mention great lines like ''No Mr. Bond, I expect you to die.'' Goldfinger is a film that is packed full of unforgettable imagery and that helps it live long in the memory. The locations are all excellent as usual and setting most of it in the United States gives it a unique edge, whilst Ken Adam is back to design more stunning sets. We also get the first signs of Q branch and the addition of more crazy but cool gadgets, which are surprisingly well-thought out here. Conclusion: For many Goldfinger is the quintessential Bond flick and it is very easy to see why. This is Bond at its most entertaining and it goes all out to thrill the audience in every single aspect. It abandons the low-key approach of the previous films, but it doesn't get too unbelievable and keeps you gripped at all times. The plot is enjoyable and keeps you interested, whilst the acting is very good from almost everyone involved. It also set up many aspects that would be poorly copied later on such as big villains, emphasising gadgets and a slightly more humorous tone, but all of these are at their best here. Memorable is the work that sums up Goldfinger the best and it is the best Bond film purely from an entertainment sense.

What I like1. The dead girl painted in gold2. Connery as Bond is as good as ever3. The plot is more fleshed out than Dr No and From Russia With Love4. The characters are more enjoyable5. The fact it started "Goldpingas"6. The final battle7. The mystery feel to itWhat I didn't like1. Nothing reallyOverall this is one of the best Bond movies and probably Connery's best effort out of the bunch. I feel like this movie deserves the praise that it gets at the end of the day

Goldfinger is the best Bond movie:  best villain, henchman, sexually-suggestive-nicknamed villainess converted to angel choirs, and most of all, best film symbol, the golden girl, Jill Masterson (played by Shirley Eaton).  I am happy the best villain is outside Spectre, the same old thing. Goldfinger is his own man, completely in command.  My favorites:  Oddjob and the golf ball, and everyone's -- the laser beam and one-liner.  Bond peaked with this movie, and altho Thunderball was good enough to somewhat sustain the Bond phenomenon, it was slightly second best, and the staleness began.  Sean Connery's personal feelings and situation reflected this, and his holdout coincided with the downhill turn.  Don't get me wrong--Roger Moore, though no Connery, added his personal lighter, humorous touch, and provided a needed change.  But after Thunderball, and to some extent Goldfinger, things somewhat faded and became tiresome.  The point is not of that much relevance to those seeing Bonds for the first time today.  But what I am saying is, when Goldfinger, the third and best Bond, came out, it was still fresh, and that was a good combination.

Review title: One of the best Bond films ever!
Review_body: With nearly 20 Bond films in 40 years, it's easy to choose a certain prototype of a perfect James Bond movie - "Goldfinger". Anything you imagine from a classic Bond film can be found here - a hard and smooth hero (Sean Connery), lush decorations, fancy clothes, well-looking sixties-girls, a perfect (German) villain (Gert Froebe), a menacing, ugly henchman (Oddjob), a men-killing leather gal (Honor Blackman), some nice places all over the world (the bays of Miami, Fort Knox, English golf sites and the impressing mountains of Switzerland), weird gadgets (Bond's stylish special agent Aston Martin), a brilliant title theme (Shirley Bassey's "Goldfinger" - also a prototype of typical sixties' secret agent/spy/crime music), one of John barry's finest scores, nice photography and a good pacing and many action sequences. There's always much fun and style and thrill around, and "Goldfinger" is simply an all-time fav cool movie! Sit back and enjoy - shaken, not stirred!

Review title: James Bond (Sean Connery) meets billionaire gold smuggler, Auric Goldfinger
Review_body: Although it comes as number three in chronology of the James Bond franchise, Goldfinger (1964) is the most perfectly realized compendium of gadgetry stunts and Bondian sensibilities. From its various inventive modes of untimely demise (Oddjob's decapitating bowler; the compression of an unwilling participant in a junk yard compactor; the first on screen usage of a laser beam), and its audacious Bond girls to the film's most celebrated sleek and silver Astin Martin (with its oil slicks, bulletproof shell, machine gun-totting headlamps and ejector seat courtesy of Q branch), Goldfinger delivers the cinematic goods in every way that a Bond film should. Both Guy Hamilton's slick direction and Ken Adam's marvelous sets provide the utmost visual impact for the story. On all accounts then, Goldfinger is a 24kt hit.Unfortunately, the same can't be said for MGM/UA's DVD. Visually, the film elements vary greatly in quality. Matte shots are not natural looking at all. There is some horrible color balancing during the Miami sequence. Age related artifacts abound throughout. Digital anomalies crop up throughout the transfer, but on the whole are not obtrusive. Extras include two probing documentaries about the film's success, as well as an audio commentary and a host of promotional junkets that are sure to thrill.

What can be said that has not already been said? Very little.So there's no point in repeated analysis of the plot, characters, action, music, set pieces, etc. It's been done.On a personal level, I don't rate it above Dr No, From Russia With Love or Thunderball these days. However, this might have a lot to do with over-familiarity. As a kid I overdosed massively on this movie. For years, I thought it the best thing I had ever seen. Whenever it played in the local cinema or was screened on TV, I was there. I bought the VHS release and played it until it wore out. I had a LaserDisc version that stayed in the big 12 inch drive almost constantly. By the time of the DVD version I was saturated and then saturated some more. And now, still it remains one of the greatest films ever made – even if the gold doesn't shine quite as radiantly for me as it used to. It's a small thing, an infinitesimal depreciation, and matters very little, because I still love it to death.What you've got here is the fully-formed template for the Bond movies. This is the one that is so entrenched in the public consciousness, that so encapsulated sixties popular movie culture, that so engraved itself into the history of cinema, it is simply the Bond film equivalent of The Beatles. Certain phenomena in the arts transcend critique, because no matter what critique is levelled, it has no meaningful impact, slides off the surface and dissolves into the immaterial dust of the utterly inconsequential. Goldfinger is the epitome of the unassailable monument, the unimpeachable icon, the impregnable example of just how rare, wondrous and downright dashed bloody-well good Bond movies – and movies in general – can be.If you really love and are excited by the unadulterated spine-tingling serotonin glory of movies as pure escapist entertainment, there is no more apt, fitting and deserving object of desire upon which to lavish that love.That said, though, I still prefer Thunderball. But what the hell?

This is the movie that set the tone for nearly every Bond movie that has followed. Goldfinger must have been quite a movie at the drive-ins with it debuted; lots of action, a fancy car, and a naked girl covered in gold paint.Goldfinger has one of the best villains, the best henchman, and some of the greatest lines from then whole series.There isn't much to add about Goldfiner other than it doesn't hold the same level of entertainment level on repeated viewings as some of the other chapters of Bond, but nevertheless it is easily in my top 2 or 3 of Bond movies.

The previous film was an improvment over Dr. No, but Goldfinger takes it to an whole other level.Like the last movie, it jumps straight into the action, and the sense of adventure and fun is ever present - Sean Connery is absolutely phenomenal as his dashing and smooth-talking action hero, with this movie, he has reached his uttermost potential.We are introduced to a new villain, called Goldfinger. Unlike Dr. No or Colonel Klebbs, he does not work for SPECTRE, and he is not that much of a badass, but rather a coward, a big manchild who hates to loose and lets others do the work for him. But that does not get in the way of his ruthlesness - and there are some truly shocking scenes in this movie attesting to his evilness.Aside him is his henchman, Oddjob - a ruthless and mute Korean who becomes one of the most memorable Bond characters of all time, standing as the silent tough-guy in this story.Without going too much into spoilers, this is truly Bond perfected. The action-scenes are amazing, and the Oscar Win for its Sound Effects is undoubtly justified. The acting is fantastic, notably from Connery, as always, and Gert Fröbe - they help give us some of the most memorable characters seen in an adventure movie, and delivers some fantastic quotes.If From Russia With Love was The Empire Strikes Back of the Bond-franchise, this is what it would have been if Return of the Jedi (which was still a fantastic movie in its own right) was even better.There are many great Bond-movies, but I doubt any would stand against this masterpiece, which is both one of the best action-movies and best movies of all time!

The third Bond flick is the greatest -it also keeps for me the first place in the TOP three Bond movies with Connery, afterward come "Thunderball" and "You only live twice"."Goldfinger" is between the more realistic Bond thrillers and the more gadgeted era of 007 (the Aston Martin is actually the first gadget of cinematic Bond).Sean Connery's character is lighter, wittier and glamorous than before -he'll keep the same magical chemistry in "Thunderball", a year later. Here he fights against Auric Golfinger (Gert Froebe), a megalomaniac who wants to robber... Fort Knox! Bond girls are among the best in the series. Honor Blackman -star of the TV series "The Avengers" before Diana Rigg (later another Bond girl!)- is lesbian pilot Pussy Galore. Bond makes her change her mind about sexual taste...Shirley Eaton is the girl painted of gold -one of the most famous images of movie history."Goldfinger" is the blueprint of all the Bond adventures, for the first time we have all the ingredients which form the classic Bond icon (tuxedo, irony, women, sexual but extremely refined innuendos, gadgets, special effects, huge sets).In the following years these elements will be present as well, but from "Thunderball" on gadgets, stunts and action take a bigger place in the plot, whereas in "Goldfinger" acting and comedy are more important than the rest.The jewel of Bond series and one of the British TOP movies of all time.

Is or is not "Goldfinger" the best Bond movie? Hard to say. It's quite different than the previous two Bonds, "Dr. No" and "From Russia with Love". "Goldfinger" is more comical and entertaining. It has one of the best villains in the series (Gert Fröbe's portrait of Auric Goldfinger is simply fantastic), collection of gorgeous women (Shirley Eaton as Jill Masterson, Tania Mallet as Tilly Masterson, and Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore), and the Aston Martin with its special equipments. But where are exotic locations, an ingredient of the Bond formula? Otherwise, "Goldfinger" represents almost perfect entertainment with many classic scenes, for example the one involving Goldfinger, Bond and a laser.

"Goldfinger" is the perfect Bond movie.  All of the things that Bond movies are famous for were perfected in this movie.  The memorable theme song, the beginning sequence that has nothing to do with the rest of the movie, the Bond villain (Gert Frobe, possibly the best of the Bond villains), the cruel henchman (Oddjob), the gadgets (the tricked out Aston Martin) and the clever Bond witticisms; this is what Bond films are known for.  The movie closely follows the Ian Fleming book but leaves out the more controversial elements: Fleming has Goldfinger give a speech on how the Koreans are a very vicious people (embarrassing as it is to read imagine how it would play in the movie), also Tilly is in the book a lot longer than the movie.  In the book, she constantly rebuffs Bond's advances and when she meets Pussy Galore and her all-girl air force we find out why (thankfully the movie never even hints about that).  So even if there are problems with some aspects of the story (as Roger Ebert has said, why does Goldfinger tell all of the gangsters of his plan and ask them to join him if he is going to kill them anyway?), the movie is such fun that it doesn't really matter.

Review title: The Best Entry For Many Decades to Come
Review_body: 'Goldfinger' starts with a bang, an earth shattering and deafening bang. This Bond outing means business. Gone is any sense of calm, down to earth villains and the plot slowly inching forward. Here we have gadgets galore, double entendres and sophistication marked with a stylish tuxedo.007 is given the task of looking into Auric Goldfinger's dealings and affairs. Goldfinger is smuggling his gold from country to country and if Bond can find a connection, then his agency can come down hard on him. Goldfinger though has bigger plans. To break into the gold depository bank at Fort Knox and make the gold radioactive so that no one can access it for half a decade. The value of his gold will then increase to ten times its original value.'Goldfinger' features the first prologue scene that has nothing to do with the main plot of the film. We as an audience though are more than content. This adrenaline pumping action scene pushes the film forward and ensures that we remain thrilled from beginning to end. It amounts to a minor scene; Bond planting bombs in a heroin factory, yet it is intoxicating because of how quickly it draws us into the film without the use of exposition.'Goldfinger' is notable for its gadgets. They are provided courtesy of Q and are rather fantastical and ingenious. His car alone has bullet proof windows, front mounted machine guns and an ejector seat for the uninvited passenger. Goldfinger never takes its self too seriously and that's refreshing to see.Apart from the heart pounding climax that takes place in Fort Knox, there is another sequence slightly more effective and memorable. This is because it is compromised solely of quick and witty dialogue exchanges. This is the laser beam sequence and it remains tense for several reasons. The look of terror on Bond's face, the increasingly suspenseful music by John Barry and the witticisms that come across unforced and with the right amount of power.I'm not sure how the film makers got away with giving the leading lady the name of Pussy Galore. But it allows for unstoppable laughs whenever Bond whispers her name. She is herself an unstoppable force, determined, independent and loyal to Goldfinger. You buy her eventual love for Bond and she even warns him "You can turn off the charm, I'm immune".Sean Connery delivers his best performance in 'Goldfinger'. You can tell how he has matured and settled into the role with ease. Gert Frobe as Goldfinger is not intimidating, but great fun to watch as he laps up every second on screen.'Goldfinger' is a rare example of the perfect Bond film that holds up even for today's standards set for an action film. Stunning sets, gorgeous girls, vicious villains, sublime set pieces and memorable music. The list goes on and on. Most amazingly of all 'Goldfinger' remains entertaining from first frame to last. It is sure to leave you shaken, not stirred.

Review title: Number 3 and the best so far...
Review_body: I am watching all the bonds from the beginning.I can see why goldfinger is iconic. Odd job/Jill masterson painted gold/oddjobs hat/goldfinger himself!I enjoyed seeing q sorting out bonds technology also. There seems to be a massive improvement in plot and feel of the film since the first two. Best so far.

Warning - possible spoilers.Goldfinger is universally hailed as the best of the James Bond films, the third epic in the decades-spanning series gelling together many of the givens that help make the series as entertaining as it is as well as featuring the most memorable villain of the series.What makes Goldfinger a favorite is the mixture of a memorable villain in Gert Frobe's Auric Goldfinger, the audacity of the villain's plot (raiding Fort Knox, KY), and the ability of James Bond to pierce Goldfinger's inner circle in large part due to the arrogance and confidence of Goldfinger as well as the charm of his pilot.Honor Blackman left "The Avengers" to become the most famous Bond girl next to Ursula Andress' Honey Ryder. Her character name of Pussy Galore caused considerable tut-tutting in Britain and the US; "I must be dreaming," uttered by Bond upon meeting her is a feeling no doubt matched by many others upon hearing the name Pussy Galore. Though she is the most popular Bond girl, I'm not all that impressed with Honor Blackman or Pussy Galore; she looks too stiff to be really sexy and Blackman plays the role a bit too harshly until the end.Bond has just succeeded in exploding a terrorist's lair in Spain, as well as escape a revenge killing that leaves the would-be assassin electrocuted and a luscious go-go dancer with a severe headache. On leave in Miami, Bond is contacted by Felix Leiter (Cec Linder, the second of six actors to portray James' close CIA compatriot; the different actors used reflected disagreement with what to do with Leiter, who shifted from the Bond-esquire charmer of Dr. No to the bureaucrat of Goldfinger and Diamonds Are Forever to the tough and charming tropical lurker of Thunderball - Rik Van Nutter is my personal favorite of the five actors to portray Leiter - to David Hedison's engaging mixture in Live and Let Die and License To Kill), who tells James that he is to tail British industrialist Auric Goldfinger.James first meets Goldfinger when he is cheating at cards, and James pulls a brilliant double-cross - one that gets him in trouble and leaves a young woman dead. Sir Miles Meservy is very displeased - "You haven't exactly covered yourself with glory, have you?" he snaps at a clearly shaken Bond as he ponders demoting the troublesome Secret Serviceman. Sir Miles, however, knows James' real strengths, and at a dinner meeting with the head of the Bank Of England, James learns just why Auric Goldfinger is considered a security issue to the UK.James then meets Goldfinger again, and this next encounter leaves Goldfinger in the hole yet again - all allowing James to surreptitiously tail the industrialist to his corporation's branch in Switzerland, where he starts piecing together clues to Goldfinger's plans.Someone else, however, has a lethal score to settle with Goldfinger, and when the ensuing car pursuit comes to a crashing end Goldfinger's pursuer is left dead, numerous Goldfinger henchman are killed, and James is unconscious, his reputation as a ladies' man in the cross-hairs of a well-aimed laser beam. This is by far the most suspenseful single scene in the entire Bond epic; killing Bond is easy, but "Can you afford to take that chance?" amid the pulse of John Barry's most heart-pounding suspense music cue.The full extent of Goldfinger's scheme then becomes clear in a meeting with branches of American organized crime, who have helped Goldfinger smuggle in the necessary tools to pull off the ultimate bank heist. It is a project toward which Goldfinger has invested his energies since 1949 and in which he intends to leave James Bond holding the bag.The only weakness to the film is that James succeeds only because of the sheer arrogance of Goldfinger; it never occurs to Goldfinger that killing Bond will eliminate the real threat to his plan; that keeping Bond alive will convince the authorities to back off requires more than the usual suspension of disbelief to really work. The other aspect of the film that I didn't like is that Bond plays virtually no role in the actual denouement of the scheme. The first two Bond films had him doing just about everything, and one can understand wanting to tone down his one-man heroics, but here they go too far; they don't strike the right balance until Thunderball.Goldfinger also continues the practice first used in From Russia With Love - the false ending, one of the most overused and annoying dramatic devices ever. True, it works both in FRWL (the hotel fight scene) and here (the Learjet fight scene), but the device itself is grossly flawed, double-crossing the viewer needlessly. It nonetheless adds greatly to one of the best scenes in the film - Goldfinger's surprise switch when his plan suddenly goes up in a hail of gunfire.

I always have and always will love the Bond films, I grew up with them, before I got into any other films, I was crazy about the Bond movies. The first one I watched was MOONRAKER(1979)and I was so completely blown away by it that I just had to see all the others, I couldn't get enough of them,Lately,I began rewatching them again to relive my fond childhood memories and I still got that same adrenaline rush that I had all those years ago. The first film I watched was GOLDFINGER, probably the most iconic and best remembered Bond film, the story goes like this, Agent James Bond(SEAN CONNERY)tracks international billionaire Auric Goldfinger(GERT FROBE)suspected of smuggling large amounts of Gold across the world,however,Bond discovers something more serious,Goldfinger is working with the Chinese who have provided him with an Atomic bomb, which he plans to detonate inside Fort Knox, one of the world's major Gold depository's, thus destroying the economy of the western world and making his own Gold shares more valuable.007 must stop him.Now without a doubt, Goldfinger is a classic, the Bond series just wouldn't be the same without it, but a major factor that has always played a big part in the Bond movies is action, every Bond film features a handful of explosive, fast paced action sequences and Goldfinger is one such example. The film begins with an explosion, followed by a bruising fistfight between Bond and an assassin, which is excellently choreographed and impressively staged. My favourite action scenes of the film are the two car chases featuring Bond's Aston Martin and it's trademark gadgets, watch as Bond races down the road whilst being shot at and chased by Goldfinger's men and check out how he disperses smoke and Oil onto the road causing their cars to crash, the part I loved the most was when one car is sent flying over a cliff and explodes into flames. It's hilarious when Bond ejects the guy several feet in the air using the Aston Martins ejector seat and I couldn't help but laugh at the old lady who fires the Machine Gun at the Aston Martin, spraying the windscreen with bullet holes and causing Bond to crash the car into a wall, another excellent stunt. Another thing that impressed me was that the car's really looked as if they were going at breakneck speeds, just watch as the Aston Martin and the other car skid round corners and charge towards the camera, it's one of the most spectacular car chases I've ever seen. The battle at Fort Knox was also fantastic and brilliantly done, although they could have had more close-ups of the action and focused on it a little more rather than splicing it in with footage of Bond trying to detach himself from the Atomic bomb, but it was awesome anyhow. The fight between Bond and Oddjob was amazing and I liked the final confrontation between Bond and Goldfinger on the plane, I was in agony laughing as Goldfinger got sucked out of the window. The action scenes were top notch and suspenseful and I nearly went flying out of my chair watching them.Other scenes I enjoyed in the film was the part were Bond uses the Aston Martins wheel spikes to slash Tilly Mastersons tyres as she overtakes him on the road, causing he to run into a ditch,you'e got to love Oddjobs hat,especially when he uses it to knock the head off the statue, but the one scene that has always fascinated me since I was a child is the scene in which the good looking American car is crushed into a tiny cube in a compactor, this wowed me as a child and I will always remember this film for that one scene. As with every Bond film, there's plenty of one liners(007 on Mr Solo being crushed in the car, "He had a pressing engagement")and we can't forget that forever mocked line("Do you expect me to talk?", "no Mr Bond I expect you to die").Another major part of every Bond film are the colourful title sequences, they're a thing of beauty and I was truly awestruck by Goldfinger's which features golden girls against a pitch black background with scenes from the film projected onto their bodies, another part of the film that impressed me.The soundtrack and Shirley Bassey's main title music are magnificent and the latter will be forever remembered when film music is mentioned.The acting and characters are also flawless but I won't go into detail, Goldfinger is a good strong, sadistic criminal mastermind and no one could have portrayed him better than Gert Frobe.My favourite character is Oddjob,he's one of the coolest Bond villains,right up there with Jaws and the others.Overall,Goldfinger is a highly enjoyable and fast paced action film. I had a great time watching it again and it still has the power to impress me,I know why people say it's one of the greatest, or the greatest Bond film, they aren't far wrong as in my opinion Goldfinger is up there with the very best, not just the very best Bond films, but the very best films ever made. An action packed, energetic thrill ride, a must see for any Bond or action fan.10/10.

Review title: The Gold Standard of all the Bonds
Review_body: What can I say that hasn't already been said? Absolutely THE best of the Bonds, bar none.Remember seeing this when I was 12 years old. I thought WOW! what a movie.Shorlty after that, the first 2 bonds were re-released_ Dr,. No and From Russia with Love.Naturally, I had to see them after Goldfinger, and these three films remain my favorites of all time.Anyway getting back to Goldfinger. Connery is in top form, there is no wasted time in the film, everything works like a well oiled machine and no matter how many times i've seen it {40 is a good estimate}it still thrills me like the first time I saw it. The Aston Martin with the ejector seat is without a doubt the most famous car in screen history. The laser beam torture sequence had me squirming in my seat, the "hoods convention" at Goldfingers ranch set just the right tone for the rest of the film, and, of course the raid on Ft. Knox- absolutely a knock out. Bond always has a great one-liner to fit any ocassion{shocking,positively shocking, thats like listening to the Beatles without earmuffs,etc} and of course the best Bond girl of them all- Pussy Galore. Goldfinger and his mute Korean henchman Oddjob are villains in the classic tradition and not the caracatures the later series entries were. There is a great Golf game, beautiful Swiss locations, and the excellent title song.Hard to believe this film was made some 42 years ago! About the only thing that dates it are some of the 60s vintage cars and some of the outfits. Bond mania caught on big time after the release of Goldfinger, and it is easy to see why.Nothing will ever top this. Like a fine wine, it only gets better with age. Can you say that about the Roger Moore or Pierce Brosnan Bonds?
