"Goldfinger" is the second James Bond film I have ever seen and the first of the Sean Connery Bond films. The first Bond film I had ever seen was the 2012 film "Skyfall". While I did not find "Skyfall" to be bad, I was not impressed by it, nor did it make me want to watch "Casino Royale" or "Quantum of Solace". However, after watching "Goldfinger", it left me wanting to watch more of the missions of Sean Connery's Bond.It is the perfect film to open someone up to the Bond franchise with the mission, the interesting antagonist, and the crazy plot of the bad guy. It is exactly what "Get Smart" and "Austin Powers" led me to see the series as.This is exactly what I thought "Skyfall" should be. Sean Connery was brilliant with his role and is a better Bond than Daniel Craig in my book. The main antagonist and his plan were interesting and did not even come close to a cliché plot like a lot of spy films do. With this film, I have decided to watch more of the missions of Sean Connery's Bond 007.

Review title: The best Bond movie of the sixties
Review_body: This was Sean Connery's best outing as Bond and still an excellent film to watch more than fifty years later.Unlike the other sixties Bonds, Goldfinger doesn't involve SPECTRE and concerns a megalomaniac gold dealer, Auric Goldfinger, who plans to destroy Fort Knox and wreck the world's economy and make the value of his gold soar in value, with some help from Red China.There's not a dull moment in the whole film, from the start where Bond destroys a heroin factory in Mexico, to the end where he has to kill Goldfinger on a plane. Excellent are the lesser characters, Howard Sakata is brilliant as the mute henchman Oddjob, a martial arts expert who has a lethal bowler hat and a sick smile, and Honor Blackman is on top form as Bond girl, Pussy Galore, who is like a continuation of her character in The Avengers and is the only Bond girl to have been older than 007.My favourite scenes are the car chase in Switzerland, where Bond displays his stunt Aston Martin to full effect, Bond being tortured in Goldfinger's factory( " do you expect to talk, Goldfinger", " no, Mr Bond, I expect you to die) and the fight between Bond and Oddjob inside Fort Knox. Don't forget the magnificent theme tune sung by Shirley Bassey( Goldfingaaahhh!), featuring a young Jimmy Page on session guitar. All in all, Connery's finest Bond and one of the greatest films of all time.

Most people know their are formulas for action films. But do people know what movies inspired them? The first one of the bunch was James Bond's third adventure, Goldfinger (in case you are wondering, the others include Lethal Weapon, Die Hard, and Point Break). Face it, this Bond film set the standard for all others. Bond must stop Goldfinger from robbing Fort Knox of its gold bullion. In 007's way are a very deadly laser, a temptuous vixen named Pussy Galore, and Odd Job. First, this is the James Bond when Connery put it in full force. Sure, From Russia with Love is the best down-to-earth Bond, but this one started more of the spy movie clichés: the megalomaniac, the hired assassin, the woman with a very sexual name, and the action sequences. It also gives us one of the most tense Bond moments as he faces a laser that threatens to slice him into two. He also faces a very powerful nemesis, Odd Job who throws an iron hat. The best part, I think, is the way he seduces Pussy Galore and brings her to his side. That is what makes Bond the ultimate male fantasy. Not only can he out think opponents, kill the bad guy and deliver clever lines, he always gets the girl. In all the Bond movies, I rank this one as number two, finishing only behind From Russia with Love. Casino Royale is a close number three. All the others finish in Goldfinger's dust.

Review title: Third Time is Definitely the Charm
Review_body: Most consider Goldfinger, only the third film in the franchise, to be the best of all Bonds. Younger viewers can boast about the superiority of Skyfall all they want - Skyfall is a fine Bond film, no question. But it is no Goldfinger. Everything that made the first two Bond films work so well - memorable villains, Bond ladies, a sly sense of humor, witty dialogue, suspense - is on display here, along with a generous does of action. Even people who have not seen Goldfinger must be familiar with the "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die!" line. The film's story moves along at a nice pace, setting up the characters, particularly Goldfinger himself (the golf match is classic). Yes, elements are dated - what do you expect for a movie made in 1964? There is a reason Goldfinger is the only Bond film to appear on many "greatest adventure films of all time" lists. Watch and enjoy.

While this Bond movie is one of the better and more memorable of the series, I still wouldn't call it a terrific movie.  The problem I have with Goldfinger is that its plot and characters are so blatantly outdated.  Overall, the movie is somewhat racist and of course sexist.  The ladies are gorgeous, but generally easy, petty, surprisingly treacherous and not very good at anything else.  (I suppose this might be better than the newer movies, such as the World is Not Enough, in which the audience is expected to believe that an airhead like Denise Richards is a rocket scientist.)Goldfinger is unbridled male chauvinism at its best and worst.   Having said that, I'll admit that it does have a lot going for it.  Pussy Galore probably ranks among the top-5 bond women of all times.  Bond's Aston Martin looked great then and still looks great now.  Oddjob is possibly the best-known bond Henchman of all (plus he's real good to use in the Goldeneye video game; since he's so short he's hard to shoot).  Finally, this movie definitely does have some of the most infamous lines in all Bond history.I didn't think the plot here was particularly good or plausible, though it's no worse than any other Bond flick.  However, I did not find Goldfinger to be a particularily intimidating villain.  He seemed a little too human and ordinary, and his initial scenes showed him dabbling in fairly low-stakes gambling.  Overall, he was one of the least interesting Bond villains.All in all, Goldfinger now shows its wear and tear over time, but it's still required viewing for anyone who claims to be a Bond fan.

Awesome, just awesome.This film had superb acting, superb, interesting characters and above all had some of the best action sequences in any Bond movie.Goldfinger bought us the most memorable characters in any Bond movie with Pussy Galore, Odd Job, Goldfinger himself and Jill and Tilly Masterson just to name a few. When Bond discovers Jill Masterson covered in gold paint this ranks as one of the best and most shocking parts in a movie of all time.The scene in where Bond is sent to Goldfinger's ranch is supposedly in Kentucky, USA but in reality this was shot at Pinewood Studio's in London, in fact the only actor to travel to the United States was Cec Linder who played Felix Leither and I must add was played exceptionally well by Linder but unfortunately fans of the film don't appear to remember him enough than say David Hedison who played the Leither character in Live and Let Die and Licence to Kill.This Bond film did not mention the organization known as SPECTRE which gave us Ernest Stavro Blofeld, Donald Grant and Dr No just to name a few. Perhaps producers decided audiences at the time were tiring of introducing SPECTRE in every Bond film, but what makes up in this film was Auric Goldfinger played magnificently by Gert Frobe. However his voice was dubbed for the film because Frobe could not speak a word of English.Harold Sakata who played Odd Job was excellent in the role and Sakata was a professional wrestler and went under the name of Tosh Togo.One of the best Bond film EVER made.Grade - A**

Goldfinger has some of the most iconic images, lines, and gadgets that have come to define the series, for better or worse. The Bond series goes through a typical cycle. It starts out with a more down to earth action film, and they gradually become more and more outlandish until they cross the line. The producers decide to go back to square one. Goldfinger marked the start of the over-the-top gadgets and villains, but I think it is has a better balance between the outlandish and serious aspects than some of the films that followed it.It's all here, the Aston Martin car equipped with bulletproof glass, spikes on the hubcaps, and a passenger ejector seat. Jill Masterson, the woman painted in gold, is a classic death in the series. We also have Odd Job, the Japanese henchman with a deadly bowler hat. Gert Frobe plays Auric Goldfinger, who straps Bond to a table and nearly kills him with a giant laser. His line "No Mr. Bond, I expect you to die" has become a classic rebuttal. Goldfinger was one of the more comical Bond villains, partially due to his appearance, and he had good chemistry with Connery even though Frobe's voice was dubbed. The plot was as ludicrous as ever; Goldfinger plans on detonating a nuclear bomb in Fort Knox, making the U.S. gold supply radioactive, thus increasing his stock. The inside of Fort Knox was like a dungeon, but the real Fort looks nothing like it. A brutal fight with Odd Job and Bond ensues, although it was not as brutal as the fight with Red Grant. Honor Blackman, Goldfinger's pilot, was the first Bond girl whose voice was not dubbed. Her performance stands out as one of the better girls of the Connery era. Connery is great again.My one criticism would be that Goldfinger drags in the middle. I find Bond films often have problems with pacing and length, and James Bond follows Goldfinger's car for a little too long. For its time though, this was the most action packed film in the series and it remains on the top of many people's Bond lists. It was my first Connery Bond film so it is my sentimental favorite.

Old is GOLD! A classic plot to destroy the Fort Knox gold depository, present a diabolocal scenario. A classic movie, where Bond overpowers an alleged lesbian with his manly charms. The action is steady. With a stunning climax. Enjoy !

This is definitely an Excellent Bond Film. It has an awesome car and a pretty good bad guy. Sean Connery is also excellent as Bond. Some of the real praise goes to Goldfingers Henchman, Oddjob, who is very original and very lethal. The Bond girl, Pussy Galore, is a beautiful, but sassy bitch. She is arguably one of the best Bond Girls. This movie has the most memorable scenes of James Bond Movies, Bond strapped to a table with a laser going to cut him in two and the girl covered in Gold on the bed.

I tell you what is wrong with this film. Nothing, not one thing. Ladies and gentlemen, this is as close to cinematic perfection that I have seen. Entertaining to the extreme, featuring some of the most famous scenes in the history of cinema as well as showing how good Bond films can be, Goldfinger is quite possibly the best Bond film ever made. I love Bond films, don't get me wrong and I love all the actors who have played the part over the years, but Goldfinger is a cinematic cocktail of perfection. Setting in stone many of the trademarks we associate with Bond films, Goldfinger has it all; a pre-title sequence that is more or less a mini-Bond adventure, beautiful women, a maniacal and brilliantly over the top villain with equally over the top henchman (he breaks golf balls with his hand), car chase with Bond's car full of helpful gadgets, a cracking theme song and a great music score from John Barry, not to forget, great puns. The film is brilliant throughout and while the Bond films did get bigger and some are equal to Goldfinger, it is arguable if some have bettered it.Sean Connery as James Bond is superb throughout, his delivery of the his dialog superb and his performance assured and confident. Gert Frobe may have been dubbed, but he has screen presence and while Harold Sakata does not say any lines, the same is true of himself, with his fight against Bond in Fort Knox superbly staged. Honor Blackman is just gorgeous throughout and her silky delivery of her lines and the manner of her performance is one of the highlights of the Bond series.Overall this is a great film, it is has it all, action laughs and one liners aplenty. Guy Hamilton's direction is slick throughout and the film moves at such a pace that the 105 minute running time flies by. While whether its impact on the Bond series is a positive or a negative one remains argumentative, but nevertheless this is one of the funnest films committed to celluloid.

First there was Dr. No and then came From Russia with Love, but not even together can they compete against the best Bond film ever made, Goldfinger. Sean Connery returns as Agent 007 as he is sent out to investigate a mysterious gold lover by the name of Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) and he discovers the mad mans secret plans for the biggest bank job ever in the history of the world, the robbing of Fort Knox.This film is pure Bond, it gets everything right. With 007 you get separate ingredients all Bond films have but not well put together but with this film, even in the first scene, you get the whole Bond flavor. This film is the best 007 film to date with the best villain. Oddjob played by Harold Sakata has given one of the best performances of the evil henchman, being the most famous in the whole series till Jaws came along, and the plot is memorable. But what is a Bond film without a beautiful Bond girl and this film delivers with not just one Bond girl, but three! You have the beautiful Jill Masterson who you see in one of the most famous Bond scenes ever, her corpse painted in pure gold paint. Next you have Tilly Masterson, Jills sister, who sadly gets killed by Oddjobs killer bowler derby hat, and you get the main coarse with Miss. Pussy Galore. And aside from the famous quote " Bond...James Bond" you get the one single line that everyone in the whole world will remember after this film. "You expect me to talk Goldfinger?" "No Mr. Bond I expect you to die!" You'll get caught up in the tense fight between 007 and Oddjob in the vault of Fort Knox with a ticking nuclear time bomb about to go off, and you'll get in depth with the villainous schemes in the Operation Grand Slam scene with Goldfinger and his investors. So if your a James Bond nut like me you need to turn off the T.V and go find this movie and watch it right now!

Ian Fleming's and Albert R. Brocolli's first selection for the James Bond role is appropriately perfect as far as the original novel related Bond is concerned. That is to say that Sean Connery's physiognomy and aquiline facial contours are the perfect representation of what a clever,intelligent, bold, suave, tall and handsome hero has to portray. Being a pioneer James Bond and imbued with the original reflection and demeanor that was required for the particular spy character and surely guide lined by the writer himself, Sean Connery was the perfect choice.It is, however, sad that Connery, after performing just in five bond flicks became tired of the stereotypic role and refused to play anymore. George Lazenby took the torch for only one Bond outing before Connery realized his mistake and agreed to play the same dashing role in "Diamonds are Forever". Thereafter, upon his final refusal to play James Bond, Roger Moore appeared on the scene who had been earlier rejected by Brocolli (considered by Fleming) for sporting a too pretty and soft visage to come up to the robustly clever role.Roger Moore, by that time i.e, 1973 had already passed his prime lovely youth while playing Simon Templar in TV series - "The Saint" and by that time had established himself to portray the image of a bold suave and urbane detective. His pretty features had also diluted and his appearance became mature with the passage of time. While with Connery, the producers got annoyed for his erratic attitude and signed Moore for a number of Bond movies. Later, Connery regretted a lot to have done away with such a good team, good money and lucrative perky role. He came in legal brawl with Moore to recapture the title role which was appropriately set aside by the court.As far as, Goldfinger is concerned, it is, an improved version of Dr. No. and From Russia with Love having good musical score, as well. Besides, Bond, Goldfinger and OddJob, the deadly steel hat did also carry a lot of suspense adding a new dimension to the heroism of James Bond. Honor Blackman was primarily selected for the role because she boldly accepted the outrageous name of Pussy Galore for the lead feminine role, whereas, other actresses had denied to perform with such a rude name.Last but not the least, Guy Hamilton's direction was good enough to elevate the 3rd Bond movie to a real success story.

Review title: The Ultimate Benchmark for the future Bonds.
Review_body: Goldfinger is the Ultimate Benchmark in the James Bond series. This was the blueprint in plot, guns, beautiful women, evil foes, evil henchmen, enthralling title song (GOLDFINGAAAAAA!!!!) and World Domination plans.Sean Connery clearly enjoys playing James Bond here for perhaps the last time. He now clearly dominates every scene hes in. Sean Connery IS James Bond (although his hair is starting to look false) he looks ice cool in white Tuxedo in the Pre-Credits sequence walking into a Mexican bar like he owns the place while lighting a cigarette. He puts Rick in Casablanca in the shade on appearance alone.Gert Frobe as Auric Goldfinger is a criminal Mastermind you will never forget. Every scene Frobe is in, despite being charming and charismatic, you never know just how evil and cold blooded his character really is. The title song by Shirley Bassey is memorable, but after listening to it a couple of dozen times over viewing periods you will get sick of it.Harold Sakata along with Richard Kiel is the ultimate Bond Henchman. Crushing golf balls in his hand and chopping statue's heads off with his Razor rimmed gentleman Butler's hat, he is the character you will remember most when you first see this film. His big fight with 007 at Fort Knox is one of Goldfinger's highlights.A fantastic Classic.

Sean Connery really does a good job in his third bond film against the evil Aric Goldfinger who loves gold so much that his plan is to break into Fort Knox and steal all of the gold.Along with Oddjob and the infamous bowler hat that slices through a statue's head also with Pussy Galore who eventually turns against Goldfinger.Sadly for Goldfinger he meets his end by , in a plane, he shoots a window and gets sucked out.Then Bond and Pussy jump out of the plane and onto a island.8/10

Review title: No Mister Bond, I expect you to die!
Review_body: I will admit, many consider Goldfinger to be the best Bond of all, never-mind the best Connery effort. And as an official Bond-O-phile, I too will cast my opinion... it's really good, but not the best.To me, it's predecessors are two better films, with 'From Russia..' being the better Connery vehicle. Less gadgets, more spy caper.Goldfinger is a great 007 film, and indeed can fit my classification of epic, but there are some better 007 films. This movie does have it all, however, with a great sinister villain who is as human as the rest, a hot broad Bond Girl in Pussy Galore, and of course, another Felix Leiter... a trend that carries on today. And don't forget... the DB5.Gadgets guns and girls, this film does reach epic and fills all the Bond requirements.Connery near the top of his 007 game.

Well, what can you say about the film tat has come to be regarded as the quintessential 007 movie? Not a lot that hasn't really been said already.Let's try and get a few negatives out of the way first. The fact that Gert frobe was dubbed throughout...although it works brilliantly. Ahem.Okay, how about the fact that Goldfinger doesn't kill Bond, but waits for a laser to very slowly cut it's way towards him? Although this creates brilliant tension and provides the series with one of it's greatest pieces of dialogue. I will not bore you by repeating this.What about the fact that Pussy Galore turns against Goldfinger after a quick bit of slap and tickle with Bond? Though she wasn't very keen on Goldie anyway...Oh hell! I give up. There really is very little wrong with this sublime movie. It sticks relatively to the plot of the original book, it has sexy women, it has Oddjob and His Spinning Hat of Menace. It has Sean Connery acting cooler than a penguin with his tongue stuck to a very large iceberg for a long, long time.In short, this movie simply is Bond...James Bond. My 3rd favourite! 8/10

Goldfinger is the third Sean Connery Bond film and is the film were they really perfected the Bond formula. This still remains one of the best Bond films for me. Connery is great, the villain is great and the Bond girl. This film has many iconic scenes and lines. This film also has a really good plot and soundtrack. Even though this film doesn't have as much action compared to many others it never gets boring. My only main complaint is the scene with Bond and the Bond girl when they are in the Bond. That scene makes me cringe a bit. Other than that it is an amazing movie.9.4/10

I am not a fanatical Bond fan and haven't seen most of them but figured I would give some of them a try now that I could see them on DVD in widescreen instead of on TBS with a bunch of commercials.  That said, this was a very enjoyable movie, with clever dialogue, memorable villains and unpredictable plot turns.  The picture quality suffered a few times due to age, but the colors were fairly vivid.  What I found most refreshing having seen a few of the more recent Pierce Brosnin Bond films was the lack of frenetic editing and pounding music during the action/fight scenes.  GOLDFINGER doesn't pound you over the head with loud, obnoxious effects and MTV editing.  It just tells an exciting story and does it very well.  * * * 1/2

By consensus, "Goldfinger" remains the best of the Bond movies. The third James Bond movie took 1964 by storm and influenced action movies for years afterward. It was the fifth Bond that I saw, and it took me awhile to sweep aside the aura and focus on the movie. I liked what I saw then, and I still like it now. I prefer "From Russia with Love" and some of the later Bonds, but "Goldfinger" should not be discounted as an excellent movie.The movie opens with a fun scene where Bond sabotages a heroin dealer, but he spends the bulk of the movie locking steel with a completely different villain. Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe, voice of Michael Collins) is an obese international businessman whose obsession with gold is so extreme he will "welcome any enterprise which will increase his stock." This naturally concerns the Bank of England, since gold was still used in 1964 to set the value of the pound and large scale smuggling could reduce their accuracy.This is where James Bond (Sean Connery) comes in to gather evidence for the bank to use in court proceedings. That soon becomes unimportant as Bond quickly discovers that everybody has been thinking way too small regarding how far Goldfinger's greed will drive him. On Goldfinger's payroll are a pilot named Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman) and a Korean named Oddjob (Olympic weightlifting silver medalist Harold Sakata).Oddjob is the best supporting villain in the series. As a man of no words, he allows his gaze and smile to speak for him. Oddjob possesses massive physical strength and prefers to kill his targets with a chakram doubling as the brim of his ever present bowler hat. Although he is intimidating from his first appearance, it is not until the movie's splendid climax that we see the awesome extent of his physical capabilities. Only Jaws rivals him in the debate for most acclaimed henchman in the entire series, and I think Jaws is overrated.Unfortunately, Oddjob also spawned a bad habit. Starting with "Diamonds Are Forever" eight years later, the producers often looked to emulate the style of "Goldfinger" in future movies. By the middle of the 1970s, they had already filmed the most memorable of the James Bond novels and had to start writing their own stories. Jaws was the first of four nearly invincible supporting villains, but, unlike Oddjob, they often looked farcical. It is a feat of toughness to absorb a direct hit from a gold bar. Being able to lift up and throw a motorcycle is corny and stupid."Goldfinger" is lighter than the first two 007 adventures. Composer John Barry employs relaxing violin measures during a scenic drive through the mountains of Switzerland, contrasting the horn crescendos in the score of "Dr. No" and the foreboding notes heard during "From Russia with Love." The indoor scenes are more brightly lit than before, and the humor is increased. The running tension between Bond and MI6 equipment manager Q (Desmond Llewelyn) started in "Goldfinger" and grew into one of the Bond series most endearing elements.Twenty-three James Bond movies have made the series' hall-of-villainy crowded at the top. Goldfinger belongs in that crowd. The fact that Oddjob works for him boosts his credibility by itself. Mr. Goldfinger sees no need to be loud, unpleasant, or brutal to make his point. Pussy Galore, who along with Octopussy has spawned quite a few questionable jokes through the years, is more useful than Honey Rider and Tatiana Romanova were, but also a slightly inferior character. Shirley Eaton provides some additional beauty as Jill Masterson, the first and greatest golden girl.Connery is splendid as usual in the action scenes, especially the showdown with Oddjob, and some good special effects and a witty script help along the way. Finally, the fun gadgets elevate the overall quality, from Bond's special scuba suit to the great Aston Martin DB5 with modifications.The movie's first 50 minutes stand up to any film in the series. Every chapter, from the "shocking" opening moments, the mental jousting of the golf game featuring a delightful bit performance by Gerry Dugan, to the factory spying and the car chase, are as good as any Bond film can hope for. The middle act is short on excitement and runs slightly too long; on the other hand, it is hard to find anything to remove that would make the movie better.Many of the Bond movies' recurring trademarks started in "Goldfinger." I have never thought is should be declared best Bond movie for that reason. It also would be wrong to give later movies too much credit because they improved on what "Goldfinger" started. In a way, its legacy lives in each of the 20 Bond movies that have followed. In the end, the reason I do not place in my top five Bond movies comes mostly from my personal preferences and not any weaknesses of the movie. As I said, I liked it the first time, and I like it just as much now. High quality movies often do that.

I saw this several times at the theatre in my youth--it was really the first high-flying gadget-electronics driven film in the Bond series (although a couple of plainer 'gadgets' saved Bond's life in the previous FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE). This film sparked a rush of imitators & knock-offs
(Dean Martin's Matt Helm & James Coborne's FLINT series). No one quite matched Connery's cold-hearted charm, however. After all, if you read the books, Bond was far from a nice guy--the 00 meant he was a killer, after all.I'd like to comment on 1 weakness & 1 strength in the film:1) Early, Bond catches Goldfinger cheating at cards, & nails him for it, but he was supposed to be doing a surveillance. He also steals his girlfriend. Talk about blowing your cover. Wouldn't look good on a spy resumé.2) In the book, Goldfinger plans on robbing Fort Knox of its gold--absurd, right? In the movie, Goldfinger plots to contaminate that gold with radiation, thus increasing the value of his own holdings---brilliant, eh?The film has a super-villain, OddJob, who is a brilliant addition, a karate expert who also wears a razor-plated frisbee for a bowler hat. Will Bond beat this guy?Anyway, overall, the movie is a classic (even if it's a bit dated) and well worth seeing if it hasn't crossed your path yet.

What can you say about the James Bond classic made in 1964. This was what got people into the James Bond franchise. This time he takes on Goldfinger a rich guy that just loves gold and it's color. Goldfinger also has a manservant Oddjob who has a metal rim on his hat like King Lao from Mortal Kombat. There's also James Bond's new car that also has ejector seats in it too. As well as some scenes that show you how it works. Even this one scene where Bond gets captured and Goldfinger has him tied down and uses a laser to kill him. There's also Pussy Galore a lady pilot that's allied with Goldfinger in a scheme that involves Fort Knox. That's also where I think I'll stop and try not to spoil too much and let you all see it yourself. The movie is a classic and it was amazing seeing all the sets and the 1960's feel as well.

First of all, I must state for the record, Sean Connery is THE James Bond. Even though the first Bond film I ever saw was "For Your Eyes Only" with Roger Moore. I was very young and very much drawn in. I have seen every one of the Bond films and without a doubt, "Goldfinger" is the finest the 007 saga has to offer.Before I had begun an appreciation of the Connery films, i.e. before I'd seen them, a good friend and cartooning mentor, Ross Paperman, sorted me out. He helped me see how Connery's Bond was suave and sophisticated but also demonstrated a quality the other Bonds do not portray: fear. Not a panicky soil-your-pants kind of fear, mind you. But Connery's Bond actually has a few anxious, sweat-soaked-brow moments. A perfect example is when Bond is strapped to a table as Goldfinger's captive with a laser beam primed to cut him in half. 007 has to think fast. "Do you expect me to talk?" "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die!" A famous scene and line from Bond's most enjoyable film.Perhaps what makes the earlier films more enjoyable is that they had fresh, innovative elements that have now become cliché and gimmicky. The new films are often stale and already covered ground and they don't even appear to be trying anymore.But it's more than that. Even watching "Goldfinger" today, having seen all the latest in special effects and technology that Hollywood has to offer, it still is riveting and thoroughly entertaining. That is also without the added advantage of being overly nostalgic about "Goldfinger". How could I? I hadn't even been born when it first hit theaters, and it was far from my first 007 experience. The story, the characters and the fun of "Goldfinger" is timeless and if given a chance could probably rope in a whole new generation of fans. It just doesn't seem likely to happen.Much of the satire from the Austin Powers films is directly derived from the Connery films, especially "Goldfinger" and "Dr. No", proving their lasting effect on popular culture. As well, John Barry's scores from the Connery films are finding their way into the ears of a new generation through pop music as snippets from his soundtracks are sampled by such artists as Robbie Williams, Mono and Curve, to name a few.But if by some fluke you read this and you haven't seen "Goldfinger" yet, do yourself right and acquaint yourself with the real James Bond. You'll probably be hooked by the time you hear Shirley Bassey's voice in the famous opening theme.

***Warning! Spoiler Information Inside***After the wide acceptance of From Russia With Love(1963), Eon released the follow up Goldfinger to great expectation.Bond is tasked by M to determine why considerable sums of gold are leaving Britain's banks. His search leads to the American Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe). Goldfinger it seems loves gold , loves it so much he's intent upon owning it all. Including Fort. Knox.Goldfinger was masterfully directed by bond rookie Guy Hamilton. At this point Bond had been a female attraction (owing to Sean Connery). The franchise at last settles in this movie with the gadgets , girls and guns, taking a decidedly male turn in culture. Bond girls include Honor Blackmon (Avengers), and Shirley Eaton as the famous woman in gold.Four stars(of 5.)

This film is so memorable for me as it contains numerous Bond Classics: One line quotes "I think you've made your point", an excellent baddie "No Mr. Bond, I expect you to die!". A film which has had numerous aspects replicated in other films, and well directed. Probably my favourite Connery Bond film.

Review title: Bond Month #3: Let's have a little fun with Mr. Goldfinger...
Review_body: The first Bond movie that I ever had just plain old-fashioned fun while watching. Goldfinger has it all. There's a memorable Bond (Sean Connery at his greatest as 007), a great villain, great Bond girl, and of course a great plot and great action sequences. Words cannot describe how good Goldfinger is, but I'll try it anyway.Instead of getting a taut Cold War thriller that was From Russia with Love, we get a surprisingly intriguing smuggling/monetary inflation story. Bond is ordered to trail a German banker named Mr. Goldfinger (played deliciously by Gert Frobe) Goldfinger's number one obsession is obviously gold, so he seeks to increase his stock by destroying the U.S. gold supply located at Fort Knox with a dirty nuclear bomb.Goldfinger is a great larger-than-life villain, but is very restrained n the sense that he just want more gold, which is the great love of his life. He's not trying to take over the world, which to me is a breath of fresh air. The sidekick, Oddjob, is also very memorable. Harold Sokata became world famous for throwing the steel-brimmed hat and silent but menacing performance every henchman has tried to match since.And then we have the ever awesome, ever popular, ever innuendo inducing Pussy Galore, played by Honor Blackman. Hee-Hee, that name, ha ha never gets old. But thats not the only reason why we remember her. She's driven, sassy, smart, but according to the original book, a lesbian, which is why she says, "Turn off the charm, I'm immune." I'm not opposed to this, that's actually very unique, but of course Bond easily (well sort of) gets inside and changes her over. Bad James, bad.And then we have pretty good action sequences. We are introduced to the greatest car of all time, the gadget-laden, sleek super car known as the Astin Martin DB-5 (It's also the first film where Desmond Llewellyn really shines as Q) And we also get a great, if fantastical view and fight inside the vault at Fort Knox, the background provided by legendary production designer Ken Adam.This film is a quintessential Bond film. I do give a lot of credit to director Guy Hamilton for injecting the series with more fun and sly humor in this film (even though he didn't do so hot in the 70s, but I'll get to that later) Heck, this is probably the most iconic Bond film of them all, and for good reason. Goldfinger is a lot of fun to watch, and golden to look at.

Review title: Perfection. How can you top characters with names like Odd Job and Pussy Galore? The best of the Bond films.
Review_body: The iconic James Bond movie, this third entry into the franchise is rightly heralded for offering the perfect blend of action, adventure, gunplay, fisticuffs, gadgetry (that Aston Martin!), romance, derring-do, and just about everything else.It has Shirley Bassey's operatic theme, the Aston Martin and Shirley Eaton, killed with that magnificently macabre gold paint.The one that all other Bond films must live up to, and the only one of the films that surpasses the book upon which it is based.Goldfinger remains the gold standard for the Bond movies. Recent entries can't compare to this lustrous thriller, a throwback to when the term "thriller" had meaning.These Bond capers were the prototypes and set the gold standard for dozens of fantasy thrillers that followed. Probably the best of the gadget-filled 007 extravaganzas.Q brings out the Aston Martin for the first time, and Shirley Bassey shatters the speakers with the consummate Bond song.The definitive, quintessential Bond.

Review title: Effortless cool, Bond was never greater
Review_body: Now, we're talking.What Goldfinger does, that so many subsequent Bond movies forget, is not overdo things. It underplays everything. This is a movie of such effortless cool and style that it's sweeps the viewer along with charm. Many Bond movies also jar between action and non-action scenes (The World is Not Enough, for instance). Goldfinger moves through the gears with aplomb.Goldfinger is so stylish that even the pre-credit sequence contains more cool than the entirety of most 007 films. You have the iconic wetsuit/tuxedo scene; Bond lighting a cigarette just as an explosion goes off; the unflinchingly brutality of Bond electrocuting a man then just turning away to make a quip; and finally him slamming the door - even than leads perfectly into the Shirley Bassey theme.Everything is pitch perfect. Goldfinger himself is the ideal combo of vulgar greed and gentlemanly host. A perfect foe for for Bond. Pussy Galore combines the voluptuousness of 60's Bond girls with the spirit of the more modern ones. Connery himself is the epitome of Bond; charismatic, tough, ultra-suave.There are plenty of standout scenes; the laser-beam table is unmatched in the series for sheer, pure tension; the aston martin chase is again one of the best in the series and shows up similar scenes in the likes of Die Another Day as merely visual showcases - this one is genuinely exciting. Bond's fight with Oddjob set the template for numerous, 'How do I stop this guy?' cat-and-mouse fight scenes, especially in Spielberg movies.You might argue than Goldfinger could do with at least one more action set-piece, as it does slow down before the climax whilst Bond is Goldfinger's guest. But it wouldn't really fit into the story. As a Bond film, Goldfinger is practically perfect. Connery even has the best wig.

Review title: The most over-rated Bond of all!!!!
Review_body:
Sorry guys, but I just can't see why so many of you agree that this is the best Bond flick. I won't go too far as to say that it's the worst one, because there are a few moments (just a few) that make it ok.   
The pre-credits sequence is cool. The title song is cool. Oddjob is cool.....But that's it!!Auric Goldfinger turns out as a bumbling, non-threatening menace. I mean, after he's been outsmarted by Bond at the card & golf games, he no longer appears as a super villain and his character becomes worn out. And besides from turning Pussy Galore into a heterosexual, what does 007 actually DO in this flick? He destroys the Aston Martin(the only exciting scene in the flick). He gets locked up for half of the movie. Escapes. Gets caught. Gets locked up again. *Yawn* Gets his a$$ kicked by Oddjob until he uses his smarts.And then sits back & lets Leiter deactivate the bomb. Geez! And I know deep down that you GOLDFINGER lovers have to let out an embarassing chuckle when the Fort Knox army gets gassed. Yet this was the one that paved the way for the comic book approach for Bond. That can be considered good or bad. It depends on what can of James Bond fan you are. But FROM RUSSIA WITH LOVE is, and will always be,  the best of the early 007 adventures.  'Nuff Said!

Every other Bond film that follows is a pale attempt to recapture the recipe of 'Goldfinger'. The movie makers had the ingredients for the follow-ups, but it never quite captured the magic. What we got is just more circus stunts, goofy gadgets and less enthusiasm. Connery justifiably left and no one has done it as well since. Connery shows what a great actor can do; with vulnerability, cool assurance and class.'Dr No', 'From Russia With Love' and 'Goldfinger' are THE summation of James Bond. The rest have moments of greatness, but ended up with episodic parts that were better than the whole.The best background music in the entire franchise (notice I didn't say series).9 out of 10. Full of flaws, but why carp!

Often considered the best Bond film, it's hard to understand why. It's all so very average and can't approach "On Her Majesty's Secret Service" and "Licence to Kill." The trio of villains -- leader Auric Goldfinger (Gert Frobe), pilot Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman) and manservant Oddjob (Harold Sakata) -- amount to little more than petty bank robbers. And Bond (Sean Connery) romps around, sleeping with an unrealistic amount of women for the time frame (let's face the fact that he's not that charming, sexy or alluring).In all fairness, this was the Bond film that marked the transition from thrillers to action comedies. But the over-the-top nature is downplayed by all concerned and the climax has nothing to make it stand out. No volcano, no space station, no hopping between oil trucks. Just a dull, bland blink-and-you-miss-it climax on a plane. Both "Octopussy" and "The Living Daylights" had better plane climaxes.Performance wise, Sean Connery is a good actor, but not that good of a Bond. Let's face the fact that Roger Moore, Timothy Dalton and Pierce Brosnan were all better. The other actors are adequate. The standout is Honor Blackman as the cold-hearted bitch we love to hate. Too bad about the character rape at the end.It's not all bad, though. It certainly has a better pace than the one before it and the one after it, but it certainly gets on one's nerves at times, especially at the horrible laser scene ("No Mister Bond, I except you to die" -- how pathetic).

Review title: Not the Best Bond but Still Pretty Good
Review_body: The best Bond movie is The Spy Who Loved Me, in my opinion. Goldfinger is also pretty good, though. There are quite a few exciting moments, like the car chases and the laser scene. And the corpse of Shirley Eaton covered in gold paint is a memorable image. But some parts could have been far better. The fight between Bond and Oddjob, for instance. It felt pretty subdued rather than thrilling, which it should have been. Oddjob just throws Bond around and doesn't even try to snap his neck (he probably could have succeeded if he tried). Honestly the whole climax of the movie could have been done better. I mean, Goldfinger says there are 41,000 troops stationed around Fort Knox. So where are they? After they get the message that the atomic bomb has been delivered, we see only fifteen at Fort Knox.Also, it doesn't make much sense that when Bond lied about knowing about Operation Grand Slam, Goldfinger didn't even ask him to elaborate a bit on it to find out if he was telling the truth. Still, it's better than what happened in the book, where Goldfinger just decides to make Bond his secretary instead of killing him, even though Bond didn't say anything about Operation Grand Slam. So it's definitely worth seeing but I just don't agree with everyone else that it's the best Bond film. It's not even the best of Sean Connery's Bond films (that would probably be Thunderball).

This was Connery's best film, third time knocked it out of the park. This one had it all, Good storyline, good song, decent villian. Cec Linder played Felix in this one, and did a good job. Honor Blackman was good as Pussy galore. Don't want to give away too much. Goldfinger is a Spectre agent wanting to corner the gold market by storming Fort Knox. This is a worth while watch for any day of the week. 10

Goldfinger is one of the most enjoyable, boys own/comic book style adventure movies ever to be made. It has a fantastic script by Paul Diehn and Richard Maibaum, excellent Direction from Guy Hamilton, Fantastic acting by the three leads [Sean Connery, Honour Blackman and Gert Frobe] and some of the most inspired action set pieces to appear on the big screen. In Bond terms it also has a fine score by John Barry, one of the most instantly recognisable Title songs sung by Shirley Bassey, the beautifull Golden Girl, Shirley Eaton and Bonds most Famous henchman : Oddjob, Harold Sakata.By now you probably realise iam a fan. Well. as it goes i find it almost impossible to watch the first two Connery Bonds, because i was brought up on a diet of 70's and 80's escapism, with fun, humour action and thrills in every scene. Well, i didn't have to look much further than Goldfinger than that.The Opening pre Credits sequence sets the scene. Any film in wich its lead actor can strip away a wet suit to reveal a Tuxedo, is obviously having fun with itself. Or to be presise, Guy Hamilton is having fun. With the help of Broccoli, Saltzman, Maibaum and Ken Adam, Guy Hamilton set the blue prints for action movies for, perhaps forever. Sean Connery is very much the Superhero in this outing, and that is after all as we like him. He is having the time of his life with this movie and it shows, this is perhaps his bset performance as Bond. There is also Honour Blackman, very much a role model for Action Heroines for years to come as Pussy Galore. Galores lesbian undertones are toned down from the way they were in the book, but she is sexy and full to bursting with womens Lib. Gert Frobe is fantastic as Goldfinger, very chilling ."No Mr Bond i expect you to Die" has gone down in cinematic history and it is atestament to the man who dubbed Frobe!The real star of the show is Ken Adam. His sets are fantastic. I have never seen Fort Knox, and i dont want to because i have seen it in Goldfinger. Adam is a genius, as are Peter and Michael Lamont who helped him out with the sets. Add to all this the Aston Martin with Ejector Seat and Revolving Licence Plate and more, A Hawaian henchman who throws his blade laced Bowler hat, a girl killed by suffication due to being painted Gold, and THAT Lazer between the legs. What you have got is pure unadulterated Comic Book fun. Even if you dont like Comic Books, you will love Goldfinger.

Review title: The Definitive JB; Why is it not on the AFI List?
Review_body: The AFI list of the greatest films of all time is very subjective, but it is somewhat solid, especially in it's top 20 or so.  The American Film Institute took into account influence, popularity, and box office when they decided what would qualify for its list of "100 Years, 100 Movies." This is not my favorite Bond film, but COME ON!  According to "Cubby" Broccolli, half the world has seen a James Bond film, and this is the definitive one!  So many memorable scenes, lines, and characters.  It was also a major influence for action/spy films for years to come, and a box-office record-breaker when it opened.  People might think nothing of the AFI list, but it is a good effort, and this is the one film not included that definitely deserves to be there!
