Review title: The best Bond I've seen so far.
Review_body: I haven't seen all of the Bond films yet, but so far this is the best that I've seen. The film runs perfectly from it's slick opening title sequence up until the explosive finale in Fort Knox. The film has great twists, action, story, and truly memorable characters. Bond is at his best, Auric Goldfinger is a pretty original villain, and Oddjob steals the show with his uncanny hat throwing skills. Terrific entertainment.***** out of *****

Review title: Not the worst Bond, but maybe the most disappointing
Review_body: Goldfinger is probably the most popular and most beloved Bond movie of the entire series but for some reason it did not do much for me. Do not get me wrong, it was by no means horrible; it was a certainly a decent and watchable flick, but I can't help but feel disappointed by it.The acting is solid enough, with Connery giving a very confident and convincing portrayal of 007, and his usual supporting cast at MI6 doing decent jobs as well. Gert Frobe was also quite good as goldfinger. In addition there are some great one-liners, a memorable henchman in Oddjob, the introduction of the fully equipped Aston Martin, a great pre-credits sequence with the explosion and fight at the Caribbean party, and the theme song, performed by Shirley Bassey is one of the best in the entire movie series. Certainly Goldfinger has some of the greatest moments in Bond history, so where does it go wrong?While Goldfinger essentially invented the now standard "fun" Bond blueprint that everyone knows and loves (the crazed villain, the cheesy one liners, the tricked out car, the gadgets, the epic battle at the end, Bond bedding girls left and right throughout the picture, etc.), it all feels strangely pedestrian when compared to the later pictures that nailed the crowd-pleaser style of Bond movie. Goldfinger's biggest crime is that it is just rather dull and uninteresting most of the time. Instead of taking the viewer to marvel at some of the most beautiful locations in the world, most of this movie takes place in Kentucky (although Geneva was cool). The fight scenes are mostly clumsy, except for the one in the beginning. Instead of saving the day, Bond basically just sits in jail most of the time and lets other people do the work for him (he did not even defuse the bomb at Fort Knox). Goldfinger is a transition between the earlier Fleming inspired movies, and the later more outrageous ones without having the benefits of either. There is no sense of danger or suspense in the entire movie; mainly because Auric Goldfinger was one of the lamest, and most nonthreatening villains in Bond history, and add to the fact that his motives were vague and unclear, it is easy not to care about the plot of the movie or its outcome. At the same time it lacks the balls of the later flicks that had over the top ninja battles in Volcanoes, or Bond fighting a seven- foot behemoth while falling out of a plane with no parachute. Goldfinger had a mildly exciting car chase, and the likewise somewhat stimulating finale on the jet. There really is not much more to say. Goldfinger is a decent, but highly disappointing Bond flick. I personally found Dr. No to be far more interesting and suspenseful than anything in this movie, and also From Russia With Love ,and You Only Live Twice, and Thunderball, and Live and Let Die, and The Spy Who Loved Me, and Moonraker, and For Your Eyes Only, and Octopussy (yes even that one, at least it was more fun and had better action, even if it did have a similar plot) and even Goldeneye (though I thought it was kind of weak too).

The third Bond thriller, "Goldfinger," is most definitely the best of Bond. Sean Connery, the first and most exciting of all actors to play James Bond, stars in this wonderful action film alongside Shirley Eaton and Honor Blackman, two extremely beautiful Bond Girls. I'm a huge Bond fan, and of those to whom I've talked that aren't fans of Bond at all, "Goldfinger" remains in their memories as one of the greatest movies they'd ever seen. Shirley Bassey's incredible voice in the movie's title song also marks a memorable moment in the lives of many people. I own all 20 James Bond Films--here's my list (from best to worst):1. Goldfinger (1964)2. On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)3. From Russia with Love (1963)4. The Spy Who Loved Me (1977)5. For Your Eyes Only (1981)6. The Living Daylights (1987)7. GoldenEye (1995)8. Live and Let Die (1973)9. The Man with the Golden Gun (1974)10. Octopussy (1983)11. You Only Live Twice (1967)12. Thunderball (1965)13. A View to a Kill (1985)14. The World is Not Enough (1999)15. Dr. No (1962)16. Die Another Day (2002)17. Tomorrow Never Dies (1997)18. Diamonds are Forever (1971)19. Moonraker (1979)20. Licence to Kill (1989)I've seen them all at least twenty times--I mean it. Trust me when it comes to Bond films. "Goldfinger" is the best--and if you haven't seen it yet, get in the car right now and go rent it. It'll be the highlight of your night.
Every moment of Goldfinger was action packed. Cool chicks cool villains cool spy. It all rocked my world. All together Goldfinger was my favorite Bond.

How can it get any better? James Bond meets Goldfinger (who's out to contaminate the US's gold supply & thereby raise the value of HIS gold)) & Oddjob the hard way. After Bond & Goldfinger's "girl", Jill Masterson hook up for an evening of "fun, James Bond style" (Bond to Felix on the phone "No, I can't make it...something big's come up") he winds up being hit on the head with a bottle Dom Perignon '53, (which is not to be served above the temp of 38 degrees), & Jill winds up dead...& painted gold! From that point on, 007 finds himself in more than a scrape or two with Goldfinger & Oddjob (and glamorous Pussy Galore)as he tries to stop "Operation Grandslam", but in the end, he saves the day & gets the girl. Of all Bond movies I've seen (& I've seem most of them), this one just hits it. It has funny moments, tense moments, great scenery (Switzerland), cool gadgets, etc. Watch & enjoy!

Even if you are not a Bond-Fan, this is a must-see for all film-freaks. Sean Connery shows once more that he is the one and only true Bond. Even if some of the other Bond actors are good ones too (Especially Pierce Brosnan, and the new 007 Daniel Craig), Connery is the only one who combines the charme and wit of an authentic Womanizer with the harshness of a killer in her Majesty's secret service. Connery is Bond, James Bond(despite he is one of the greatest actors as well). The plot is (how in most Bond movies) told very fast: The movie begins with an action scene in Columbia. After the credits, Bond receives (as usual) his assignment at the headquarter of the British secret service. For this he has to make the acquaintanceship of Goldfinger (Bad German Gerd Fröbe, in another great performance). The rest is told really fast: A lot of action, sexy girls (like Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore, probably a name most feminists wouldn't use for the female in a motion picture) and black humour. The point why this Bond is the Best is not the plot (Who cares about the plot in a Bond movie anyway... I mean, he always wins... Doesn't matter how mean the villains and how sexy the girls are). No, the real reason why this one is the Best, is the fact that this movie has everything what you expect when you go in a Bond movie: a lot of action, sexy girls, Cold war atmosphere, a sleazy but charismatic villain (like in most Bond movie it is either a German, a Chinese or a Russian guy... this time it's a German with a Chinese pal), very eccentric ways how this bad boys die, a grim sense of humour, nice cars, Q's gimmicks, Wodka-Martini and at last but not least a Sean Connery at his best. If you don't like this Bond, you won't like the other ones!

I myself being quite possibly one of the largest James Bond fanatics this planet has come to known, would recommend this movie tenfold in comparison to the many other wonderful entries in this never-dying series. Sean Connery stars as the ultimate James Bond in this 1964 classic of the usual ego-galactic maniac wishing to take over the world.  I might recognize that some entries in the James Bond series have not been any milestones in the movie business, but I can guarantee that the finesse of Goldfinger set a precedent in this genre of action film.      To begin with, we have the perfect character.  Sean Connery played the image of the cinematic Bond the best.  [Timothy Dalton was the closest we got to the original Ian Fleming literary character].  In the beginning "teaser", we see the character of James Bond completely--with no strings attached.  He is tough, rough, and after he does his duty--ever so smoothly pulls off a wetsuit to reveal a 1,000$+ suit.  As he goes into the local bar he sits himself down ever so slightly, checks his watch, and feels the explosion next door that he created.  As everyone screams and panics--we see James Bond.  Sean Connery's expression is timeless at this part when we see him so easily light his cigarette and press on as if it didn't phase him in the least.  Afterwards, he returns to his room where he meets a girl, passionately kisses her, only to fight a man who snuck up behind him.  As the fight continues, he electrocutes the man and simply states the classic "shocking....positively shocking".  Now what more do you have to hear about James Bond?  There is humor, lust, fighting, and gadgets all in this 7 odd minute teaser.  This beginning sets the stage for a movie we know will be entertaining.      As the movie progresses we are introduced to the best Bond villain: Auric Goldfinger, whom is brilliantly portrayed by the German actor Gert Frobe.  Bond has a run in with, in my opinion, the best looking Bond girl to date: Shirley Eaton, who plays one of Goldfinger's accomplices.  It is a shame that this beauty had to leave so early in the film at the hand of the mysterious henchman, Oddjob, we first see as a shadow in the film.  When we finally see Oddjob, we get the impression that he is practically harmless; a mute servant whose height is laughable in the presence of Bond's power. However, after we see a lethal toss of his bowler hat, which cuts off the head on a statue--we see that Oddjob has a little aid with him; not to mention the fact we learn he is quite strong, after he crushes Bond's golf ball with his bare hands.  The characters of Oddjob and Goldfinger both make for an excellent pairing of evil in the movie, unparalleled in any of the other Bond pictures.      Pussy Galore, who is introduced as the main Bond girl of the film also has a wonderful part--and certainly meets the expectations of what a Bond beauty is.  Her chemistry with Sean is superb, and you can certainly see the lust of this fling in Bond's "romantic" life. Goldfinger has it all--from the best villain of the series, to one of the best girl's of the series, to certainly the best car of the series--which must not be forgotten.  The Aston Martin DB5 is truly the essential Bond car (given to by Q, who has one of the funniest confrontations with Bond in the series).  Beautiful in appearance, deadly in action.  Watch in the sequence when Bond is speeding through the factory of Goldfinger.  The camerawork when it follows the car is superb.  I still get chills watching and listening to the engine of that beauty. If you want to watch sheer entertainment, watch Goldfinger.  If you want to see a great advance in the action film, watch Goldfinger.  And if you want to see the best movie of the 19 James Bond films, watch Goldfinger. You will not be disappointed, and you will be on the edge of your seat from the point Bond steps out of the water in the beginning, to the hair-raising climax in Fort Knox.  10 stars for Goldfinger (coming from one of the largest James Bond know-it-all's in the world)  :)

I respect Goldfinger for what it did for film and I respect thats its also the most important Bond film as far as formula goes, but I just cant help but feel completely confused by its popularity.Connery is pretty much the only highlight of the film. Goldfinger lacks the suspense and intrigue Dr. No and From Russia With Love had as well as the well staged action. The plot of Goldfinger, while good on paper, is executed without any type of suspense or build up. Everything just sort of "happens". Goldfinger himself is also highly overrated as a villain. Even the most cartoonish of villains like Scaramanga and Drax feel more threatening than Goldfinger. Another overrated aspect in my eyes is Pussy Galore. Whats so great about her? She does next to nothing the whole film and she is regard as one of, if not the best Bond girl. I guess its just the name.All in all I find Goldfinger completely un-remarkable. It lacks the suspense and well executed plot of the previous two films and the sheer fun later films had.5/10

The year is 1964, and Goldfinger sets an entirely new bar for musical soundtrack. John Barry was the major composer. Let's start with the theme song, sung by Shirley Bassey, which made the pop charts on its own strength -- the unconventional chord progression helps build the mystique of the nemesis Goldfinger. In the movie, we've already opened with Bond fighting his way out of some Mexican standoff by throwing a lamp into his adversary's bathtub -- "shocking, simply shocking". Then the title hit Goldfinger. Then cut Miami Beach....a splash of a diver into the pool at the Founainbleu kicks off John Barry's jazzy 3/4 tempo instrumental, which is dripping with sexual libido....we're in Bond's hang. Barry's soundtrack perfectly sets the mood...Bond's mood...every bikini-clad chick hanging by the pool a potential pleasure. Obviously this is a masterpiece of 60s cinema...acting, storytelling, sets....but the score takes everything else to a new level, communicating mood with extraordinary timing and control.A particularly brilliant transition occurs during the Fort Knox counter-assault, when the U.S. Army, who were alerted to the plot, come to life and begin the counterassault. Barry signals the shift of fortune, again brilliantly, with his upbeat cadence, its military-sounding precision with piccolos pacing the assault over the next 5 minutes. The music tells the emotional side of the story.John Barry did receive an Oscar nomination for the musical score, and Norm Wanstall won an Oscar for the best sound effects and special effects.When I think of movie scores & musical soundtracks, Goldfinger defines the highest art. The catchiness of Bond theme is as fresh today as it was 50 years ago when first heard.

The third is a charm, as it proves "Goldfinger", the great third installment of James Bond franchise!With Guy Hamilton hopping in as a director and John Barry accompanying him in making the movie, they made no mistake!James Bond (Sean Connery) is sent to investigate the gold smuggling led by Auric Goldfinger (Gert Fröbe). What simply is supposed to be a gold smuggling, it's much more dastardly and a really great villain scheme, Operation Grand Slam! Bond not only has to fight Goldfinger but his deadly and memorable henchman Oddjob (Harold Sakata). Bond gets to meet the girl who'd be measured as a equal, Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman)!James Bond goes across Mexico, Miami, United Kingdom, Switzerland all the way to Fort Knox, Kentucky to prevent Goldfinger from his deadly scheme! Is Goldfinger the villain that's so memorable that doesn't hesitate to kill Bond?The pre-title sequence is solid at its' best, but that reflection in the girl's eye is a bit ridiculous in my opinion. But wait... there's the first theme song sang beautifully by Shirley Bassey! Desmond Llewelyn has been finally credited as Q in this movie, showing his basement and introducing us to the iconic Aston Martin DB5.Shirley Eaton and Tania Mallet portray Jill and Tilly Masterson as two of Bond Girls, but the ultimate Bond girl is Pussy Galore, who's tough, knows Judo and doesn't succumb to Bond's charm until the end of the movie! Gert Fröbe is so amazing as Auric Goldfinger and his scheme is brilliant even by today's standards. Would you believe it that he was dubbed by Michael Collins? Harold Sakata is awesome in his role as a mute Oddjob, who's also able to defy the pain when James throws a gold bar at his chest. We have Felix Leiter back again, but this time recast with Cec Linder, who does his work pretty well and helps James to prevent Goldfinger's scheme.Goldfinger is indeed a great film, introducing us to the gadgets, humor, one liners and many other things Bond fans desire. Sean Connery's performance is really great!5 out of 5 stars!

Goldfinger is, in spite of the huge sums of money spent on the few last ones, the best Bond ever, and will certainly, if the directors keep on the "Action-Fun-Humor" way, stay it. First, it is useless to say it another time, but there will never be another actor as great as Sean in this part, because he had everything to be Bond. In fact, he is Bond. Pierce is surely great (better than George, Timothy or, hum, what's his name, Roger "I am an actor, look how I play with my eyebrow" Moore), but he can only see Sean's ankle. Then, the story of Goldfinger is great, and the famous gadgets are quite simple but terribly efficient for the fun of the spectator. The ugly is (with Walken (but it was with Roger) and Pryce) the best bad guy ever seen in a Bond movie, and look at his partner and his hat. Great ! Then, this is maybe the cleverest Bond movie, as it is playing with several aspects the recent directors are forgetting. It is not innocent to end with Bond, alone in Fort Knox. And in 1964, wasn't it courageous to present a female fantasy (and, well, Honor Blackman has everything to be it) as a lesbian, named Pussy ? The action is, as always, here (see the scene on the golf course, i love it), the bondgirls are, hum, quite nice, Sean is here, and so is the humor. What could we ask for more ?

This is the movie everyone should think of when they think about James Bond. It's a quintessential '60s period piece that defined the character of 007, and the spy film genre. "Goldfinger" shows a Bond that is fully fleshed out by Sean Connery in his third outing as the indestructible agent--touches of humor, anger and bemusement all rise to the surface in this performance; his James Bond is a credible, multi-faceted person. Other high watermarks featured here are the superb title theme (sung by Shirley Bassey) and soundtrack (composed by John Barry), and the wonderfully drawn villains Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) and Oddjob (Harold Sakata)--both of whom inspire legions of evildoers and their henchmen to this day. Also, this is the movie where Bond got to fully explore the gadgetry of his incredible Aston Martin DB5, which became yet another archetype of the secret agent flick.

3 things make this movie great...First, Shirley Bassey's title song is the best opening song of any of the Bond movies (and she's the only singer to sing on 2 different 007 films) (Nancy Sinatra's You Only Live Twice is a close second.)  Bassey's music also appears during the closing credits.Second, Honor Blackman is one of the best Bond girls ever...blond, blue-eyed, what a beauty!Third, during the scene where the 5 fantastic shapely blonds in their tight jump suits fly their planes over Fort Knox to gas the soldiers, listen closely for that great Goldfinger theme with the piccolo up-and-down staccato and great bass line.

This was the film that made the world fall in love with James Bond. It has a tight plot, a hero so cool that ice is warmer than him, a villain who loves being a villain, an indestructible henchman and an appeal that most other Bond films can only live up to, but never better.Auric Goldfinger is in love with gold, and is suspected of smuggling the stuff with his Rolls Royce. The British Government assign Bond to follow and gain evidence on Goldfinger, and if possible to stop him. Sounds simple enough, but this being a Bond film it's never simple. Goldfinger has several attractive women (birds really) to keep Bond entertained and also has Oddjob to dispose of any threat to Goldfinger himself.Goldfinger has more moments in it that are legend than most of the other Bond films put together. The (at the time) jaw-dropping Aston Martin, Oddjob's steel-rimmed hat, the pre-title scene where Bond blows up a drug empire and then gets into a fight to the death before electrocuting his attacker: ''Shocking. Positively shocking.'' And of course the scene where Goldfinger is about to take away Bond's ability to procreate: ''No, Mr. Bond. I expect you to die!!''Connery is in top form, suave and witty and looking as if he was born to play the role, he is also the only actor to play Bond that when he gets tough it looks real. Gert Frobe is great as Goldfinger and gets most of the best lines in the film. Goldfinger is also one of the shortest Bonds, so ordinary people won't get bored easily.A real classic, and should be on anyone who is a film lover's Top 100 list.

This masterpiece is one of the best Bond movies.After a really bad Bond movie,this one exceeded the greatness of even the really great Dr. No before it.One of the best Bond villains(and henchmen) and an amazing plot that's more focused than From Russia With Love.This is,not surprisingly,one of the most famous Bond films.Great acting and a great Bond can go a long way.Eon Productions has made better Bond movies,but this one was still amazing and would probably be in my Top 10(if I were to write that down).The cast and crew did a wonderful job on Goldfinger,very few Bond movies are better than it!A masterpiece of a Bond movie!

Many things make this one of the greatest Bond films. One is the use of the Aston Martin DB5. Another is that it is the first use of Q, who is one of the greatest characters in the series. Also, it is the first one where Bond uses ingenious gadgets which would fill the minds of people aged 5 to 500 for generations to come.The plot is much better than that of some of the earlier Bond films, with SPECTRE (SPecial Executive for Counter-intelligence, Terrorism, Revenge and Extortion) having been abandoned for a villain essentially attempting a giant bank robbery. It also features some of the first truly larger-than-life (for the time, anyway) inventions, such as Goldfinger's Industrial Laser (which is used to torture Bond after capture by Goldfinger's guards). The characters are some of the most original to have emerged from the series, such as Oddjob (Goldfinger's Korean butler).Whatever your taste in films is, there will be something in Goldfinger which you will like, so I would absolutely recommend it to everyone and anyone.

Review title: Bond wears a strap on plastic seagull hat
Review_body: James Bond wears a strap on plastic seagull hatThis entry is widely recognised as the template for all the Bond films that followed - and we can see why in the opening sequence. James Bond ( Sean Connery) in disguise wearing a strap on plastic seagull on his head.It's a Roger Moore Bond movie nine years before Roger Moore! I love the ludicrous Bond movies such as Goldfinger and Octopussy - two of my favorites. Octopussy has Roger Moore riding a plastic crocodile and Goldfinger has Sean Connery wearing a strap on plastic seagull hat!Thunderball, a year later, continued the ludicrous fun with Connery's Bond riding a jet pack and fighting cross dressing assassins.It's a shame that in 2006, the franchise died and became something utterly bland with the advent of the Craig era.

Goldfinger is a great movie. It's great Bond, and it's really the first to set the format for later movies. Many consider this the best Bond movie. While it's certainly a great Bond movie, and in the top 5, I'm not so sure it's the best. There are quite a few great Bond movies, but none of them clearly beat out the others. Anyways, this movie has it all. Great action (Bond vs Oddjob is a great action scene in the entire series), great plot, a great villain, great dialogue, great evil plot, everything about this movie is great. A must see for even the most casual fan, or a good introduction into the Connery era.

In contrast to some other opinions here, this is the best James Bond ever since it all begun with Dr. No. No need to say that Sir Sean Connery is the "only" true James Bond, Gert Fröbe appearing as Auric Goldfinger is also the most interesting villain in the history of Bond movies. The dialogues are intelligent, funny and not as much over the top as they are in today's Bond movies, the action was spectacular for those times, the Aston Martin DB7 of course is the most famous Bond gadget ever and can still be bought as models (I don't believe that is possible with any stupid satellites or Moonraker space stations or whatsoever).Sorry, just writing this, because I just could not accept the comment that came up on the start page saying: not as good as the first two.... ridiculous!

Everything about "Goldfinger" is great.  It has a great cast and crew, the story is interesting and complex, it has the best Bond character names (Auric Goldfinger, Odd Job and, of course, Pussy Galore), and Q Branch gives James Bond the classic Aston Martin DB5 (complete with ejector seat) as well as a bunch of gadgets.  Every Bond fan knows that "Goldfinger" is one of the best!  I would recommend this film to everyone.

Hands down, the funniest, liveliest Bond film ever made. Truly the first "event" film, as Connery by now comfortably fit into the roll like hand in glove. Gert Forbe as "Goldfinger" still makes the best Bond villain. The film's teaser is "shocking", the golf game is a battle-of-wits masterpiece and the car....well, what can you say about the car, other than: it's still the standard by which all other movie gadgets are measured. The film's execution is so flawless that later Bond film pale by comparison. One for the collection.

Maybe Goldfinger is the best Bond movie ever made, because the performances of Sean Connery, Gert Fröbe and all the others are outstanding and the soundtrack is a delight! I'm not sure which one is my favourite 007 movie, but Goldfinger is one of the top candidates! The only thing I dislike is that Gert Fröbe has been dubbed in the english version because it's his powerful voice that helps to give his performance the right touch.

Sheer Brilliance. One of the greatest Bond film ever made. Connery is exceptional, and the women are luscious. A ground breaking achievement in film making. Everything about this film is great. It makes you want to watch it over and over again. With names like pussy galore, what's there not to like? The great James Bond one liners, the gadgets, the girls, the guns. What more can you ask for in a film? I think this particular James Bond film stands the test of time and will go down in history for future generations to come as one of the greats. I think Golfinger has a very special quality about it. Not just for the beautiful way it is filmed, but also the authentic, intelligent, and unique ideas that make it a success.

Although I have a soft spot for all of the early Bond films, this is the best. Its so good they are still trying to emulate it thirty-eight years later. It has it all: the glamour, the wit, the fiesty girls, the locations, the marvellous Robert Brownjohn title sequence, the darkly glittering music by John Barry, the marvellously sly sets by Ken Adam, and a brilliantly assured man's man performance by Sean Connery.Infinitely quotable, and despite a hideous blue terry towelling jump-suit and some dodgy back-projection, the paradigm of sixties British cool.

Bond movies aren't the best movies in the world.  They don't win Oscars or serious critical acclaim but more often than not they do what they set out to do - entertain thoroughly.  That's the reason behind the phenomenal success of these movies over the last 40 years and soon to be 20 films. 'Goldfinger' is the best example of this.  It's two hours of great lines, car chases, silly names, great baddies, classic scenes, gadgets and cartoon violence - Goldfinger set the tone for all we expect from Bond movies. Definitely one of the series best with 'From Russia with Love', 'The Spy who Loved me', 'For your eyes Only' and 'Goldeneye'

Review title: Sean Connery and Goldfinger; an icon and a genre maker
Review_body: This movie has it all. Beautiful women, international intrigue, action from start to finish, excellent product placement, fantastic score and theme, and most importantly the only James Bond that matters: Monsieur Connery. Goldfinger created a franchise that is still popular more than 50 years after its inception. The 007 movies are fun and entertaining if not artful, but a vibrant cultural phenomenon none the less.

This is the best Bond of all. Sean Connery is great in the role of Bond.A must see action/adventure for everyone. Goldfinger has a great plot, great content, and great acting. Once again, the best Bond.

There is no work for Bond in this Movie. Villain Actor rocks. He and his Korean bodyguard are superb. Movie Plot is extremely boring and it is pathetic to see such a Villain to go down easily without causing single havoc to Protagonist. Actresses are OK, Shooting Locations are good and Cinematography isn't bad. The Movie is two time watch for Villain Actor only. As far as Hollywood Movies are concerned, this is the earliest film where i yearned for Antagonist. I am stunned by the fact that Villain Actor didn't received any Awards. But who cares? He is still remembered for his outstanding Performance in this Movie. This is the best Bond Movie until "Skyfall" arrived in 2012.

Despite the fact that almost everyone rates Goldfinger as one of the best Bond films, I thought this movie was one of the worst of the series. The movie itself was quite lacklustre, with no intensity and there were three main aspects in particular that made the movie a disappointment.The first was that Bond was under capture by Goldfinger for the majority of the movie, so he didn't have the freedom to go about his usual 007 business. The second flaw of the movie was that there was no real Bond girl. Pussy Galore ended up with this role, but she only assisted Bond towards the latter stages. The final aspect of the movie that I didn't enjoy was the fact that Bond didn't stop the bomb from exploding; he needed the assistance of the US soldiers to do it for him. This should never occur as James Bond is always the one to save the day. Overall, this movie was quite poor despite the vast majority of people who suggest otherwise.

After Casino royale my favorite movie
And Goldfinger plan is very good

Review title: One Of The World's Favourite James Bond Movies
Review_body: As a massive James Bond fan, I am glad to say that Goldfinger was the first 007 movie that I saw. Sean Connery's performance is one of his best in the series and Gert Fröbe's performance is equally impressive that not a lot of people realise that he was dubbed. Auric Goldfinger is the ultimate Bond villain - He is ruthless but very very clever. Goldfinger is also memorable among 007 fans because it is the first film in the series that features the character "Q".John Barry's score is absolutely fantastic. His soundtrack has some wonderful tracks such as "Dawn Raid On Fort Knox". Shirley Bassey does a great job with the title song and the lyrics are brilliant.The famous Austin Martin DB5 with all its gadgets is a highlight of the movie. Other highlights are the golf game between Bond and Goldfinger, and the world-famous laser scene.James Bond: Do You Expect Me To Talk? Goldfinger:  No Mr. Bond, I expect you to die.That is my favourite piece of dialogue from any film. Goldfinger is a thrill ride from start to finish and will go down in history as one of the world's favourite James Bond movies.

From the opening sequence to the climatic end sequence, this is the best Bond of all.  Best master villain Auric Goldfinger, best henchman Odd Job, Best sexy woman Pussy Galore, Best Bond Sean Connery, Best Special effects that are believable, most believable plot, etc.  While I grew up loving Roger Moore as the Saint, there always was one and only one Bond - Sean Connery.  This Bond, the third in the series, had finally developed the 007 character, sauve sophisticated, sexy and a true man of everyday action. Connery didn't need special affects and far out plots to bring out the best of the Ian Flemings character.  Having just seen the 19th in the series, the World is Not Enough, I only hope that they will simplify the plot and make Bond once again the true "action" hero.

Review title: Simply the Best James Bond Movie
Review_body: This is simply the best James Bond film of the lot, because: (1) Best Bond - Sean Connery (2) Best Bond line in opening sequence - "Simply Shocking" (3) Best Bad Guy (despite the dubbing): Goldfinger (4) Best Bad Guy's Henchman: Oddjob (5) Best Car driven by Bond: Aston Martin DB5 (6) Best retort by a Bad Guy to James Bond: JB: "Do you expect me to talk" AG: "No, I expect you to die!" (7) Best named female character: Pussy Galore (though Plenty O'Toole in "Diamonds Are Forever" comes close) (8) Best Cliche in a Bond Movie: Timer on bomb stopping at 007

Review title: Best bond film of the lot
Review_body: This has to get a better rating Its the best bond film ever made. Closely followed by The Man with the Golden Gun Then Goldeneye (which incidentally is the name of the villa that Fleming wrote most of the books). And the surname Bond means 'the world is not enough'. A Bond freak you ask - yes I am! The film is classic bond - the Aston Martin db5 makes it first appearance. And pussy galore!!! How can this film not be in the top 250. How about the part where Bond fleeces Goldfinger when playing golf to beat him and win the £5000. You need to rate this film at 10 to compensate all the other people who have bad taste in films. Cheers Del Boy

I first saw the film when I was 15 y/o. It made a big impression and I wasn't satisfied until I had seen the other Bond films. All the Sean Connery films were great, my least favorite being You Only Live Twice. Goldfinger had everything: beautiful women, great locations, terrific cars, a few airplanes. What else could you want? I've probably seen it no less than 30 times and I'll watch it again whenever it comes on. The Bond series deserves respect for the number of sequels it spawned; most films can't produce more than one or two sequels until the films become terrible such as Jaws, for instance. I've tried watching the Pierce Brosnan versions but I have never been able to sit through one.

Review title: Third Bond movie establishes the franchise
Review_body: Goldfinger begins in the same spy-movie structure as Dr No and From Russia with Love, but with a little darkish humour and exaggerated reality - characteristics that define the franchise thereafter. Bond disregards his orders and enters into his own game of intellectual one-upmanship with Goldfinger, leaving a now-conventional trail of destruction behind him.This is Sean Connery's peak performance as Bond - he begins to lose involvement after this movie. Gert Fröbe displays pleasing range as the insane antagonist, contrasting Harold Sakata's bone dry henchman.John Barry's music and the general sound of the film ooze metallic-ness and gold-ness, and this theme pays off nicely in the end game.This is the movie people think of when they say that the Sean Connery movies were the best, and I recommend it to anyone who has only seen more recent ones and is ambivalent about the whole series.8 out of 10
While thoroughly entertaining, Goldfinger is plagued by the overabundance of outdated green screens and awful fight choreography.

there is no question: gold finger is,without any doubt in my mind,and always will be the 'finest' film of the entire James bond series. many times the greatness of an impending movie is eagerly announced by the thrilling opening score,and in this case,that is certainly 'legendary'.not for nothing did 'cubby' broccoli select the great Shirley Bassey to do not just this one, (gold finger) but the opening songs to three separate bond films. theme to 'gold finger',in my estimation,is also the greatest of the bond opening themes. kudos to the great Shirley Bassey for this classic,powerful rendition.the swinging sixties 'jazzy' opening to this superlative movie also sets one up for what you just know is going to be a thrilling ride.the panoramic 'sweep' of Miami beach and the fabulous, 'fountainbleu'hotel,one of the worlds most beautiful hotels at that time, suggest terrific movie fare ahead,and this film 'never' disappoints.this is the 'third' outing for the greatest James bond that ever will be,Sean Connery, and we have had three others,all good,mind you, but none of the latter can touch him or his unique,suave manner that delineated the image of bond in the movies, immediately,since doctor no..there is 'no' improving on Mr. Connery! another sign that this film is the best in the series are the unforgettable characters and character development,which is explored and enhanced all during the film. the character, 'q',also,for the first time,is examined in earnest, and the beginnings of the tremendous,sometimes friendly,sometimes antagonistic interplay between he and James bond are first honed to maximum future effect in this movie.then there is the Aston martin db5, which, by itself, would be enough to solidly place this in the greatest lists. this was,is,and always will be 'the ' car in a bond film. speaking as a 'then, child of 8 years old,words totally fail me to describe the feeling i got when first seeing this classic on the big screen,those (hard to believe) 42 long years ago.it has stood the test of time with me, and i still get a chill and that 'spark' of nostalgia when hearing much of the fabled dialog which proliferates throughout the movie.yes...to my mind, and to many other James bond devotees,this is certainly the greatest of the James bond series,by far,and i haven't even mentioned pussy galore,Oddjob or the most classic part of the film, the laser beam scene with gold finger about to do away with our favorite secret agent,and the incredibly memorable dialog that leads up to it! gold finger delights the senses in so many ways,and thrills in so many ways to such an extent that (and i have known this for 42 years,now) they will never be able to combine elements,characters,plot, great music and skill enough in the future to ever supplant this great masterpiece of a film from being what it is, and always will be, the absolute greatest James bond film of all ! -- Brad Savage film historian --

Many of the infamous scenes associated with James Bond originate from this movie such as the gadget-filled car, the "laser" on the table scene, invading Fort Knox for its gold, and the Korean "bowler hat" killer. Sean Connery also delivers some of the best one-liners ever and the entire movie's dialogue is filled with clever little anecdotes.

The third issue of the James Bond series, Goldfinger, hit the cinemas with a huge expectation following the success of its predecessors From Russia with Love and Dr.No and it didn't disappoint. Goldfinger was the first of four Bond movies Guy Hamilton directed and with a budget of $3million and the gross revenue being $124.9million, it is safe to say that it was the crown jewel of his career and of the James Bond franchise.The film has a rather basic storyline of how Goldfinger plans to raid Fort Knox and become the richest man in the world and Bond sets out to thwart him. Though the storyline may have been nothing special but the film's use of iconography and presentation that made it outshine other Bond issues. Unlike the more recent Bond films such as Casino Royale, Quantum of Solace etc, Goldfinger has that James Bond feel to it. What I mean by this is that the newer Bond issues lack the conventions, which made it successful and unique for example there isn't as much use of gadgets in newer Bond films. I mean you have a beautiful Aston Martin DB5 and not only has it got the speed, but those gadgets within it which Bond can utilise when he is in a chase scene, that can help make it epic and breathtaking. This was shown very well in this film as Bond can shoot from using in his car, track villains down, and one particular gadget, the ejector seat, which simple but effective and amusing. There is something else which also stands out in this film and which is decreased in the newer Bond films and that is clichés. For me I think it is a huge mistake of not utilising clichés in up coming Bond films, as you look in modern times, we can watch so many films of the action/adventure genre, who now also use the similar conventions such as the gadgets, the fast cars etc, that you would want a film which is unique on its own. This is where I feel clichés are really important and how it shows this film having that James Bond feel than of Quantum of Solace for example. One real famous cliché, which is used in this film, is when Sean Connery's character says "The names Bond. James Bond". The use of clichés in this film like the one I just quoted can show the iconic status of James Bond. The acting in Goldfinger was absolutely superb especially of Sean Connery and Gert Frobe, who both had unique characters and were the perfect match in the antagonist and protagonist. This film displayed Auric Goldfinger as a real legitimate threat and as a sadistic psychopath. There is a famous scene which shows this aspect of his character where a laser beam is about cut Bond in half, James says "Do you expect me to talk, Goldfinger?" to which Goldfinger replies "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die!". In the following moments we see Bond worried and I feel this can allow us to recognise Auric Goldfinger as a powerful enemy and as an equal to Bond. The fact that we see James Bond anxious is very rare in the franchise as he has a very strong screen presence and there is an expectation of him being the powerful, authoritative figure. With this expectation, the franchise shows itself as a fairytale and the film also displays this. The character of Bond shows to be a resilient hero that defeats the bad guy and saves the world. But the earlier Bond character, which was acted by Sean Connery, Roger Moore, showed wit and humour which so dearly lacks now. Now that we distinguished the traits and personality of the good character and the bad character, what else does every evil, manipulative villain need in the James Bond franchise? For those who haven't guessed it, there is one word, which I'm looking and that's henchman. Henchmen's play a huge part in the Bond film chain (Stamper, Tee Hee and Gobinda to name a few) as they are presented as the unstoppable force that 007 has to fight. The main henchman in this film is Oddjob who is played by Harold Sakata and to be quite honest with you, he is my favourite henchman throughout the whole series. The reason being is that he is silent, manservant of Goldfinger but is a ruthless killer and ends up having an epic battle with James Bond, who has to use his intelligence and resiliency to defeat the Korean born wrecking machine. As always every Bond film needs Bond girls! Now first of all I would like us to consider the fact that Goldfinger was made in 1964, so naturally back then, the female gender was seen as the inferior sex however that did not stop the persistent use of sexual innuendo but it isn't as explicit as it used in the more recent Bond movies. The main Bond girl in this film goes by the name of Pussy Galore (note the strong use of innuendo in the name!), but she isn't the stereotypical Bond girl that gets taken in by 007. When we see her first meet James Bond, there is a clear indication that she will not be seduced and she is playing hard to get. With this we can make the clear assumption that she is not the stereotypical female, and to emphasise this further, in the film her profession is a pilot and she also has learnt judo, thus revealing the masculine nature in the character, evidently summing up why she isn't easily taken in by Bond. Eventually however, she falls for him and again it's mainly about Bond's character, his wit, his bravery, and his intelligence. Having such characteristics is sure to woo even the likes of Galore.

This is an excellent entry in the Bond Franchise and is quite possibly the best of the bunch.  It is only really rivaled by From Russia With Love and On Her Majesty's Secret Service. This is the first time we really see the "Bond Formula" in action: cool car, outrageous villain, girl with sexual innuendo name etc. We had seen these in previously in the last two films, but never all in the same one, this just brings it all together. This is a quintessential action film and a must-see for anyone with a passing interest in the bond series

I watched this again for the first time in years today and it was a bit of a let down. It doesn't deserve its rating. The film has some great elements. Elements that were truly groundbreaking at the time. The set design is spectacular. The soundtrack is brilliant. And the film on the whole is fun, entertaining and full of endless charm.However it gets let down by the story and the characters, The plot is rarely coherent. The characters are weak. They do illogical things that are completely at odds with who they are supposed to be. The manner in which Goldfinger treats Bond is completely ridiculous. And before you all disregard this review through rose-tinted spectacles you should know that I loved this film and everything about 007 when I was 10. I'm 23 now and I wanted to love this film again, but it just features gaping holes that are hard to ignore. By all means watch it, it'll entertain you, But its by no means a flawless cinematic great.

Review title: Watch Sean Connery work his magic! If you've ever watched a Bond movie, and this is not it--then, put Goldfinger on your must see list.
Review_body: Goldfinger. Some call it the best of Bond movies. I'm not sure about that statement, but the action and suspense, and the Bond intrigue alone make it worth the watching. If you're new to Bond movies and you've only seen the latest three in the series—Skyfall, Quantum of Solace, and Casino Royale, you must go back to the building of the Bond character and all that goes with it to understand the James Bond persona. This movie's main genre is a spy, action, thriller, yet after twenty-three Bond movies, I believe that Bond movies alone is a legitimate sub-genre. The Goldfinger movie is classic Bond and a must see. The film begins with the classic, rich, and identifiable Golden Girl song alongside gold-laden dancing Bond girls. Then, within the first thirty minutes the viewer finds Bond interacting with M, his boss and the head of the British Secret Service, and Q, the wizard of all Bond gadgetry. Moneypenny, M's secretary, exchanges some brief, cloaked, flirtatious remarks with Bond. In addition, the Aston Martin is introduced. And, not the least, Bond beds a woman who ends up dead and painted in gold! Thus begins the larger story as Bond works to find out how the psychopath, Auric Goldfinger, sends his gold overseas, illegally. Bond then ultimately discovers that Fort Knox is in danger as the mighty Goldfinger plans to infiltrate this well guarded facility to become the wealthiest gold baron in the world. How he plans to do this and how Bond and crew foil his plan must be seen by watching the film. No spoilers here. Some classic Bond lines appear in this third film in the series that will be used over and over to build the Bond character. When asked what drink he wants, Bond says "a martini, shaken, not stirred." More than once when he is asked his name he says, "Bond, James Bond." And when Bond asks Goldfinger's personal pilot her name, she openly says Pussy Galore. This use of a double entendre for the names of Bond girls becomes a staple in Bond films. This film moves from Miami Beach to Switzerland to Baltimore and finally Kentucky as Bond chases Goldfinger. (The camera shows off the scenery in Miami and Switzerland as is to be expected in a Bond movie.) Bond is often imprisoned during this long chase. All the while his friends in the CIA are monitoring his moves as much as possible. Bond repeatedly gets out of life threatening situations and somehow avoids the wrath of Oddjob (Goldfinger's manservant) and his slicing hat! Looking back over fifty years of Bond movies, some scenes may seem predictable, yet the formula used for this series must have something going for it as the next Bond movie is currently in the works in 2014! It's hard to find any series that has survived this long. Sean Connery as James Bond, Honor Blackman as Pussy Galore, Gert Frobe as Auric Goldfinger, and Shirly Eaton as Jill Masterson give superb performances as they were nominated for many awards. In the film, Jill Masterson was painted in gold and died of skin suffocation after she betrayed Goldfinger and gave her loyalties to Bond. Her gold, nude body lying on a bed is an iconic movie image. As Goldfinger is watched for the very first time you will see much more in this film to build your Bond IQ. Enjoy!

I saw this movie for a second time yesterday (Friday 5th July 2013) and boy was I again disappointed! Nothing in this movie makes sense. This goes for subplots as well as for the plot in its entirety. I could give a thousand of examples, but just don't where to start. Everything really. Take the 1st appearance of Goldfinger. Seconds after appearing, he is busy cheating with the cards. But, while doing so, he is *very* obviously wearing a headphone so that even to a really uninformed playing partner, his cheating would have to be *very, very* obvious. Yet, in the movie, he gets away with is. A second example (whatever comes to the mind, a 1000 examples are possible, I am sure). Later on, Bond get stupidly caught, and finds himself tight to a table. With a laser gun advancing dangerously towards his vital parts, he does some "quick thinking" and says to Goldfinger: "Can you take that risk?". Meaning: can Goldfinger, the bad guy, take the risk that his so-called "Grand Slam"-operation would perhaps be known to a "back-up" agent of Bond, because that back-up agent would presumably know as much of this plan as Bond does, that is: nothing at all? Well, Goldfinger, for no good reason at all, decides he can't take that risk. The logical thing to do would have been to ask - for instance - to tell him just *a little bit* more about that plan, even just 1 or 2 words like "contamination" or "Ford Knox", but no, this so-called brilliant criminal isn't even smart enough to figure that out and decides that Bond is more worth to him alive than dead. And so on and so on ... A *tremendously* overrated movie. For me: 1/10 (even if the late Robert Egbert, whom I usually respect a lot in his ratings and reviews, gives it 4 stars).

Review title: I'm Not Sure Why The Reviews Are So Good
Review_body: I am not sure why this is regarded as such a good movie. The acting is generally not that great, the story itself is absolutely ridiculous and barely strung together, and the characters themselves are almost laughable. But most importantly, none of the events in the movie seem to flow together in anyway, things just sort of happen one after the other.I suppose this is one of those movies that was/is really important to those who saw it at or near its initial release. However, I find it almost sad that this is in the same family as Dr. No, a film I genuinely enjoyed. As far as I am concerned this is not only a terrible James Bond movie, but just a terrible movie in general.

Even though this movie is over 50 years old with some special effects that look primitive by today's standards it is still one of the greatest spy movies of all time. Sean Connery is as young and fit as we've ever seen as 007 and Auric Goldfinger is introduced as a classic Bond villain, "...no Mr. Bond I expect you to die." Also,
in this movie the viewer gets their first introduction to Bonds Aston Martin DB5, his trademark auto of choice.

Widely proclaimed a THE best Bond movie ever made, This milestone to action films best captures the wit, danger, and secrecy of the bond world. Sean Connery portrays the role of 007 (bond, James bond) flawlessly capturing the exact nuance and style of Ian Fleming's original Secret Agent. Never missing a beat yet rolling with every punch, This godly hero is the perfect secret agent. If there were 1 Bond movie to see, this is the one.perhaps the most notable classic feature Is the Q-gadgets. The ingenious and slightly anal Q (lewllen Desmond) provides Bond with a fantastic tool for his every need. Ranging from tracking-beacon shoes to a super Aston-Martin (with ejector seats, no less) 007 squeezes though many a hard place thanks to his old friend. The other side comes well equipped with lasers, nerve gas, and even a decapitating bowler hat! Action packed scenes are well placed, neither dull or overpowering to the storyline. However, If you only watch movies for guns and explosions, you might be a tad disappointed. Unlike the later films, this is focused on the stealth and subtle but meaningful action. It emphasizes that James bond is a SPY not an all-destroying super weapon of the British government. A well placed false identity or smokescreen is more appreciated than a panzer and a 50-megaton rocket.The Evil "Evil genius" goldfinger has an ingenious plan, Not impossibly outrageous as A space colony and doomsday weapons, but not a petty theft. Oh I could gush for hours, but I won't give anything away.So, be you a new viewer or a die-hard Bond fan (I being the latter) This the must-have for any secret agent. Being coined and parodied for decades, this classic should be missing from any collector. You may have trouble finding in stores, but don't let that stop you from seeing THE greatest bond of all time. Like Wal-mart, The net is always open. and e-bay is almost certain to have a spare copy, or any other classic movie dealer. I hope I could help you, make sure you get YOUR goldfingers on this icon of films.
